nuisance, originating on county property, that impacts neighboring lands so
that their owners or occupants sustain a special and unreasonable interference
with the quiet enjoyment of their property?
      4.   Does the action interfere with a fundamental attribute of ownership
such as the right to reasonable access, the right to light, air and view within
the right of way of an abutting public street, or the right to exclude others
from private property?
      5.   Does the action unreasonably interfere with a separately protected
and vested right, such as the right to continue a nonconforming use; the right
to have an application reviewed under the law that was in effect when a
complete application was submitted; legally issued subdivision plat approvals,
building permits or licenses; or other protected property interests?
      6.   Does the action impose a severe economic burden that is
inappropriately unfair when considered in light of: a) the burden placed on the
property owner; b) the nature of the government action and benefit; and c) the
property owner's investment backed expectations?
      7.   Does the action deprive the property owner of all economically
viable use of the property in a situation where the proposed use does not
constitute a nuisance or a severe threat to health and safety?
      8.   Does the action limit the use of private property without
substantially advancing a legitimate public interest?
      9.   Has the county failed to demonstrate by an individualized
determination that any conditions, dedications or exactions imposed as a
condition of approval of development applications place only fair and roughly
proportionate burdens on development, offsetting the burdens that the proposed
development places on public utilities, streets and other services, but not
imposing additional burdens on development that the community as a whole should
bear?
      10.   Does the action discriminate against property owners, imposing
restrictions or burdens on one property owner that other similarly situated
property owners do not bear? (Ord. 2003-826-O, 2-18-2003, eff. 2-24-2003)
1-13-5: ANALYSIS:
If the county determines that a governmental action involves constitutional
taking issues, the proposed action should be reviewed by the county to analyze
the possible taking and to determine the action to be taken. In reviewing the
proposed action, the following factors may be analyzed:
   A.   The affect the potential taking would have on the use or value of the
private property.
   B.   The likelihood that the action may result in a constitutional taking.
   C.   Any alternatives to the proposed action that would fulfill the county's
lawful objectives and reduce the risk of a constitutional taking.
   D.   The cost to the county for payment of compensation if a taking is
determined. (Ord. 2003-826-O, 2-18-2003, eff. 2-24-2003)
1-13-6: APPEALS:
Any owner of private property whose interest in the property is subject to a
physical or regulatory taking by the county, pursuant to a final and
authoritative decision or action of the county, may appeal the county's
decision or action by filing a written notice of appeal and statement of the
grounds for the appeal in the county commission's office within thirty (30)
calendar days from the date of the county's decision or action. The county
commission, or its designee, shall hear all evidence regarding the appeal and
render its decision and findings in writing within fourteen (14) days from the
date the appeal was filed. If the county fails to hear and decide the appeal
within fourteen (14) days, the county's decision or action is presumed to be
approved. (Ord. 2003-826-O, 2-18-2003, eff. 2-24-2003)
1-13-7: LIMITATIONS:
The guidelines set forth herein are advisory only and shall not be construed to
expand nor limit the scope of the county's liability for a constitutional
taking. The county shall have no legal liability to any person, firm or entity
of any nature whatsoever, and a court may not impose liability upon the county
for failure to comply with the provisions of this chapter, or the provisions of
Utah Code Annotated section 63-90a-1 et seq., as amended. (Ord. 2003-826-O, 2-
18-2003, eff. 2-24-2003)
1-13-8: LEGAL ACTION:
A property owner's failure to appeal the action of the county does not
constitute, and may not be interpreted as constituting, a failure to exhaust
available administrative remedies or as a bar to bringing legal action. (Ord.
2003-826-O, 2-18-2003, eff. 2-24-2003)
CHAPTER 14
ELECTION PRECINCTS
SECTION:
1-14-1: Established
1-14-2: Boundary Descriptions
1-14-3: U.S. Congressional District
1-14-4: Utah State School Board District
1-14-5: State Senate Districts
1-14-6: State House Districts
1-14-7: Local School Board Districts
1-14-1: ESTABLISHED:
The following described election precincts are established in Washington
County. All boundary descriptions are set forth below generally and more fully
set forth on the Washington County precinct map available for inspection in the
office of the Washington County clerk. (Ord. 2012-1015-O, 1-26-2012)
1-14-2: BOUNDARY DESCRIPTIONS:
   A.   Election Precinct STG01; St George: Beginning at the intersection of
The St George City limit line and 2450 East Street; thence south along 2450
East Street to its intersection with the north boundary of the River Bend
Estates subdivision; thence east along the north boundary of the River Bend
Estates subdivision to it transition to 175 North Street (including parcel SG-
RBE-A-20-A) and its intersection with 2750 East Street, thence south along 2750
East Street to its intersection with the north boundary of the Paradise Vista
subdivision; thence east along the north boundary of the Paradise Vista
subdivision to its intersection with 3050 East Street; thence northerly along
3050 East Street to its intersection with 170 North Street; thence east along
170 North Street to its intersection with the east boundary of the Palms of St
George subdivision; thence south along the west boundary of the Palms of St
George subdivision to its intersection with the Virgin River; thence easterly
along the Virgin River to its intersection with the St George City limit line;
thence east, north and west on the St George City limit line to the point of
beginning. The above and foregoing shall be known as Election Precinct Number -
one STG01.
   B.    Election Precinct STG02; St George: Beginning at the intersection of
2450 East Street and 50 South Street; thence west along 50 South Street to its
intersection with 2200 East Street; thence north along 2200 East Street to its
intersection with 40 North Street; thence east along 40 North Street to its
intersection with 2450 East Street; thence north along 2450 East Street to its
intersection with the north boundary of the River Bend Estates subdivision;
thence east along the north boundary of the River Bend subdivision to its
transition to 175 North Street, excluding parcel SG-RBE-A-20-A; thence east
along 175 North Street to its intersection with 2750 East Street; thence south
along 2750 East Street to its intersection with the north boundary line of the
Paradise Vista subdivision; thence east along the north boundary of the
Paradise Vista subdivision to its transition to the south lot line of parcel
SG-MIP-20-A-1-A-2-B-MB and its intersection with 3050 East Street; thence
northerly along 3050 East Street to its intersection with 170 North Street;
thence easterly along 170 North Street to its intersection with the east
boundary of the Palms of St George Subdivision; thence south along the east
boundary of the Palms of St George subdivision to its intersection with the St
George City limit line; thence westerly along the St George City limit line to
its intersection with the north lot line of parcel SG-5-2-27-3421; thence west
along the north lot line of parcel SG-5-2-27-3421 to its intersection with 2450
East Street; thence northerly along 2450 East Street to the point of beginning.
The above and foregoing shall be known as Election Precinct Number St George -
two SG02.

CHAPTER 15
OPEN AND PUBLIC MEETINGS ACT (OPMA)
SECTION:
1-15-1: Meetings
1-15-2: Electronic Meetings
1-15-1: MEETINGS:
The Washington County Commission hereby adopts those definitions and terms as
defined in Utah Code Title 52 Chapter 4, the Open and Public Meetings Act
("OPMA"), as amended. (Ord. 2021-1174-O, 4-6-2021)
1-15-2: ELECTRONIC MEETINGS:
   A.   The Washington County Commission recognizes and authorizes that county
boards, commissions, committees or other county public bodies may, from time to
time as needed, convene and conduct public meetings in which one or more
members attend and participate in the meeting through electronic means and
pursuant to OPMA as found in Utah Code Title 52 Chapter 4.
   B.   One anchor location for electronic meetings shall be the location of
regularly published public body meetings, unless a different anchor location is
designated. A different anchor location may be designated, as long as adequate
facilities are provided for public attendance. If comments from the public will
be accepted during the electronic meeting, space and facilities at the anchor
location will be provided, so interested persons and the public may attend,
monitor, and participate in the open portions of the meeting.
   C.   The public body may allow members of the public, through electronic
means, to attend, monitor, and, where appropriate. participate in the public
portion of electronic meetings.
   D.   The public body may conduct an electronic meeting without an anchor
location in accordance with Utah Code Section 52-4-207.
   E.   Notice of the meeting is to be given pursuant to the special noticing
requirements of Utah Code Sections 52-4-207(3) and 52-4-202. (Ord. 2021-1174-O,
4-6-2021)
CHAPTER 16
COUNTY RECORDER
SECTION:
1-16-1:   County Recorder; Appeal Of A Recorder Decision
1-16-1: COUNTY RECORDER; APPEAL OF A RECORDER DECISION:
   A.   There shall be an office of county recorder, headed by an elected
county recorder. The office of county recorder shall have all the functions,
responsibilities and powers provided under Utah Code section 17-21-1 et seq.
(as amended) and by other applicable law.
   B.   Appeal Of A Recorder Decision:
      1.   County Recorder decisions may be appealed:
         a.   By a person with standing that is adversely affected as a result
of the Recorder’s decision by alleging that the Recorder’s decision did not
comply with rules made by the County Recorder Standards Board under Utah Code
section 63C-30-202 (as amended); and
         b.   Only if it is the final decision issued by the Recorder, as
appeals of decisions made by supporting staff must be reviewed by the Recorder.
      2.   A Notice Of Appeal Must:
         a.   Commence within 10 business days of the adverse order,
requirement, decision, or determination by filing a written notice of appeal
with the Washington County Recorder’s Office; and
         b.   Identify the decision being appealed, the allegation of non-
compliance, and the party making the appeal.
      3.   The appellant has the burden of evidencing that the Recorder’s
decision did not comply with rules made by the County Recorder Standards Board
under Utah Code section 63C-30-202 (as amended).
      4.   The Appeal Authority shall be a Hearing Officer as used for appeals
of Land Use Authority Decisions under Washington County Code 10-2-5 (as
amended). The Hearing Officer for an appeal under this Chapter shall have
sufficient qualifications or experience to hear such an appeal.
         a.   When a notice of appeal is filed, the Appeal Authority will hear
the appeal at the next regularly scheduled meeting for a hearing, unless such
time is extended for good cause or stipulation of the parties; and
         b.   The Appeal Authority may require written briefs or memorandum of
the parties as the Appeal Authority deems necessary. At the hearing, the
appellant must appear in person or by agent.
      5.   Substantial evidence is permissible as the evidentiary standard of
review, the Appeal Authority determines the correctness of a decision of the
Recorder in its interpretation and application rules made by the County
Recorder Standards Board under Utah Code section 63C-30-202. Only those
decisions in which the Recorder has applied rules made by the County Recorder
Standards Board under Utah Code section 63C-30-202 may be appealed.
      6.   Hearing Procedures shall follow those established in Washington
County Code
10-2-6 (as amended).
      7.   The Appeal Authority must issue a decision in writing within 30 days
of the final hearing, which constitutes a final decision under Utah Code
section 17-50-340 (as amended).
      8.   Any person adversely affected by a final decision of the Appeal
Authority may petition the Fifth District Court for judicial review of the
decision as permitted by law. (Ord. 2023-1235-O, 6-30-2023)
TITLE 2
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
CHAPTER 1
COUNCIL ON AGING
SECTION:
2-1-1: Title
2-1-2: Statutory Authority
2-1-3: Purpose Of Provisions
2-1-4: Established
2-1-5: Membership
2-1-6: Employees
2-1-7: Budget
2-1-1: TITLE:
The chapter shall be known as the WASHINGTON COUNTY COUNCIL ON AGING ENABLING
ORDINANCE. (Ord. 718, 9-18-2000, eff. 9-21-2000)
2-1-2: STATUTORY AUTHORITY:
The statutory authority for enacting this chapter is Utah Code Annotated
section 17-53-223, as amended. (Ord. 718, 9-18-2000, eff. 9-21-2000)
2-1-3: PURPOSE OF PROVISIONS:
The purpose of this chapter is to create a council on aging to assist and
advise the county in improving, developing, coordinating and strengthening
programs for the county's growing elderly population and to more fully utilize
the potential of the county's older citizens, their skills, wisdom and
experience. (Ord. 718, 9-18-2000, eff. 9-21-2000)
2-1-4: ESTABLISHED:
The council on aging is hereby established to assist and advise the county
commission and the county council on aging program director to:
   A.   Promote and develop programs of interest and to provide for the welfare
of senior citizens;
   B.   Cooperate with the five (5) county association of governments and other
public and private agencies on the local, state and national levels, to more
effectively meet the needs of and provide opportunities for older persons;
   C.   Provide educational, recreational and social activities for senior
citizens;
   D.   Provide volunteer and service opportunities to senior citizens;
   E.   Foster positive public relations on behalf of senior citizens and the
county's senior programs; and
   F.   Develop funding and other resources at the local, state and national
level to provide services to senior citizens. (Ord. 718, 9-18-2000, eff. 9-21-
2000)
2-1-5: MEMBERSHIP:
   A.   Specified: The council on aging consists of nine (9) regular voting
members, who shall be sixty (60) years of age or older, who shall be
representative of the county senior citizen centers in St. George, Hurricane
and Enterprise, and at least three (3) of whom shall be lay citizens. In
addition, the council may have the following ex officio, nonvoting members: a
member of the county commission; the council on aging program director;
supervisors of the Washington County senior citizen centers; and, at the
discretion of the county commission, other individuals involved in the
provision of services or programs to the elderly.
   B.   Vacancies: Vacancies among the nine (9) regular voting members of the
council on aging, are filled by appointment by the county commission, who may
follow recommendations submitted by the council on aging. Appointments to fill
new or expiring terms are effective January 1 of each year. Appointments to
fill vacated terms take effect upon appointment and last for the balance of the
vacated term.
   C.   Staggered Terms: Appointments as a regular voting member are to be
staggered as follows, and thereafter for three (3) year terms:
      1.   Three (3) appointments expiring December 31, 2000;
      2.   Three (3) appointments expiring December 31, 2001; and
      3.   Three (3) appointments expiring December 31, 2002.
   D.   Officers: The council on aging may elect the following officers to
three (3) year terms from among its regular voting members: chairperson, vice
chairperson and secretary. The election will take place at the council on
aging's first regular meeting of the year, every three (3) years.
   E.   Meetings: The council on aging shall meet at least three (3) times a
year and may have special meetings as needed, which may be called by the chair
of the council on aging or the council on aging director. A quorum of the
council on aging will consist of five (5) regular voting members.
   F.   Compensation: Council on aging members shall serve as volunteers
without compensation; however, members may be reimbursed for actual expenses
incurred on behalf of the council on aging.
   G.   Removal: The county commission may remove members of the council on
aging for good cause. Any member absent without cause from three (3) or more
regular meetings in any one year, may be removed.
(Ord. 2016-1078-O, 12-20-2016; Ord. 2019-1146-O, 9-17-2019)
2-1-6: EMPLOYEES:
Personnel and employment decisions regarding the county's elderly programs are
under the sole discretion and control of the county commission and its
designated personnel director. (Ord. 718, 9-18-2000, eff. 9-21-2000)
2-1-7: BUDGET:
The county commission will annually establish a budget for the council on aging
based upon the council on aging's recommendations. It is the express desire of
the county commission that the council on aging be self-sufficient insofar as
possible and subject to minimal oversight and control by the county commission.
Monies collected and expended shall be accounted for annually by the council on
aging and audited annually by the county clerk/auditor before the approval of
the succeeding year's budget. (Ord. 718, 9-18-2000, eff. 9-21-2000)
CHAPTER 2
ACCIDENT REVIEW BOARD
SECTION:
2-2-1: Board Established
2-2-2: Report Of Accident
2-2-3: Evaluation By Board
2-2-4: Determination By Board
2-2-5: Written Report
2-2-6: Department Head Responsibility
2-2-7: Disciplinary Action
2-2-8: Appeal
2-2-1: BOARD ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established an accident review board for the county. The
accident review board shall consist of one county commissioner, the county
administrator, one member of the county attorney’s office, one member of the
sheriff’s office, one representative from the human resources department, one
representative from the county road department, one representative from the
county assessor’s office, one representative from the council on aging, and the
county insurance coordinator. The accident review board shall review each
vehicular accident involving county employees and county vehicles as described
herein, and shall forward its conclusions and recommendations to the board of
commissioners and to the department head of the employee involved in said
accident. Other types of accidents may be reviewed by the accident review board
upon request of the department head of the employee involved in the accident.
(Ord. 2003-828-O, 3-18-2003; amd. Ord. 2022-1207-O, 5-3-2022)
2-2-2: REPORT OF ACCIDENT:
Each accident involving a county vehicle shall be reported to the local police,
sheriff or highway patrol in accordance with Utah Code Annotated. The accident
shall also be investigated by the supervisor of the employee involved in the
accident. Each employee involved in an accident with a county vehicle shall
submit a signed, detailed report to his or her supervisor on forms to be
supplied by the county. The supervisor shall retain a copy of the report for
the department files and shall forward the original report to the county
insurance coordinator. The county insurance coordinator will submit the
accident report for consideration by the accident review board. (Ord. 2003-828-
O, 3-18-2003)
2-2-3: EVALUATION BY BOARD:
The accident review board shall evaluate the accident and shall consider any or
all of the following information:
   A.   Written evidence presented by the driver of the county vehicle, the
supervisor and the police report of the accident investigation.
   B.   Maintenance records of the vehicle or the other information available
concerning the vehicle both before and after the accident, including estimates
of the cost of repair.
   C.   Laboratory tests of vehicle parts.
   D.   The driver's past driving record.
   E.   Diagrams, photographs and other evidence.
   F.   Testimony of other drivers and witnesses present. (Ord. 2003-828-O, 3-
18-2003)
2-2-4: DETERMINATION BY BOARD:
The accident review board shall determine, as far as possible, the cause of the
accident and whether the accident was preventable. A "preventable accident" is
herein defined as an accident in which the driver failed to exercise every
reasonable precaution to prevent the accident. (Ord. 2003-828-O, 3-18-2003)
2-2-5: WRITTEN REPORT:
The accident review board shall prepare and submit a written report of their
findings and recommendations to the department head of the employee involved in
the accident to implement corrective action, if indicated. The report shall
also be delivered to the county commission, and to the human resources
department to be placed in the employee's personnel file. A copy of the report
shall be given to the employee. (Ord. 2003-828-O, 3-18-2003)
2-2-6: DEPARTMENT HEAD RESPONSIBILITY:
The employee's department head shall review the findings and the recommendation
of the accident review board, including recommended corrective measures, as
soon as practical. The department head shall determine the corrective action
and/or discipline, if any, to be administered to the employee and shall report
the action taken to the county commission. (Ord. 2008-965-O, 9-16-2008)
2-2-7: DISCIPLINARY ACTION:
If the accident involved the violation of established policies associated with
preventing injuries and incurring liability, corrective disciplinary action
shall be taken as soon as practical. Appropriate disciplinary action may
include loss of driving privileges, required defensive driving courses,
reassignment or termination of employment. (Ord. 2003-828-O, 3-18-2003)
2-2-8: APPEAL:
In the event the employee disagrees with the findings of the accident review
board or with the action taken by his or her department head, the employee may
file an appeal to the county commission. In order for the appeal to be
considered, the appeal must be in writing and must be filed with the county
commission within thirty (30) days of the date on which the employee is
provided with a copy of the report from the accident review board. (Ord. 2003-
828-O, 3-18-2003)
CHAPTER 3
LIBRARY BOARD
SECTION:
2-3-1: Statutory Authority
2-3-2: Purpose Of Provisions
2-3-3: Library Board Of Directors
2-3-4: Bylaws And Officers
2-3-5: Library Fund Deposits
2-3-6: Responsibilities And Duties Of Library Board Of Directors
2-3-7: Duties And Responsibilities Of Library Director
2-3-1: STATUTORY AUTHORITY:
The statutory authority for enacting this chapter is Utah Code Annotated
section 9-7-501 et seq., as amended. (Ord. 2005-865-O, 1-18-2005)
2-3-2: PURPOSE OF PROVISIONS:
The purpose of this chapter is to delegate certain policy responsibilities to
the county library board ("board") and provide basic guidelines and procedures
for library operation. (Ord. 2005-865-O, 1-18-2005)
2-3-3: LIBRARY BOARD OF DIRECTORS:
   A.   Established: There is hereby established the county library board of
directors, which shall consist of not less than five (5) and not more than nine
(9) directors from the citizens of the county.
   B.   Commission Member: Only one director of the board may be a member of
the county commission (legislative body) at any one time.
   C.   Appointment: All directors shall be appointed by the county commission.
Appointments to the board shall be made before July 1 of each year in which an
appointment is necessary.
   D.   Terms: Directors shall be appointed to serve for four (4) year terms,
or until their successors are appointed, and shall not serve more than two (2)
consecutive full terms.
   E.   Staggered Terms: Terms of directors shall be staggered so that
approximately one-fourth (1/4) of the board is appointed each year.
   F.   Removal: The county commission may remove any director for misconduct
or neglect of duty.
   G.   Vacancies: Vacancies created by resignation, death, removal, or
otherwise shall be filled for the duration of the unexpired term in the same
manner as the original appointment. (Ord. 2005-865-O, 1-18-2005)
2-3-4: BYLAWS AND OFFICERS:
   A.   Bylaws: The board shall adopt bylaws for managing the business and
affairs of the board.
   B.   Officers: The board shall elect a chair and such other officers as
specified by state law and/or the board's bylaws. The chair shall arrange staff
to take minutes and maintain official records of board actions. (Ord. 2005-865-
O, 1-18-2005)
2-3-5: LIBRARY FUND DEPOSITS:
The county treasurer shall have legal custody of all library fees/fines and
other funds collected or received by the library, and taxes and fees collected
by the county, and shall act as the treasurer of such funds. The library fund
may not be used for any purpose except that of the county library. The county
treasurer shall not be a member of the board. (Ord. 2005-865-O, 1-18-2005)
2-3-6: RESPONSIBILITIES AND DUTIES OF LIBRARY BOARD OF DIRECTORS:
Subject to compliance with federal laws, state laws, and county ordinances and
policies, the board is hereby granted responsibility for:
   A.   The expenditure of library funds as budgeted by the county commission;
   B.   Establishing and revising policies in cooperation with the library
director for the use, operation, maintenance, and care of the library, library
facilities, equipment, staff and other such resources;
   C.   Establishing policies for the enforcement of library rules and
applicable laws and ordinances;
   D.   Establishing policies for selection, acquisition, cataloging,
maintenance, and use of the library collections and information resources, and
submit those policies to the county attorney for review;
   E.   Establishing rules to exclude from the use of the library any person
who wilfully violates library rules, and submit those rules to the county
attorney for review;
   F.   Recommending to the county commission a competent person for
appointment to serve as the county librarian, with those duties specified in a
job description approved by the library board and the county commission;
   G.   The county commission shall, within thirty (30) days of the
recommendation, either make the appointment or request that the board submit
another recommendation;
   H.   Make an annual report to the county commission on the condition and
operation of the library, including a financial statement;
   I.   Submit an annual report to the state library board;
   J.   Furnish to the county commission, in writing, and prior to the time
required by law to levy county taxes, an estimate of the amount of monies
necessary to establish, equip, and maintain the library, and to provide library
services during the next ensuing fiscal year and certify the amount; and
   K.   Perform such other duties and exercise such other powers as may be
specifically assigned or delegated to the library board by the county
commission. (Ord. 2005-865-O, 1-18-2005)
2-3-7: DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES OF LIBRARY DIRECTOR:
The county library director shall:
   A.   Executive Officer: Serve as the executive officer for the board.
   B.   Administrative Officer And Department Head: Serve as the administrative
officer and department head of the county library system as a department of the
county in accordance with and subject to the requirements of county ordinances,
policies, and procedures.
   C.   Other Established Duties: Perform such other duties related to the
library as established in the official job description or as may be assigned by
the county commission. (Ord. 2005-865-O, 1-18-2005)
CHAPTER 4
ETHICS COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-4-1: Definitions
2-4-2: Formation And Composition
2-4-3: Ethics Complaints; Who May File
2-4-4: Filing; Form
2-4-5: Review Of Complaint For Compliance With Form Requirements

2-4-7: Scheduling And Notice
2-4-8: Response To Ethics Complaint
2-4-9: Hearings
2-4-10: Decision
2-4-11: Special Service District And Local District Option
2-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
EMPLOYEE: A person who is an officer, employee, or volunteer of Washington
County and subject to Utah Code Annotated title 17, chapter 16a, county
officers and employees disclosure act.
ETHICS VIOLATION: A violation of Utah Code Annotated title 17, chapter 16a,
county officers and employees disclosure act. (Ord. 2012-1022-O, 9-18-2012)
2-4-2: FORMATION AND COMPOSITION:
   A.   The Washington County ethics commission is established.
   B.   The Washington County commission is authorized to designate, by
resolution, the members of the Washington County career service council as the
members of the Washington County ethics commission. If the county commission
does so, then the terms of the career council members and the ethics commission
members shall coincide.
Alternatively, the Washington County commission may appoint the members of the
Washington County ethics commission to terms of three (3) years. The Washington
County ethics commission shall be composed of three (3) members. Each member of
the ethics commission must be a resident of Washington County. No member of the
ethics commission may be currently employed by Washington County.
   C.   The Washington County ethics commission shall adopt rules and
procedures in accordance with this chapter.
   D.   The Washington County ethics commission shall render final decisions on
matters brought before it in accordance with this chapter. (Ord. 2012-1022-O,
9-18-2012)
2-4-3: ETHICS COMPLAINTS; WHO MAY FILE:
   A.   Who May File:
      1.   Subject to the requirements of subsections A2 and A3 of this
section, any combination of three (3) or more registered voters who reside
within the boundaries of the county or who pay a fee or tax to the county may
file an ethics complaint.
      2.   A person described in subsection A1 of this section may not file a
complaint unless at least one of the complainants has actual knowledge of the
facts and circumstances supporting the alleged ethics violation.
      3.   A complainant may file a complaint only against an individual who,
on the date that the complaint is filed, is serving as a county employee. (Ord.
2012-1022-O, 9-18-2012)
2-4-4: FILING; FORM:
   A.   A complaint shall be filed with the office of the county clerk/auditor:
      1.   In good faith;
      2.   Within ninety (90) days from the date the complainant(s) first learn
of the alleged ethics violation, except that:
         a.   A complaint may not be filed during the ninety (90) calendar days
immediately preceding:
            (1)   A regular primary election, if the accused officer is a
candidate in the primary election; or
            (2)   A regular general election in which an accused officer is a
candidate.
         b.   If a complaint is delayed subject to subsection A2a of this
section, the filing time limit will be tolled.
   B.   Each complaint filed under this section shall be in writing and contain
the following information:
      1.   The name and position of the employee alleged to be in violation;
      2.   The name, address, and telephone number of each individual who is
filing the complaint;
      3.   A description of each alleged ethics violation, as applicable of
Utah Code Annotated title 17, chapter 16a, county officers and employees
disclosure act;
      4.   For each alleged ethics violation:
         a.   A reference to the section of the code alleged to have been
violated;
         b.   The name of the complainant who has actual knowledge of the facts
and circumstances supporting each allegation; and
         c.   With reasonable specificity, the facts and circumstances
supporting each allegation;
      5.   A list of the witnesses with information related to the complaint,
including for each witness:
         a.   The name, address, and, if available, one or more telephone
numbers of the witness;
         b.   A brief summary of the testimony to be provided by the witness;
and
         c.   A specific description of any documents or evidence a complainant
desires the witness to produce;
      6.   A statement that each complainant:
         a.   Has reviewed the allegations contained in the complaint and the
sworn statements and documents attached to the complaint;
         b.   Believes that the complaint is submitted in good faith and not
for any improper purpose such as for the purpose of harassing the respondent,
causing unwarranted harm to the respondent's reputation, or causing unnecessary
expenditure of public funds; and
         c.   Believes the allegations contained in the complaint to be true
and accurate; and
      7.   The signature of each complainant. (Ord. 2012-1022-O, 9-18-2012)
2-4-5: REVIEW OF COMPLAINT FOR COMPLIANCE WITH FORM REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Within fourteen (14) calendar days after the receipt of a complaint,
the county clerk/auditor shall examine the complaint to determine if it is in
compliance with this chapter.
   B.   If the clerk/auditor determines that the complaint does not comply with
this chapter, the clerk/auditor shall:
      1.   Return the complaint to the first complainant named on the complaint
with:
         a.   A statement detailing the reason for the noncompliance; and
         b.   A copy of the applicable provisions in this chapter; and
      2.   Notify the applicable government department that a complaint was
filed against an employee of the department but was returned for noncompliance
with this chapter.
   C.   If a complaint is returned for noncompliance with the requirements of
this chapter, a complainant may file a renewed complaint if the new complaint
independently meets the requirements of this chapter. If more than ninety (90)
days have passed from the date the complainant(s) first learned of the alleged
ethics violation, then in order to be timely received a renewed complainant
must be filed within fourteen (14) days from the date the complainant received
notice of the deficiency of the complaint. (Ord. 2012-1022-O, 9-18-2012)
2-4-6: PRELIMINARY REVIEW:
   A.   If the clerk/auditor determines that the complaint complies with the
requirements of this chapter, the clerk/auditor shall send the complaint to the
county attorney and the county commission chair within fourteen (14) days of
receiving the complaint.
The county attorney shall review the complaint, in consultation with the county
commission chair, in accordance with this section. However, if the county
attorney or the county commission chair are named parties to the complaint then
the full county commission shall review the complaint.
   B.   The preliminary review of the complaint shall consider:
      1.   Whether the facts alleged, if true, constitute an ethics violation;
      2.   Whether the complaint includes an affidavit from a person with
firsthand knowledge of alleged facts as described in subsection 2-4-3A2 of this
chapter;
      3.   Whether the complaint is frivolous or solely for a political
purpose; and
      4.   Whether the complaint fails to meet any requirement of this chapter.
   C.   If the preliminary reviewer(s) determines that a complaint: 1) does not
contain an ethics violation; 2) is not based on firsthand knowledge; 3) is
frivolous or solely for a political purpose; or 4) fails to meet any
requirement of this chapter, then the complaint shall be dismissed. The
reviewer(s) shall notify the first named complainant, in writing, of the
dismissal and the reason for the dismissal.
   D.   If the preliminary reviewer(s) determines that a complaint should not
be dismissed in accordance with this chapter, then within fourteen (14) days of
making the determination the reviewer(s) shall:
      1.   Forward the complaint to either the Washington County ethics
commission, or to the Utah political subdivisions ethics review commission; and
      2.   Forward the complaint to the employee who is the subject of the
ethics complaint.
   E.   If the reviewer(s) opt to forward the complaint to the Utah political
subdivisions ethics review commission, then any further action regarding the
issue shall be governed by the law, policies, and procedures that govern that
commission. (Ord. 2012-1022-O, 9-18-2012)
2-4-7: SCHEDULING AND NOTICE:
   A.   Once it has received the complaint, the Washington County ethics
commission shall:
      1.   Schedule a commission meeting to consider the complaint on a date no
later than sixty (60) calendar days after the date the complaint was accepted;
and
      2.   Provide notice of the date, time, and location of the meeting:
         a.   To the respondent; and
         b.   The first three (3) named complainants on the complaint. (Ord.
2012-1022-O, 9-18-2012)
2-4-8: RESPONSE TO ETHICS COMPLAINT:
   A.   The employee who is the subject of the complaint may file a written
response to the complaint with the office of the county clerk/auditor no later
than twenty one (21) calendar days after the date on which the employee
receives delivery of the complaint issued under subsection 2-4-6D2 of this
chapter.
   B.   Within five (5) days, the county clerk/auditor shall forward the
response to:
      1.   The county commission chair;
      2.   The county attorney;
      3.   The Washington County ethics commission; and
      4.   The first three (3) named complainants on the complaint.
   C.   The response shall be in writing and contain the following:
      1.   The name of the respondent;
      2.   Any defenses and affirmative defenses for each alleged ethics
violation in the complaint;
      3.   A list of the witnesses that the respondent wishes to have called,
including for each witness:
         a.   The name, address, and, if available, telephone number of the
witness; and
         b.   A brief summary of the testimony to be provided by the witness;
      4.   A statement that the respondent:
         a.   Has reviewed the allegations contained in the complaint and the
sworn statements and documents attached to the response; and
         b.   Believes the contents of the response to be true and accurate;
and
      5.   The signature of the respondent. (Ord. 2012-1022-O, 9-18-2012)
2-4-9: HEARINGS:
   A.   The scope of a review by the Washington County ethics commission is
limited to an alleged ethics violation, unless the Washington County ethics
commission elects, with permission of both parties, to consolidate the alleged
ethics violation with another claim regarding the same parties, events, and
circumstances being appealed to the commission.
   B.   The Washington County ethics commission shall either follow the
procedures outlined in the "Washington County Employee Policies And Procedures
Manual", section X(B)(3)(d) and (e), or adopt, in writing, its own rules of
procedure.
   C.   The standard of proof for all decisions of the Washington County ethics
commission shall be clear and convincing evidence. (Ord. 2012-1022-O, 9-18-
2012)
2-4-10: DECISION:
   A.   For each complaint brought before the Washington County ethics
commission, the commission shall issue a final decision in writing. A copy of
the decision shall be forwarded to the first three (3) listed complainants, the
employee that is the subject of the complaint, and the Washington County
commission.
   B.   Each allegation that is not found to be proved by clear and convincing
evidence shall be dismissed.
   C.   For each allegation that is found to be proved by clear and convincing
evidence, the Washington County ethics commission shall order one of the
following actions:
      1.   Private censure; or
      2.   Public censure.
The Washington County ethics commission shall have discretion in determining
the form of any censure it orders. (Ord. 2012-1022-O, 9-18-2012)
2-4-11: SPECIAL SERVICE DISTRICT AND LOCAL DISTRICT OPTION:
   A.   Special service districts and local districts that operate in
Washington County may, upon interlocal agreement with Washington County,
designate the Washington County ethics commission as their body to hear ethics
complaints.
   B.   Under this section, this chapter shall apply to the political
subdivision officers and political subdivision employees under Utah Code
Annotated title 67, chapter 16, Utah public officers' and employees' ethics
act. (Ord. 2012-1022-O, 9-18-2012)
CHAPTER 5
INDIGENT DEFENSE COMMITTEE
SECTION:
2-5-1: Statutory Authority
2-5-2: Established
2-5-3: Duties
2-5-4: Membership
2-5-5: Bylaws And Officers
2-5-6: Meetings
2-5-7: Compensation
2-5-1: STATUTORY AUTHORITY:
The statutory authority for enacting this chapter is Utah Code Annotated
sections 17-53-223 and 77-32-306, as amended. (Ord. 2018-1125-O, 11-20-2018)
2-5-2: ESTABLISHED:
The Washington County Indigent Defense Committee is established to assist and
advise the County Commission regarding the operation of a constitutionally
adequate legal defense system for indigents. (Ord. 2018-1125-O, 11-20-2018)
2-5-3: DUTIES:
The duties of the Washington County Indigent Defense Committee are to:
   A.   Review applications, conduct interviews, and make recommendations
regarding the awarding of public defender agreements;
   B.   Receive concerns regarding the provision of indigent defense services
by a specific public defender, conduct any appropriate investigation, and make
any appropriate recommendation to the County Commission;
   C.   Evaluate and make recommendations regarding the termination or renewal
of a public defender agreement; and
   D.   Unless otherwise required by law, keep confidential all information
received in connection with other duties except that information may be shared
with the County Commission and the County's lead public defender. (Ord. 2018-
1125-O, 11-20-2018)
2-5-4: MEMBERSHIP:
   A.   Number Of Members: The Indigent Defense Committee shall consist of
three (3) members and as many alternate members as the County Commission deems
appropriate.
   B.   Appointment: All members shall be appointed by the County Commission.
   C.   Attorney Members: At least two (2) members shall be licensed or retired
attorneys.
   D.   Conflicts Of Interest: No member may be an employee of the County or
currently under contract as a public defender. Members must be free from
conflicts of interest and be able to provide independent recommendations.
   E.   Terms: Committee members shall be appointed to serve four-year terms
and shall remain on the committee until a successor is appointed. Initially,
terms may be for a shorter duration to ensure staggered terms.
   F.   Removal: The County Commission may remove any committee member for
misconduct or neglect of duty.
   G.   Vacancies: Vacancies created by resignation, death, removal, or
otherwise shall be filled for the duration of the unexpired term. (Ord. 2018-
1125-O, 11-20-2018)
2-5-5: BYLAWS AND OFFICERS:
   A.   Bylaws: The Indigent Defense Committee may adopt bylaws and any other
rules it deems appropriate for managing the business and affairs of the
committee.
   B.   Officers: The committee shall elect a Chair. The Chair shall arrange
for County staff to take minutes, maintain records, and provide all necessary
support to the committee. (Ord. 2018-1125-O, 11-20-2018)
2-5-6: MEETINGS:
Meetings may be called by the Indigent Defense Committee Chair or a Washington
County Commissioner. (Ord. 2018-1125-O, 11-20-2018)
2-5-7: COMPENSATION:
Committee members shall serve as volunteers and be paid a rate established by
the County Commission. (Ord. 2018-1125-O, 11-20-2018)
CHAPTER 6
TOURISM TAX ADVISORY BOARD
SECTION:
2-6-1: Statutory Authority
2-6-2: Purpose Of Provisions
2-6-3: Established
2-6-4: Membership
2-6-5: Duties
2-6-6: Bylaws And Officers
2-6-7: Meetings
2-6-8: Compensation
2-6-9: Employees
2-6-1: STATUTORY AUTHORITY:
The statutory authority for enacting this chapter is Utah Code Annotated
sections 17-31-8 and 17-53-223. (Ord. 2017-1103-O, 11-21-2017)
2-6-2: PURPOSE OF PROVISIONS:
The purpose of this chapter is to codify the makeup and duties of the
Washington County Tourism Tax Advisory Board. (Ord. 2017-1103-O, 11-21-2017)
2-6-3: ESTABLISHED:
The Washington County Tourism Tax Advisory Board is hereby established to
assist and advise the County Commission. (Ord. 2017-1103-O, 11-21-2017)
2-6-4: MEMBERSHIP:
   A.   Number Of Members: The Tourism Tax Advisory Board shall consist of at
least seven (7) members.
   B.   Appointment: All board members shall be appointed by the County
Commission.
   C.   County Residents: All board members shall be residents of Washington
County.
   D.   Taxed Entity Members: A majority of the board members shall be current
employees of entities in the County that are subject to either the Transient
Room Tax 1  or the Tourism, Recreation, Cultural, Convention, and Airport
Facilities Tax 2 .
   E.   Industry Members: All other board members shall be employees of
recreational facilities, convention facilities, museums, cultural attractions,
or other tourism related industries located within the County.
   F.   Terms: Board members shall be appointed to serve four (4) year terms,
or until their successors are appointed. Initially, terms may be for a shorter
duration to ensure staggered terms.
   G.   Removal: The County Commission may remove any board member for
misconduct or neglect of duty.
   H.   Attendance: If a board member fails to attend at least seventy five
percent (75%) of the board meetings in a calendar year, they shall be
considered as if they have resigned from the board. The County Commission shall
appoint a new member.
   I.   Vacancies: Vacancies created by resignation, death, removal, or
otherwise shall be filled for the duration of the unexpired term. (Ord. 2017-
1103-O, 11-21-2017)
 
Notes
1 1. As described in UCA § 59-12-301.
2 1. As described in UCA § 59-12-603.
2-6-5: DUTIES:
The Tourism Tax Board shall:
   A.   Transient Room Tax: Recommend to the County Commission, on an annual
basis, a priority listing for proposed expenditures of Transient Room Tax funds
based on projected available revenues;
   B.   Tourism, Recreation, Cultural, Convention, And Airport Facilities Tax:
Recommend to the County Commission, on an annual basis, a priority listing for
proposed expenditures of Tourism, Recreation, Cultural, Convention, and Airport
Facilities Tax funds based on projected available revenues; and
   C.   Each Recommendation:
      1.   Of an appropriation of funds for capital projects, the Tourism Tax
Advisory Board shall make a recommendation to the County Commission for the
amount of funds to be appropriated for use on capital projects at the
discretion of the County Commission. The County Commission must find that the
appropriation contributes to the safety, health, prosperity, moral well-being,
peace, order, comfort, or convenience of County residents.
         a.   The County Commission shall appropriate monies to municipalities
or other governmental agencies for capital projects through an interlocal
agreement. The municipality or other governmental agency shall agree to use the
money for the reasons outlined in the interlocal agreement and in compliance
with the requirements of Utah Code sections 59-12-301, 59-12-603, et seq., and
17-50-303.
      2.   Of an appropriation of funds to nonprofit entities, the Tourism Tax
Advisory Board shall make a recommendation to the County Commission for the
amount of funds to be appropriated for use by nonprofit entities. The County
Commission must find that the appropriation contributes to the safety, health,
prosperity, moral well-being, peace, order, comfort, or convenience of County
residents.
      3.   Of an appropriation of funds to events or activities for profit or
to for-profit entities, the Tourism Tax Advisory Board shall make a
recommendation to the County Commission for the amount of funds to be
appropriated for use by for-profit entities or for events or activities for
profit. The County Commission must find that the appropriation contributes to
the safety, health, prosperity, moral well-being, peace, order, comfort, or
convenience of County residents. County staff shall conduct a study and follow
the requirements in Utah Code section 17-50-303. The following criteria will be
used to determine whether funds should be appropriated to a for-profit entity,
event, or activity:
         a.   If the appropriation is likely to result in an event or activity
attended by non-residents of Washington County;
         b.   If the appropriation is likely to:
            (1)   Increase patronage to local hotels, and if so, by how many
nights; and
            (2)   Impact the amount of money being spent in the community
through restaurants, shopping, or otherwise;
         c.   If the appropriation will be used to promote the brand
development of Washington County;
         d.   If the for-profit entity has a plan:
            (1)   To develop finances sufficient to move away from government
assistance in the future; or
            (2)   To develop sufficient economic impact or brand development
for Washington County to merit ongoing funding;
         e.   If the for-profit entity is receiving support (financial or
otherwise) by the municipality where the event or attraction is located;
         f.   Other sources from which the for-profit entity is receiving
money;
         g.   If there are other events occurring within the County in the same
time-frame;
         h.   Other factors the Tourism Tax Board deems necessary or important.
   D.   Advise: Otherwise advise the County Commission on matters for which the
County seeks out the advice of the board. (Ord. 2017-1103-O, 11-21-2017)
2-6-6: BYLAWS AND OFFICERS:
   A.   Bylaws: The board shall adopt bylaws for managing its business and
affairs.
   B.   Officers: The Chairperson of the board shall be a County Commissioner.
Other officer positions shall exist as outlined in the board's bylaws. County
Commission staff shall fulfill secretarial duties of the board including
keeping minutes and official records of board actions. (Ord. 2017-1103-O, 11-
21-2017)
2-6-7: MEETINGS:
The board shall meet at least annually and may have other meetings as needed.
Meetings may be called by the board Chair. (Ord. 2017-1103-O, 11-21-2017)
2-6-8: COMPENSATION:
Board members shall serve as volunteers without compensation; however, members
may be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred in the performance of the
member's official duties. (Ord. 2017-1103-O, 11-21-2017)
2-6-9: EMPLOYEES:
Personnel and employment decisions regarding County employees are under the
sole discretion and control of the County Commission and its designated
Personnel Director. (Ord. 2017-1103-O, 11-21-2017)
CHAPTER 7
HABITAT CONSERVATION ADVISORY COMMITTEE (HCAC)
SECTION:
2-7-1: Title
2-7-2: HCAC Established
2-7-3: Purpose Of The HCAC
2-7-4: HCAC Meetings
2-7-5: Duties Of The HCAC
2-7-6: Membership
2-7-7: Length Of Terms
2-7-1: TITLE:
This chapter shall be known as the WASHINGTON COUNTY HABITAT CONSERVATION
ADVISORY COMMITTEE ORDINANCE. (Ord. 2017-1093-O, 6-20-2017)
2-7-2: HCAC ESTABLISHED:
The HCAC was established in 1996 by the adoption of the Desert Tortoise Habitat
Conservation Plan (HCP). This chapter is drafted in accordance with the HCP
document at 6.2.3. (Ord. 2017-1093-O, 6-20-2017)
2-7-3: PURPOSE OF THE HCAC:
The HCAC's purpose is to:
   A.   Oversee the administration of the HCP, and
   B.   Serve in an advisory capacity to the County Commission to oversee
threatened, endangered, and candidate species matters in the County. (Ord.
2017-1093-O, 6-20-2017)
2-7-4: HCAC MEETINGS:
The HCAC will meet regularly and operate by consensus. (Ord. 2017-1093-O, 6-20-
2017)
2-7-5: DUTIES OF THE HCAC:
As an advisory body to the County Commission, the HCAC will:
   A.   Interpret the HCP document when necessary for the direction of the HCP
Administrator (subject to the final review of the County Commission),
   B.   Direct the activities of the HCP Administrator,
   C.   Review and approve quarterly and annual reports on take and mitigation,
and identify deficiencies in the reports that require correction prior to
submission of those reports to the County Commission,
   D.   Oversee the expenditure of mitigation monies,
   E.   Review proposed amendments to the HCP and make recommendations to the
County Commission, and
   F.   Provide problem-solving advice to the HCP Administrator. (Ord. 2017-
1093-O, 6-20-2017)
2-7-6: MEMBERSHIP:
The Chairperson of the HCAC will be determined by the committee members on an
annual basis.
The HCAC will include:
   A.   A representative from the Utah Division of Wildlife Resources (UDWR),
nominated to the County Commission by the UDWR,
   B.   A representative from the U.S. Bureau of Land Management (BLM),
nominated to the County Commission by the BLM,
   C.   A representative from the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS),
nominated to the County Commission by the USFWS,
   D.   A representative from an environmental organization, appointed by the
County Commission,
   E.   A representative of local governments, designated by the Washington
County Mayors' Association,
   F.   A representative of local development interests, designated by the
County Commission, and
   G.   A citizen at large, nominated to the County Commission by the
municipality with the largest population that is participating in the HCP.
(Ord. 2017-1093-O, 6-20-2017)
2-7-7: LENGTH OF TERMS:
The three (3) agency representatives will serve at the will of their respective
agencies.
Of the four (4) non-agency representatives, terms will comply with the
requirements of the HCP. (Ord. 2017-1093-O, 6-20-2017)
CHAPTER 8
SOUTHERN UTAH SHOOTING SPORTS PARK ADVISORY BOARD
SECTION:
2-8-1: Statutory Authority
2-8-2: Purpose Of Provisions
2-8-3: Established
2-8-4: Membership
2-8-5: Duties
2-8-6: Bylaws And Officers
2-8-7: Meetings
2-8-8: Compensation
2-8-9: Employees
2-8-1: STATUTORY AUTHORITY:
The statutory authority for enacting this chapter is Utah Code Annotated
section 17-53-223. (Ord. 2017-1098-O, 8-15-2017)
2-8-2: PURPOSE OF PROVISIONS:
The purpose of this chapter is to codify the makeup and duties of the Southern
Utah Shooting Sports Park Advisory Board. (Ord. 2017-1098-O, 8-15-2017)
2-8-3: ESTABLISHED:
The Southern Utah Shooting Sports Park Advisory Board is hereby established to
assist and advise the Southern Utah Shooting Sports Park Manager and the
Washington County Commission on all things relating to the park. (Ord. 2017-
1098-O, 8-15-2017)
2-8-4: MEMBERSHIP:
   A.   Number Of Members: The Southern Utah Shooting Sports Park Advisory
Board shall consist of nine (9) members as follows:
      1.   The majority of the Advisory Board shall be affiliated with at least
one venue operating within the park.
      2.   All board positions shall be appointed by the County Commission.
      3.   The Southern Utah Shooting Sports Park Manager shall not be a member
of the board.
   B.   County Residents: All board members shall be residents of Washington
County.
   C.   Terms: Board members shall be appointed to serve four-year terms, or
until their successors are appointed. Initially, terms may be for a shorter
duration to ensure staggered terms.
   D.   Removal: The County Commission may remove any board member for
misconduct or neglect of duty.
   E.   Vacancies: Vacancies created by resignation, death, removal, or
otherwise shall be filled for the duration of the unexpired term. (Ord. 2017-
1098-O, 8-15-2017)
2-8-5: DUTIES:
   A.   Advise the Park Manager on policy issues.
   B.   Recommend park policies and procedures relating to safety, hours of
operation, fee schedule, and public access to the Park Manager.
   C.   Work closely with the Manager to ensure efficient operation of the
park. (Ord. 2017-1098-O, 8-15-2017)
2-8-6: BYLAWS AND OFFICERS:
   A.   Bylaws: The board shall adopt bylaws for managing its business and
affairs.
   B.   Officers: Officer positions shall exist as outlined in the board's
bylaws. The County Commission shall appoint a board member to take minutes and
maintain official records of board actions. (Ord. 2017-1098-O, 8-15-2017)
2-8-7: MEETINGS:
   A.   The board shall meet at least quarterly and may have other meetings as
needed. Meetings may be called by the board Chair, Park Manager, or the County.
(Ord. 2017-1098-O, 8-15-2017)
2-8-8: COMPENSATION:
   A.   Board members shall serve as volunteers without compensation; however,
members may be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred in the performance of
the member's official duties. (Ord. 2017-1098-O, 8-15-2017)
2-8-9: EMPLOYEES:
Personnel and employment decisions regarding the County's Convention and
Tourism Department are under the sole discretion and control of the County
Commission and its designated Personnel Director. (Ord. 2017-1098-O, 8-15-2017)
CHAPTER 9
COUNCIL OF GOVERNMENTS
SECTION:
2-9-1: Statutory Authority
2-9-2: Purpose Of Provisions
2-9-3: Established
2-9-4: Membership
2-9-5: Duties
2-9-6: Bylaws And Officers
2-9-7: Meetings
2-9-8: Compensation
2-9-9: Support Staff
2-9-1: STATUTORY AUTHORITY:
The statutory authority for enacting this chapter is Utah Code sections 17-53-
223 and 72-2-117.5. (Ord. 2019-1142-O, 7-2-2019)
2-9-2: PURPOSE OF PROVISIONS:
The purpose of these provisions is to codify the Washington County Council of
Governments, set forth the Council's purpose, and provide for the Council's
membership and governance. (Ord. 2019-1142-O, 7-2-2019)
2-9-3: ESTABLISHED:
The Washington County Council of Governments is established to carry out the
purposes described in this chapter. (Ord. 2019-1142-O, 7-2-2019)
2-9-4: MEMBERSHIP:
   A.   The Washington County Council of Governments is composed of the County
Legislative Body and the Mayors of each municipality in the County.
   B.   Each member has one vote on items brought before the body. With consent
of the voting members, the Chair may invite other cooperating agencies,
governmental entities, non-governmental organizations, or other interested
parties to participate as non-voting, ex officio members.
   C.   One representative of the Utah Department of Transportation at any
given meeting of the Washington County Council of Governments may act as an ex-
officio member of the Council and may cast a single vote on any agenda item
that involves public transportation. If there is a question as to whether an
item involves public transportation, the Council’s Chair shall make the final
decision.
(Ord. 2019-1142-O, 7-2-2019; Ord. 2019-1145-O, 8-20-2019)
2-9-5: DUTIES:
The Washington County Council of Governments shall:
   A.   Engage in a cooperative and comprehensive process of transportation
planning, corridor preservation, right-of-way acquisition, project programming,
and providing public transit throughout Washington County by County and
municipal governments;
   B.   Oversee expenditure of Local Transportation Corridor Preservation Funds
based on appropriate considerations including:
      1.   Areas with rapidly expanding population,
      2.   Local governments' completion of proper studies and impact
statements,
      3.   Preservation of corridors by the use of local planning and zoning
processes,
      4.   Availability of matching funds for a project,
      5.   Cost-effectiveness,
      6.   Ongoing maintenance costs of property acquired,
      7.   The inclusion of the corridor or project on applicable master and
long range plans;
   C.   Annually submit to the County Legislative Body a priority list of
highway projects that may qualify for Local Transportation Corridor
Preservation Funds; and
   D.   Oversee the implementation, expansion, and ongoing operation of public
transit as funded by the County Option Sales and Use Tax for Roads and Public
Transit, by grants, or other funding mechanisms including interlocal
agreements. (Ord. 2019-1142-O, 7-2-2019)
2-9-6: BYLAWS AND OFFICERS:
   A.   The Washington County Council of Governments may create bylaws,
procedures, and rules to ensure it efficiently carries out its duties.
   B.   The Chair of the Washington County Legislative Body shall be the Chair
of the Washington County Council of Governments. The Washington County Council
of Governments may appoint other officers as it deems necessary. (Ord. 2019-
1142-O, 7-2-2019)
2-9-7: MEETINGS:
The Washington County Council of Governments shall meet at least annually and
as often as deemed necessary by its Chair, who calls the meetings. (Ord. 2019-
1142-O, 7-2-2019)
2-9-8: COMPENSATION:
No member shall be compensated for time spent serving on the Washington County
Council of Governments. (Ord. 2019-1142-O, 7-2-2019)
2-9-9: SUPPORT STAFF:
Administrative support to the Council of Governments shall be provided by
Washington County as directed by the Chair. (Ord. 2019-1142-O, 7-2-2019)

CRIMINAL JUSTICE COORDINATING COUNCIL

2-10-2: Purpose Of Provisions

carry out the purposes described in this chapter.
(2022-1213-O, 7-19-2022)

   B.   Each member shall have one vote on all matters Council takes action on.

(2022-1213-O, 7-19-2022)
2-10-5: DUTIES:
The Washington County Criminal Justice Coordinating Council shall:

(as amended);

(2022-1213-O, 7-19-2022)
