   Washington County2-11-1   2-11-4
CHAPTER 11
WASHINGTON COUNTY FAIR ADVISORY BOARD
SECTION:
2-11-1: Statutory Authority
2-11-2: Purpose Of Provisions
2-11-3: Established
2-11-4: Membership
2-11-5: Duties
2-11-6: Bylaws And Officers
2-11-7: Meetings
2-11-8: Compensation
2-11-9: Employees
2-11-1: STATUTORY AUTHORITY:
The statutory authority for enacting this chapter is Utah Code Annotated
section 17-53-223. (Ord. 2024-1268-O, 8-6-2024)
2-11-2: PURPOSE OF PROVISIONS:
The purpose of this chapter is to create and codify the makeup and duties of
the Washington County Fair Advisory Board. (Ord. 2024-1268-O, 8-6-2024)
2-11-3: ESTABLISHED:
The Washington County Fair Advisory Board is hereby established to assist and
advise the Washington County Fair Director, Washington County Staff, and the
Washington County Fair Committee regarding the annual Washington County Fair.
(Ord. 2024-1268-O, 8-6-2024)
   A.   Number Of Members: The Washington County Fair Advisory Board shall
consist of seven (7) members as follows:
      1.   The Washington County Fair Director, who is a voting member of the
board; and
      2.   Any other person appointed by the County Commission who has
interest, expertise, passion, or experience in matters related to the
Washington County Fair.
   B.   County Residents: All board members shall be residents of Washington
County.
   C.   Terms: Board members shall be appointed to serve two-year terms,
initial terms for some members will be for three-years.
   D.   Removal: The Washington County Fair Director may unilaterally recommend
to the County Commission the removal of any member for misconduct or neglect of
duty and the County Commission may remove any board member for the same.
   E.   Board Openings and Vacancies: The County Commission will fill a
position on the board after publicly announcing the open position or vacancy.
Vacancies created by resignation, death, removal, or otherwise shall be filled
for the duration of the unexpired term. (Ord. 2024-1268-O, 8-6-2024)
2-11-4: MEMBERSHIP:
   A.   Number Of Members: The Washington County Fair Advisory Board shall
consist of seven (7) members as follows:
      1.   The Washington County Fair Director, who is a voting member of the
board; and
      2.   Any other person appointed by the County Commission who has
interest, expertise, passion, or experience in matters related to the
Washington County Fair.
   B.   County Residents: All board members shall be residents of Washington
County.
   C.   Terms: Board members shall be appointed to serve two-year terms,
initial terms for some members will be for three-years.
   D.   Removal: The Washington County Fair Director may unilaterally recommend
to the County Commission the removal of any member for misconduct or neglect of
duty and the County Commission may remove any board member for the same.
   E.   Board Openings and Vacancies: The County Commission will fill a
position on the board after publicly announcing the open position or vacancy.
Vacancies created by resignation, death, removal, or otherwise shall be filled
for the duration of the unexpired term. (Ord. 2024-1268-O, 8-6-2024)
2-11-5: MEMBER DUTIES:
   A.   Attend Washington County Fair Advisory Board meetings to report on
assignments or other business.
   B.   Vote on recommendations regarding the operations, schedule, events, or
other offerings at the Washington County Fair.
   C.   Work closely with the Washington County Fair Director and Washington
County Fair Volunteer Committee.
   D.   Volunteer time throughout the year to complete assignments and other
business related to the Washington County Fair.
   E.   Complete an annual anonymous review and evaluation of the most recent
Washington County Fair to provide recommendations to enhance and improve the
visitor experience. (Ord. 2024-1268-O, 8-6-2024)
2-11-6: BYLAWS, OFFICERS, AND QUORUM:
   A.   Bylaws: The board shall adopt bylaws for managing its business and
affairs. The bylaws shall expound upon the member duties as outlined in
2-11-5.
   B.   Officers: The Washington County Fair Director shall be one (1) member
of the board and serve indefinitely as the Chair of the board and is not
subject to the board member terms of service as outlined in 2-11-4(C). No other
members shall act as officers of the board.
   C.   Quorum: A quorum of the board shall be four (4) or more members and
must include the Washington County Fair Director. The board may not establish a
quorum without the Washington County Fair Director. (Ord. 2024-1268-O, 8-6-
2024)
2-11-7: MEETINGS:
The board shall meet at least quarterly and may have other meetings as needed.
Meetings may only be called by the Fair Director or the County Commission.
(Ord. 2024-1268-O, 8-6-2024)
2-11-8: COMPENSATION:
Board members shall serve as volunteers without compensation; however, members
may be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred in the performance of the
member’s official duties. All reimbursements under this section shall be made
in accordance with Washington County Policy. (Ord. 2024-1268-O, 8-6-2024)
2-11-9: EMPLOYEES:
Personnel, employment, and operational decisions regarding the Washington
County Fair and the Washington County Legacy Park are under the sole discretion
and control of the County Commission and the Washington County Fair Director.
Nevertheless, the Washington County Fair Advisory Board may consider
recommendations regarding the operations, schedule, events, or other offerings
at the Washington County Fair. (Ord. 2024-1268-O, 8-6-2024)
TITLE 3
BUSINESS AND LICENSE REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
GENERAL LICENSE PROVISIONS
SECTION:
3-1-1: Definitions
3-1-2: Business License Required
3-1-3: Unlawful To Operate Without A License
3-1-4: Fees
3-1-5: Waiver Of Fees
3-1-6: Payment Date
3-1-7: Application For Licenses And Renewals
3-1-8: County Community Development Department Designated As Collector
3-1-9: Referral Of Application
3-1-10: Refunds Prohibited
3-1-11: Contents Of License
3-1-12: Display Of Certificate
3-1-13: Transfer Of License Prohibited
3-1-14: Revocation Or Denial Of Business License; Conditions
3-1-15: Hearing, Appeal On Denial Or Revocation
3-1-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this title, the following words and phrases shall have the following
meanings unless a different meaning clearly appears from the context:
BUSINESS: All activities engaged within the County carried on for the purpose
of gain or economic profit, directly or indirectly, except the acts of
employees rendering service to employers.
EMPLOYEE: The operator, owner or manager of a place of business, and any
persons employed by such person in the operation of said place of business in
any capacity, and also any salesperson, agent or independent contractor engaged
in the operation of the place of business in any capacity, regardless of the
method of compensation. As used herein, the term "employee" is intended to
include everyone engaged in the operation of the business,
ENGAGING IN BUSINESS: Means and includes, but is not limited to, the direct or
indirect engaging in, transacting or operating of any business, such as, but
not limited to, the sale of goods or materials on a retail or wholesale basis,
the manufacturing of products, the rendering of personal services for others
for consideration, or by engaging in any profession, trade, craft, occupation
or other calling, except the rendering of personal services by an employee to
his or her employer under any contract of personal employment.
PERSON: Any individual, person, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity.
PLACE OF BUSINESS: Each separate location maintained or operated by the
licensee within the unincorporated areas of the County, from which business
activity is conducted or transacted, whether or not each location is operating
under the same name. (Ord. 2017-1099-O, 9-19-2017; amd. Ord. 2025-1291-O, 5-6-
2025)
3-1-2: BUSINESS LICENSE REQUIRED:
   A.   Every person who, whether directly or indirectly, transacts, engages
in, or operates a business within the unincorporated area of the County, shall
obtain, maintain and renew a County business license for that business for each
and every calendar year in which said business is in operation unless
specifically exempted in subsection B of this section.
   B.   A business license is not required for a business that is operated:
      1.   Only occasionally; and by an individual who is under eighteen (18)
years of age or who is operating a youth enterprise; or
      2.   As a minor home occupation as defined in sections
10-4-1  and
10-26-1 , et seq. of this Code. (Ord. 2017-1099-O, 9-19-2017; amd. Ord. 2025-
1291-O, 5-6-2025)
3-1-3: UNLAWFUL TO OPERATE WITHOUT A LICENSE:
   A.   License Required: It is unlawful for any person, directly or
indirectly, to transact, engage in or operate any business within the
unincorporated area of the County without a current valid County business
license unless specifically exempted under subsection
3-1-2  B. of this chapter.
   B.   Misdemeanor: Any person violating any provision of this section shall
be deemed guilty of a Class B misdemeanor and subject to penalty as provided in
section
1-4-1  of this Code. (Ord. 2017-1099-O, 9-19-2017; amd. Ord. 2025-1291-O, 5-6-
2025)
3-1-4: FEES:
Fees shall be assessed for the issuance or renewal of any business license,
including late fees, according to a fee schedule adopted by the County
Commission. One-half (1/2) of the annual fee shall be payable for all licenses
issued by the County pursuant to applications made after July 1 of each year.
Licenses issued after July 1 shall expire on January 31 the year after the
license was issued. The application provided for in this section shall be
accompanied by the fees herein provided, which shall be deposited in the County
Treasury if the license is granted, and returned to the applicant if denied.
(2004 Code; amd. Ord. 2025-1291-O, 5-6-2025)
3-1-5: WAIVER OF FEES:
   A.   Conditions: The County Commission, upon written application, may waive
or reduce any license fee for the current year required by the provisions of
this chapter if:
      1.   The application, by reason of any special circumstances, merits such
waiver or reduction; or
      2.   The applicant is engaged in business for solely religious,
charitable, educational or other types of strictly nonprofit purposes, which is
tax exempt in such activities under the laws of the United States and the
State; or
      3.   The applicant is engaged in a business specifically exempted from
taxation and fees by the laws of the United States or the State.
   B.   In Writing And Reasons Specified: Such waiver shall be in writing and
specify the reasons for the waiver or reduction and any limitations or
restrictions on the business for which said fee has been either waived or
reduced.
   C.   Submission To Community Development Department: A copy of the written
waiver shall be submitted to the county community development director or
designee. (2004 Code; amd. Ord. 2025-1291-O, 5-6-2025)
3-1-6: PAYMENT DATE:
   A.   Specified: All license fees shall be due and payable on or before
February 1 of each and every year for which the license is issued or renewed
and shall become delinquent if not paid by March 1 of each year. The annual
license shall date from February 1 each year and shall expire on January 31 of
each year. For 2025 business licenses, all are extended until January 31, 2026.
   B.   Delinquent: If any license fee is not paid by January 31 of the year in
which it is due, a late fee penalty of ten percent (10%) of the fees due or
twenty five dollars ($25.00), whichever is greater, may be added to the
original fee, in accordance with the fee schedule adopted by the County
Commission. No license shall be issued until all fees and penalties have been
paid in full. (2004 Code; amd. Ord. 2014-1034-O, 1-7-2014; Ord. 2025-1291-O, 5-
6-2025)
3-1-7: APPLICATION FOR LICENSES AND RENEWALS:
   A.   Application Required: All applicants must submit an application for the
issuance or renewal of licenses.
   B.   Information Required: All applications for licenses shall include the
following information:
      1.   The name of the person applying for the license and the name of the
business.
      2.   The type and nature of the business, calling, trade or profession to
be performed, practiced or carried on pursuant to said license.
      3.   The place where such business is to be carried on, giving the street
address of the business to be carried on in any building.
      4.   Any other information required by the County.
   C.   State License: If the business for which a license is applied is
regulated by the State and requires a State license, the applicant must produce
that State license, or evidence thereof, and must keep it current.
   D.   Coin Operated Machines Or Devices: In the event that the license
application relates to a business which uses coin operated machines or devices,
the application shall identify the type of machine or device to which it
applies and the location thereof. (2004 Code; amd. Ord. 2025-1291-O, 5-6-2025)
3-1-8: COUNTY COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT DEPARTMENT DESIGNATED AS COLLECTOR:
   A.   Collector: The county community development director or designee is
appointed as the collector of business license fees for the county.
   B.   Assessment Of License Fees: Upon the receipt of an application for a
business license or a renewal thereof, the county shall assess the amount due
thereon and collect all license fees before a business license may issue or
renew.
   C.   Reporting Of Violations: The county community development department or
its designee shall investigate and take action for any license violations
reported to it under.
   D.   Communications from the county to the applicant or licensee may be made
inside the software program utilized for business licensing, by email, or by
mail. (2004 Code; amd. Ord. 2025-1291-O, 5-6-2025)
3-1-9: REFERRAL OF APPLICATION:
Before issuing a business license, the county community development department
or designee shall assure that the applicant and application are in compliance
with appropriate county ordinances and, if necessary, will refer the applicant
to the appropriate office or agency for compliance with the rules and
regulations of that agency and investigation by that agency. (2004 Code; amd.
Ord. 2025-1291-O, 5-6-2025)
3-1-10: REFUNDS PROHIBITED:
No license fee or penalty shall be refunded for any reason after a license has
been issued. (2004 Code)
3-1-11: CONTENTS OF LICENSE:
Every certificate of license shall bear upon its face the following:
   A.   The name of the person to whom such certificate has been issued.
   B.   The name of the business licensed; the name of the principals or
managing members; and the name of the registered agent.
   C.   The type and nature of the business.
   D.   The term of the license with the date of commencement.
   E.   The address of the principal place of the business; the address of the
registered agent; the email address of the applicant and the licensee. The
license is specific to the business location address. No changes can be made
without approval of the county.
   F.   The signature of the county community development director or designee.
   G.   Such other information that may be required by the county, such as
special conditions imposed upon the application. (2004 Code; amd. Ord. 2025-
1291-O, 5-6-2025)
3-1-12: DISPLAY OF CERTIFICATE:
   A.   Required: Every certificate of license issued under the provisions of
this chapter must be posted by the licensee in a conspicuous part of the
premises where business activities are conducted.
   B.   Expired Certificates: No certificate of license, which is not in force
and effect, shall be permitted to be posted at the place of business after the
license has expired.
   C.   Coin Operated Machines Or Devices: In the event the license is for a
business which uses coin operated machines or devices, the certificate shall be
attached or displayed in the immediate vicinity of the machines or devices for
which it has been issued. (2004 Code; amd. Ord. 2025-1291-O, 5-6-2025)
3-1-13: TRANSFER OF LICENSE PROHIBITED:
No license issued under any ordinance of the county shall be assigned or
transferred to any other person or business, except as provided by operation of
law. (2004 Code; amd. Ord. 2025-1291-O, 5-6-2025)
3-1-14: REVOCATION OR DENIAL OF BUSINESS LICENSE; CONDITIONS:
Any license issued pursuant to the provisions of this code or any ordinance of
the county may be revoked and any application denied by the county because of:
   A.   The failure of the licensee or applicant to comply with conditions and
requirements of this chapter or any other county ordinance;
   B.   Unlawful activities conducted or permitted upon the premises where the
business is conducted; or
   C.   The license is obtained by deception or is issued to or obtained by any
unauthorized person. (2004 Code)
3-1-15: HEARING, APPEAL ON DENIAL OR REVOCATION:
   A.   Notice; Hearing:
      1.   If the county community development director or designee determines
that facts exist for denial or revocation of a license under this chapter, the
county shall notify the applicant or licensee in writing of the denial or
revocation of the license, including the grounds therefor, the notification
shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, and directed to the
most current business address on file with the county. This is a final
administrative decision of the community development director or designee. If
the applicant or licensee disputes the decision, an appeal shall be filed
within ten (10) business days of receipt of such notice, by providing to the
county a detailed written appeal that shall include a statement of reasons why
the license or permit should not have been denied or revoked. Within ten (10)
business days of the receipt of applicant or licensee's written appeal, the
county shall notify the applicant or licensee in writing of the hearing date
before a hearing officer for the appeal of the denial or revocation.
      2.   Within twenty (20) business days of the receipt of applicant or
licensee's written appeal, or as otherwise agreed by the parties, the county
shall conduct a hearing at which the applicant or licensee shall have the
opportunity to be represented pro se or by counsel and present evidence and
witnesses on his or her behalf. A hearing officer experienced in business
licensing and related law shall be appointed by the county commission, and
shall conduct the hearing using the procedures in County Ord.
10-2-1 , et seq.
      3.   If an appeal is not received by the county in the time stated, or
if, after the hearing, the hearing officer county finds that grounds as
specified in this chapter exist for denial or revocation, then such denial or
revocation shall be affirmed and become final five (5) business days after the
county sends, by certified mail, a written Final Decision that the license has
been denied or revoked. Such Final Decision shall include a statement advising
the applicant or licensee of the right to appeal such decision to a court of
competent jurisdiction.
      4.   If the hearing officer finds that adequate grounds did not exist for
denial or revocation of a license, then within five (5) business days after the
Final Decision, the county shall withdraw the denial or revocation of the
license, and notify the applicant or licensee in writing, by certified mail, of
such action and shall contemporaneously therewith issue the license.
   B.   Appeal: Once a Final Decision is issued by a hearing officer, and it is
sent to the applicant or licensee, the applicant or licensee shall have the
right to appeal such action to the district court if timely filed, and in
accordance with the limitations and procedures in County Ord.
10-2-6 (E). Upon the filing of any court action to appeal, challenge, restrain
or otherwise enjoin the county's enforcement of the denial or revocation, the
county shall immediately issue the aggrieved party a provisional license. The
provisional license shall allow the aggrieved party to operate the business and
will expire upon the court's entry of a judgment on the aggrieved party's
action to appeal, challenge, restrain or otherwise enjoin the county's
enforcement. (2004 Code; amd. Ord. 2025-1291-O, 5-6-2025)
CHAPTER 2
ALCOHOL SALES AND LICENSES
SECTION:
3-2-1: Policy Purpose 
3-2-2: Definitions
3-2-3: County Alcohol Business License Types
3-2-4: License Requirements; Licensee Qualifications
3-2-5: Application and Approval Requirements; Fees; Training
3-2-6: License Renewal And Expiration
3-2-7:    License Denial, Non-Renewal, Revocation
3-2-8: Emergency License Suspension
3-2-9:    Violations; Civil Penalties; Criminal Citations
3-2-1: POLICY PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to regulate the sale, licensing, and consumption
of alcoholic beverages in the county by:
   A.   Simplifying alcoholic beverage control regulations.
   B.   Not duplicating state regulations and also adopting all definitions in
the Utah Alcoholic Beverage Control Act (the Act).
   C.   It is the county's intent to regulate only areas that state law leaves
to local control and areas of local concern. The county's regulatory interest
is limited to issuing county alcohol business licenses, providing local
authority consent, and requiring compliance with health and safety regulations.
The issuance of a county alcohol business license also constitutes local
authority consent for the purpose of any state license under the Act if the
local authority consent is obtained as outlined in County Ord. 
3-2-3 .
   D.   Placing primary responsibility on the owners and managers of
establishments to follow all laws, maintain order, and prevent breaches of the
peace. (Ord. 2025-1291-O, 5-6-2025)
3-2-2: DEFINITIONS:
All definitions under the Act are adopted and supplemented as follows:
ACT: The Utah Alcoholic Beverage Control Act, Utah Code Ann., Title 32B, as
amended.
ALCOHOL ESTABLISHMENT: An establishment where a county alcohol business license
entitles the licensee to sell alcoholic beverages for consumption on the
licensed premises and in connection with a license issued by the state of Utah
under the Act.
ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE: Alcoholic beverage shall have the same meaning as defined
in Utah Code Ann. § 32B-1-101(3), as amended.
LICENSED PREMISES: The property, building, room, or equipment used in
connection with the sale, storage, service, manufacture, distribution, or
consumption of alcoholic beverages or products where the licensee is licensed
to operate.
LICENSEE: Any person or entity issued a county alcohol business license to
operate under this chapter.
PERSON: Any individual, partnership, firm, corporation, association, business
trust, or other form of business entity, including a receiver or trustee, and
in the plural as well as the singular. A person successfully seeking a license
is the licensee.
UTAH DEPARTMENT OF ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE CONTROL: The DABC as defined by the Act
and under state law. (Ord. 2025-1291-O, 5-6-2025)

*   All county alcohol business licenses require local authority consent in the form of community development approval of
the license upon a showing that the applicant or licensee has the required state license and meets all county licensing
requirements. Additionally, for consideration of a county alcohol business license for a Brew Pub or Wine Bar, the County
Commission will consider each request at a public meeting, and the County Commission is the authority to determine if
local authority consent will be granted.
