(Ord. 2025-1291-O, 5-6-2025)
3-2-4:  LICENSE REQUIREMENTS; LICENSEE QUALIFICATIONS:
   A.   License Required For Each Location:
      1.   It is unlawful to engage in the business of sale or consumption of
alcoholic beverages in the county without first obtaining a county alcohol
business license under this chapter.
      2.   An alcohol license under the Act also is required by any person
seeking a county alcohol business license under this chapter.
      3.   A county alcohol business license is only issued for permitted
activities at the licensed premises.
      4.   A county alcohol business license cannot be bought, sold,
transferred, subleased, or assigned by the original licensee to any other
person or entity unless the state has transferred the license pursuant to the
Act, and the county has approved of the transfer changing the licensee of the
county alcohol business license. A county alcohol business license cannot be
ascribed any value in the sale of a business possessing a license under this
chapter.
      5.   Every licensee, and every licensed premises, shall comply with
federal law, state law, the Act, and this chapter.
   B.   Qualifications of Licensee:
      1.   Every licensee hereunder shall be of good moral character, over the
age of twenty-one (21) years, and lawfully present in the United States. If the
applicant is a corporation, partnership, limited liability company, or other
entity, it shall be qualified to do business in the state and each shareholder,
joint venturer, partner or member holding any interest greater than twenty
percent (20%) in the applicant's business, and each director, officer, manager
and trustee, shall meet the qualifications to be a licensee. Any partnership,
limited liability company, corporation, or other entity who shall hold its
license through an agent shall also meet all the qualifications of a licensee.
Such agent shall be personally responsible for assuring compliance with this
chapter and the Act and shall be subject to the penalties for any violation of
this chapter or the Act. Upon the death, resignation or discharge of its agent,
a partnership, limited liability company, corporation, or other entity, it
shall, within twenty (20) days, appoint another agent to qualify for and hold
the license. Failure to designate a substitute agent within the time required
shall be grounds for license denial, non-renewal, or revocation. Every licensee
shall meet the qualifications prescribed by the Act.
      2.   No license shall be issued to any person who has violated any
provision of this chapter or the Act. A conviction includes a plea of guilty or
no contest, a plea in abeyance, or the forfeiture of bail on a charge. The
licensee:
         a.   Shall not have been convicted of a felony under state or federal
law.
         b.   Shall not have been convicted of a crime involving moral
turpitude.
         c.   Shall not have been convicted of a felony or class A misdemeanor
concerning the sale, offer for sale, warehousing, manufacture, distribution,
transportation, or adulteration of an alcoholic beverage.
         d.   Shall not have had an alcohol license under the Act, or under the
ordinances of another Utah governmental entity, denied or revoked in the last
three (3) years.
         e.   Shall not have failed to pay federal or state taxes, or
contributions to unemployment and insurance funds.
         f.   Shall not be in default or violation of other provisions of
county ordinances.
         g.   Shall not be indebted to county for fees or taxes.
      3.   All executives, officers, directors, managers, or agents of the
licensee with discretionary or executive authority shall comply with the
requirements, and possess the qualifications, specified in this chapter and the
Act. (Ord. 2025-1291-O, 5-6-2025)
3-2-5: APPLICATION AND APPROVAL REQUIREMENTS; FEES; TRAINING:
   A.   Application Requirements:
      1.   General.
         a. The applicant and proposed licensee's full name, mailing address,
and proposed site for the licensed premises.
         b.   The applicant and proposed licensee shall sign the application
under oath verifying that all information in the application is true and
correct.
         c.   The identity and mailing address of every owner of twenty percent
(20%) or more of the proposed licensee if it is an entity (corporation,
partnership, limited liability corporation, etc.) A list of all managers,
officers, directors, and shareholders (owning twenty percent (20%) or more of
the entity). The identity and mailing address of the registered agent for any
licensee entity.
         d.   The category or categories of state licenses requested by the
applicant under the Act.
         e.   Submit one application stating all The category or categories of
county alcohol business licenses requested by the applicant under this chapter.
         f.   Any request for local consent by the applicant to the county.
         g.   Complete applications will be processed by the community
development department. Incomplete applications are deemed rejected.
      2.   Health Department Designee. Prior to issuance of a county alcohol
business license or local consent, and if required by state law, the Southwest
Utah Public Health Department ("Health Department") shall inspect the premises
to determine compliance with state sanitation standards, and rules and
regulations regarding the preparation, storage, distribution, or sale of
alcoholic beverages. Its final report shall be submitted in writing to the
community development department. No county alcohol business license shall be
issued to a proposed licensee or for the proposed licensed premises without
compliance with all health regulations. Failure to continuously comply with all
health regulations is grounds for license denial, non-renewal, or revocation.
If recommending license denial, non-renewal, or revocation, the Health
Department shall submit a written report of its findings to the community
development department.
      3.   Sheriff's Office Designee. Prior to issuance of a county alcohol
business license or local consent, the applicant, its principals, and
supervisory personnel shall submit to a Utah Bureau of Criminal Identification
(BCI) check conducted by the state of Utah. If requested by the community
development department, the Sheriff's office shall inspect, investigate, and
report its findings regarding background checks, proximity requirements, local
consent, and licensure denial, non-renewal, or revocation. If recommending
license denial, non-renewal, or revocation, the Sheriff's office shall submit a
written report of its findings within ten days of receiving a request. Its
recommendations shall be based on the following factors:
         a.   The results of the BCI check;
         b.   The results of proximity calculations;
         c.   The reputation and character of the applicant, its principals,
and supervisory personnel including past and current business practices;
         d.   Based on information, whether the business will be, is, or has
been conducted in a lawful, quiet, and orderly manner;
         e.   The reputation and character of people who frequent the business;
         f.   Whether any criminal charges or violations exist against the
applicant, its principals, or supervisory personnel supporting denial,
nonrenewal, or revocation of the license or other action;
         g.   Whether operation of the business has resulted in an increase in
criminal activity in the vicinity;
         h.   Compliance with the Act and this chapter;
         i.   Whether the business has in place policies and procedures that
restrict minors from accessing or consuming alcoholic beverages.
   B.   Approval Requirements:
      1.   State License: Obtain and maintain state licensure under the Act.
The licensee has an ongoing duty to notify the county within 5 business days if
its state license has been denied, suspended, or revoked for any reason.
      2.   Proximity Limitations: Meet state proximity limitation requirements.
      3.   Local Consent: Obtain local authority consent from the County
Commission or the community development director or designee as set forth
herein. This includes Special Use Permit Local Consent for Special Events as
required by the DABC.
      4.   Zoning Code; Building Code: Obtain verification of zoning code and
building code compliance upon verification by the community development
department, including occupancy limits and emergency exits.
      5.   Periodic Inspections: Submit to periodic inspections of the licensed
premises by the Health Department designee, the Sheriff's office designee, or
the community development department designee. Upon presentation of
credentials, and during business hours, said designees shall be immediately
admitted onto the licensed premises without hindrance or delay and permitted to
completely inspect the entire licensed premises including obtaining samples of
alcohol.
      6.   Proof Of Insurance: Applicant and licensee shall provide proof of
insurance for approval by the county attorney's office. The business shall have
insurance in an amount to protect the county from liability up to or greater
than the governmental immunity threshold under Utah state law. Coverage shall
specifically cover claims related to the sale or service of alcohol. Also, the
applicant and licensee shall indemnify and hold harmless the county or any of
its agents, officers, servants and employees from any liability or causes of
action which might arise by reason of granting the county alcohol business
license. All coverage shall be occurrence based, not claims made.
   C.   Fees. Comply with county licensing and community development department
fee schedules. Fees are non-refundable.
   D.   Training: Comply with state law regarding manager training and alcohol
server training. (Ord. 2025-1291-O, 5-6-2025)
3-2-6: LICENSE RENEWAL AND EXPIRATION:
All county alcohol business licenses are issued for the calendar year ending
and expiring on January 31st. A fifty percent (50%) penalty will be added for
failure to pay the yearly renewal fee by February 28th. A one hundred percent
(100%) penalty will be added for failure to pay the yearly renewal fee by March
31st, and the licensee must reapply for its county alcohol business license. A
county alcohol business license automatically expires unless renewed. (Ord.
2025-1291-O, 5-6-2025)
3-2-7: LICENSE DENIAL, NON-RENEWAL, REVOCATION:
   A.   The community development department may deny, not renew, or revoke a
county alcohol business license. A written determination by the community
development department is a final administrative decision. The determination
may be based on one or any of the following substantial reasons:
      1.   Failure of the applicant to submit a complete application.
      2.   Failure of the applicant to submit to an inspection of the licensed
premises by an authorized county, Sheriff's office, or Health Department
representative or designee. Failure to pass an inspection.
      3.   Failure to comply with federal, state, or local laws. Any violation
listed under County Ord.
3-2-4 (B)(2).
      4.   Failure to comply with all building codes by bringing the licensed
premises into compliance within the required time after notice by the county
building official.
      5.   Failure to comply with all health codes by bringing the licensed
premises into compliance within the required time after notice by the Health
Department.
      6.   Failure to maintain a state license under the Act, or a county
alcohol business license.
      7.   Failure to use the state or county alcohol business license, and
open and operate the licensed premises to the public within one hundred and
eighty (180) days of obtaining the license results in automatic revocation of
the license on the one hundred and eighty-first (181st) day. Failure of the
licensed premises to be open and operate for any consecutive sixty (60) day
period also results in automatic revocation of the license on the sixty-first
(61st) day. If a venue is open seasonally only, the county in its discretion
may consider automatic revocation after one hundred and fifty (150) days
instead of sixty (60) days.
      8.   Substantive complaints received by the county from customers of the
licensee, the public, the community development department, the Health
Department, the Sheriff's office, or the County Attorney's office showing an
inability to take appropriate action to prohibit disorderly conduct, illegal
conduct, or a nuisance on the licensed premises.
      9.   Failure to pay all fees and fines, or failure to collect or remit
taxes.
      10.   Any act that endangers the health, safety, or welfare of the
licensee's customers, employees, or the public.
      11.   Fraud, misrepresentation, or a false statement of material fact in
the license application as determined by the county.
   B.   Any hearing or appeal related to license denial, non-renewal, or
revocation of a county alcohol business license shall be processed as outlined
in Washington County Code title 10, chapter 2. A written notice of appeal shall
be filed by an interested party with the county community development
department within ten calendar days of the final administrative decision to
deny, not renew, or revoke a county alcohol business license. Interested
parties are defined only as the licensee, owner, manager, or agent of the
licensee, or the county. If a notice of appeal is not received timely, the
denial, non-renewal, or revocation is immediately effective and enforceable.
The hearing officer shall be appointed by the county commission, and shall be
qualified based on education, training, or experience regarding Utah and local
alcohol licensing, in addition to being selected based on the abilities,
qualifications, and expertise required under County Ord. §
10-2-5 . (Ord. 2025-1291-O, 5-6-2025)
3-2-8: EMERGENCY LICENSE SUSPENSION:
   A.   Emergency Suspension. The Sheriff's office may immediately and
temporarily close down any licensed premises if it has probable cause to
believe the continued operation presents imminent danger to the health or
safety of its customers, employees, or the public. If the licensee eliminates
the imminent danger, the Sheriff's office may lift the emergency suspension.
During the emergency suspension, the licensed premises may not open, operate,
manufacture, distribute, or sell alcoholic beverages. Imminent danger includes,
but is not limited to, permitting disorderly conduct, violence, or other law
violations; failure to comply with state required posting of licenses or
warnings; sale of alcohol to an intoxicated person; sale of alcohol to a minor;
or any illegal sale of alcohol.
   B.   Temporary License Suspension. A county alcohol business license is
temporarily suspended during an emergency suspension by the Sheriff's office.
The licensee may request an emergency hearing before the County Commission,
which hearing shall be held within fourteen (14) business days of the emergency
suspension, unless a hearing delay is requested by the licensee. If an
emergency hearing does not occur within the fourteen (14) days, or within the
extended time requested by the licensee, the emergency suspension is lifted.
The hearing and decision of the County Commission is subject to further
proceedings to deny, not renew, or revoke the county alcohol business license,
and the appeal hearing provisions, as set forth in this chapter and Washington
County Code title 10, chapter 2. (Ord. 2025-1291-O, 5-6-2025)
3-2-9: VIOLATIONS; CIVIL PENALTIES; CRIMINAL CITATIONS:
   A.   Violations. Violations may be addressed as a regulation violation with
a civil penalty, or with a criminal citation. A violation notice may be issued
by the community development department based on substantial evidence for any
action or inaction that violates the provisions of this section, or federal,
state, or local law. A licensee, owner, manager, or agent of the licensee, or
all (the "interested parties") may receive a violation notice if the county
finds the licensee, or the licensed premises, violates any provision herein.
Any regulation violation, civil penalty, or criminal citation, or any
combination of them, may result in denial, non-renewal, or revocation of the
county alcohol business license. Such action is a final administrative decision
of the community development department.
   B.   Civil Penalty or Criminal Citation. Any interested party may be
assessed a civil penalty or be given a criminal citation if found the licensed
premises are found in violation of the provisions herein. For the first
violation of this section, an interested party shall be given written notice of
the violation, a warning of the possible civil and criminal penalties, and a
reasonable opportunity to cure. If timely cured, it still counts as a first
violation, but no further action will be taken by the county unless a second
violation occurs. No warning or opportunity to cure applies to the emergency
suspension of a county alcohol business license under County Ord.
3-2-8 . The county hereby adopts the following civil penalty schedule:
      1.   First violation: warning letter.
      2.   Second violation: two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00) a day
until compliance or county alcohol business license revocation.
      3.   Any additional violation thereafter: five hundred dollars ($500.00)
a day until compliance or county alcohol business license revocation.
      4.   Any criminal citation also is a violation, and successful
prosecution may result in fines or fees separate from civil penalties.
      5.   All civil penalties or criminal citations related to violations
enumerated herein can be enforced against any interested party as defined
above.
   C.   Criminal Citation. Any additional violation (after the first violation
warning letter, and the second violation) also may be prosecuted as a class B
misdemeanor. Each additional violation is a separate class B misdemeanor. Any
interested party as defined above may be criminally cited for violating any of
the provisions of title 3 chapter 2, and shall be guilty of a class B
misdemeanor for each offense, and for each offense thereafter, and it is a
separate offense for each day the violation occurs, cited at intervals
permitted by State law. (Ord. 2025-1291-O, 5-6-2025)
CHAPTER 3
SPECIAL EVENTS
SECTION:
3-3-1: Purpose
3-3-2: Definitions
3-3-3: Special Event Permit Required
3-3-4: Exceptions To A Requirement For A Special Event Permit
3-3-5: Application And Fees For Special Event Permit
3-3-6: Conditions For Issuing Permit
3-3-7: Application Processing
3-3-8: Grounds For Denial
3-3-9: Grounds For Revocation
3-3-10: Hearing, Appeal On Permit Denial Or Revocation
3-3-11:Enforcement
 
3-3-12:Penalties And Liability
3-3-1: PURPOSE:
It is the purpose of the county to protect the safety of its residents and
visitors. Special events have a quantifiable impact on county services, and the
health, safety, or welfare of the public. The county intends to encourage event
organizers to coordinate with the county to protect the safety and convenience
of individuals who are attending the event, and all residents and the public by
mitigating potential issues which may occur as a result of the special event.
It is the intent of this chapter to ensure that a special event does not create
a disturbance, become a nuisance, disrupt traffic, or threaten life, health or
property. It is not the intent of this chapter to regulate the content of
speech, or infringe upon the right to peacefully assemble, except for time,
place and manner regulations. The County supports the public's right to
assemble and supports free speech, and the County does not restrict assembly or
speech on the basis of content, viewpoint, or message. If two hundred (200) or
more participants are expected for an assembly, obtain a county permit for a
major event. (Ord. 2014-1037-O, 5-6-2014; amd. Ord., 4-28-2021; Ord. 2025-1291-
O, 5-6-2025)
3-3-2: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter:
APPLICANT: Any individual, natural human being, partnership, corporation, firm,
company, association, or group that requests a special permit, and is
responsible for the event and the payment of fees.
ASSEMBLE: For individuals or participants to gather in one place or for
participants to traverse from a starting point to a finishing point.
ATHLETIC EVENT: A special event that is organized for a competitive or
recreational purpose with people collectively engaged in a sport or physical
exercise on public or private property, with people collectively engaged in a
sport or physical exercise on public or private property.
ATTENDEES: General and inclusive of the all of the people included at a special
event, including: participants, registrants, organizers, spectators, staff,
contractors,
COUNTY SPONSORED EVENT: A special event where the county is a primary sponsor,
whether directly or by contract with a third party applicant.
COUNTY EVENT: A special event that is organized and operated by the county.
ENDURANCE EVENT: A prolonged athletic event that has a course that is three
mile in distance or longer. Endurance events include, but are not limited to,
marathons, triathlons, 5K or 10K races, and cycling century (100 miles or
more), encompassing public or private property.
FILMING EVENT: An event involving the recording by film, video, or other medium
of live action or landscapes for educational, commercial, or other purposes
beyond personal use. Filming events include filming a motion picture,
television, cable, or other broadcast, and digital media production, but does
not include filming for a news broadcast. A filming event requires a film event
permit.
MAJOR EVENT: An event in which two hundred (200) or more individuals will take
part (including participants, registrants, organizers, spectators, staff,
contractors, volunteers, or officials).
Any special event with seventy-five (75) or more attendees, but less than two
hundred (200) attendees, that:
   1.   Requires full or partial closure of a public right-of-way;
   2.   That uses county property;
   3.   Impacts county services; or
   4.   The event is on SR-18.
MINOR EVENT: An event in which seventy-five (75) or more, but less than two
hundred (200), individuals will take part (including participants, registrants,
organizers, spectators, staff, contractors, volunteers, or officials), unless
otherwise defined as a major event.
PARTICIPANT: Someone who takes part in the activity for which the special event
takes place, e.g., a runner in a marathon or a bicyclist in bicycle relay. This
term does not include spectators, volunteers, or officials.
SPECIAL EVENT: Any gathering of seventy-five (75) or more individuals
(including participants, registrants, organizers, spectators, staff,
contractors, volunteers, or officials). A special event includes those open to
the public, or not, for profit or not for profit, occurring for a limited or
fixed duration not to exceed fourteen (14) consecutive days. Events include,
but are not limited to, athletic events, endurance events, cultural events,
entertainment, commercial, carnivals, circuses, concerts, live shows, dances,
revivals, filming events, rodeos, race events, fight events, flea markets, swap
meets, outdoor sales events, craft fairs, parades, farmers' markets, or other
similar gatherings. (Ord. 2014-1037-O, 5-6-2014; amd. Ord., 4-28-2021; Ord.
2025-1291-O, 5-6-2025)
3-3-3: SPECIAL EVENT PERMIT REQUIRED:
   A.   Special Event Permit Requirement: No person, entity, organization,
business, or other establishment may permit, promote, advertise, organize,
manage, sponsor, sell or give tickets, or operate a special event in the
unincorporated County without a special event permit, unless an exception under
section
3-3-4  of this chapter applies.
      1.   Special Events on SR-18: Due to the amount of vehicle and active
transportation traffic on SR-18, all special events that use SR-18 from mile
marker ten to mile marker thirty-nine (39) are considered major events if there
are seventy-five (75) or more attendees.
         a.   Special events on SR-18 with less than two hundred (200)
participants shall utilize the paved county trail, not the roadway, and shall
share the trail with the public. It is the intent of this provision to get
small special events off SR-18 and onto the trail.
         b.   Special events on SR-18 with two hundred (200) or more
participants may use the roadway unless the County determines that requiring
use of the paved county trail is in the best interest of the county. The county
will determine if the event shall use the roadway or the trail and shall
determine if the county will close the trail to the public during the event.
The applicant or organizer is responsible for any needed road, trail, or other
signage to the public.
      2.   Special Events Impacting County Services: Due to the impact on
county services like traffic, parking, litter control, overcrowding, noise, or
the presence of law enforcement, all concerts, live shows, and dances are
considered major events if there are seventy-five (75) or more attendees unless
a specific exception applies under County Ord.
3-3-4 .
   B.   Operating Without A Special Event Permit: If a special event permit has
not been issued by the county, the enforcement and penalty provisions apply to
all organizers, promoters, advertisers, managers, sponsors, entities, or others
involved in the unpermitted special event. The Sheriff's office or the county
have the authority to shut down an unpermitted special event and to disperse
the attendees. Road Closure Requirement: If a full or partial road closure is
requested, a separate encroachment permit is required, and no exceptions shall
apply. (Ord. 2014-1037-O, 5-6-2014; amd. Ord., 4-28-2021; Ord. 2025-1291-O, 5-
6-2025)
3-3-4: EXCEPTIONS TO A REQUIREMENT FOR A SPECIAL EVENT PERMIT:
   A.   Established Place Of Assembly Exception: This chapter shall not apply
to any regular established, permanent place of worship, stadium, athletic
field, arena, auditorium, coliseum, the Washington County Fairgrounds, or other
similar permanently established place of assembly.
   B.   Event Business: A building that has a business with a current annual
business license as an event business. All businesses and places of assembly
shall comply with posted occupancy limits and classifications required by law
and the International Building Code.
   C.   Family Gathering Exception: This chapter shall not apply to family
reunions, wedding celebrations, funerals, or similar family gatherings as
determined by the county.
   D.   Community block parties are limited to four (4) per year per
subdivision or neighborhood area as determined by county. Garage sales are
limited to four (4) per year per lot or parcel.
   E.   County Facility: For purposes of this chapter, county events are not
special events. However, county sponsored events are special events.
   F.   Open House: Real estate open houses are not special events, including
an event held by a homeowner, real estate agent, architect, builder, or
developer to showcase a home or its outdoor landscaping for marketing purposes.
   G.   Free Speech Gathering Exception: If the purpose of the event is to
gather to protest, advocate, or otherwise express one's freedom of speech, then
a permit is not required unless:
      1.   A full or partial road closure is required;
      2.   The public safety is threatened; or
      3.   It is anticipated that two hundred (200) or more participants will
attend.
   In such cases, a major special event permit is required regulating only the
time, place, and manner of the event, and without consideration of the content
of speech or infringing on the right to assemble. (Ord. 2014-1037-O, 5-6-2014;
amd. Ord., 4-28-2021; Ord. 2025-1291-O, 5-6-2025)
3-3-5: APPLICATION AND FEES FOR SPECIAL EVENT PERMIT:
   A.   Application Deadlines: A complete application for a minor special event
permit shall be submitted to the county with a nonrefundable fee of one hundred
dollars ($100.00) for an initial application or fifty dollars ($50.00) for the
renewal of an application for an event held in the past two (2) years, no later
than thirty (30) days before a minor event. A complete application for a major
special event permit shall be submitted to the county with a nonrefundable fee
of two hundred dollars ($200.00) for an initial application, or one hundred
($100.00) for the renewal of an application for an event held in the past two
years, no later than sixty (60) days before a major event. An application may
be filed no earlier than twelve (12) months before the event. Applications
shall be on county approved forms and are not considered complete until all
required information has been submitted and accepted by the county. Advertising
for a special event prior to issuance of a special event permit is at the sole
risk of applicant. All days and deadlines expressed in title 3, chapter 3,
Special Events, refer to calendar days, unless business days are specified.
      1.   Multi-Year Special Event Permit. A multi-year special event permit
may be granted in county's discretion for up to three years upon consideration
of all relevant factors, including a showing by applicant that the details
below in paragraph C remain substantially the same as in the initial
application. Sixty days in advance of the multi-year special event, applicant
shall disclose to the county the date of the event and a new certificate of
insurance. Applicant also shall disclose any substantial changes to the event.
If no substantial changes are reported, and the new COI is approved, the multi-
year event proceeds. For a two (2)-year minor special event permit the fee is
one hundred and fifty dollars ($150.00), and two hundred dollars ($200.00) for
a three (3)-year permit. For a two (2)-year major special event permit the fee
is three hundred dollars ($300.00), and four hundred dollars ($400.00) for a
three (3)-year permit. Late fees may apply.
      2.   Late Application Fee: If an applicant fails to meet the deadline,
the applicant shall pay an additional nonrefundable fee of one hundred dollars
($100.00) for expedited processing. No late application or late fee will be
accepted unless it is a minimum of fourteen (14) days before a minor event, or
thirty (30) days before a major event.
      3.   Fundraising Event (minor or major): For an event in which seventy
percent (70%) or more of the proceeds go to an individual, family, or group
that is in need of financial assistance due to a medical issue, natural
disaster, tragic event, or similar circumstances, all fees will be waived.
Application deadlines still apply.
      4.   Cost Recovery Required: Costs incurred by the County shall be paid
by the applicant, individuals, organizers, or entities for the special event in
an amount proportionate to the impacts on the County for unbudgeted expenses
for excess public services. Event-specific fees may include: public safety,
utilities, traffic control, parking, fire protection, road damage, cleanup,
staff time, other public services, or other similar impacts generated by the
event. The County may require applicant to provide an estimate of the excess
public services needed for the special event, and may require payment in
advance for estimated expenses for excess public services to be reconciled
after the event. A post-event reconciliation and invoice may be prepared by the
County, and any outstanding expenses shall be paid to the County within thirty
(30) days. If not paid, the County may recover the expenses by filing a lien on
property of the applicant, individuals, organizers, or entities, or by other
legal means. Failure to pay for expenses for excess public services will result
in subsequent applications for special events being denied for a period of five
(5) years.
      5.   Government Sponsored Event: The fee shall be waived for a county
event, government event, or an event organized by a municipality in the county.
   B.   Unsworn Declaration: The person making the application shall include an
unsworn declaration, declaring under criminal penalty, that the information
contained in the application is accurate and complete. The applicant, event
organizer, and the entities person making the application are responsible for
the event.
   C.   Information Required: The application shall contain and disclose:
      1.   Contact Information: The name, phone number, e-mail address, and
mailing address of the applicant, and the organizer's and entity's business
addresses. A single point of contact and their physical location shall be
provided for day-of-event purposes;
      2.   Property Location: The address, and parcel numbers or legal
descriptions, of all property upon which the assembly is to be held, together
with the name, residence and mailing address of the owners of record of all
such properties. Applicant is required to have owners approval of the event on
their property;
      3.   Purpose: A description of the event and all of its anticipated
elements, including signage, merchandise, food, alcohol, entertainment, audio
or visual equipment, temporary power, amusement rides, inflatable devices,
fires, or fireworks;
      4.   Duration: The date of the special event, and the total number of
days and/or hours during which the assembly is to last. Include all set-up and
take-down days;
      5.   Maximum Capacity: The maximum number of attendees the applicant
shall permit to participate in or attend the special event, not to exceed the
maximum number which can reasonably assemble at the location of the special
event. For overnight events, the maximum number of persons allowed to sleep
within the boundaries of the location of the special event is determined in
consultation with the zoning ordinances of the county if the special event is
to continue overnight;
      6.   Maximum Ticket Sales: The maximum number of tickets to be sold, if
any;
      7.   Potable Water: The plans for supplying potable water, including the
source, amount available, and location of outlets;
      8.   Sanitary Facilities: The plans for providing toilet and lavatory
facilities including the source, number and location, type, and the means of
disposing of waste deposited;
      9.   Solid Waste: The plans for holding, collecting and disposing of
solid waste material;
      10.   Emergency Services: The plans shall include the name(s) of any
organization providing emergency or medical services and the existence of any
agreement for emergency or medical services. All special event applications
shall provide adequate measures to assure the health and safety of the
participants, attendees and the public related to the event;
      11.   Lighting: The plans, if any, to illuminate the location of the
assembly including the source and amount of power and the location of lamps.
All special events shall have adequate lighting to secure the health and safety
of participants, attendees and the public related to the event;
      12.   Parking: The plans for the adequate parking of vehicles, or
shuttling of attendees, including size and location of lots, points of highway
access and interior roads, including routes between highway access and parking
lots;
      13.   Camping Facilities: The plans for camping facilities, if any,
including facilities available and their location;
      14.   Security: The plans for security, including the number of guards,
their names, addresses, credentials and hours of availability. Security
personnel shall be adequately trained and eighteen (18) or older. The Sheriff's
office will determine if security personnel are necessary, and the required
number.
         a.   If applicant proposes an age restricted special event (i.e.,
eighteen (18) and older), applicant shall propose adequate measures to enforce
the age restriction. The county encourages applicants to impose age
restrictions for special events when appropriate to protect children,
adolescents, or juveniles from attending specific special events that would not
be appropriate for their age group.
         b.   The plans for the prevention of illegal activity at the special
event, the assembly site and the vicinity, including, but not limited to,
assault, underage drinking, or illegal drug use and/or distribution. If there
are credible reports about an applicant, organizer, operator or property owner
(including successor or related corporate entities), based on other special
events in Utah, failing to monitor alleged illegal activity at an event, the
county may deny an application, in its reasonable discretion, to further the
health, safety, and welfare of the public.
      15.   Fire Protection: The plans for fire protection, including the
number, type and location of all protective devices, including alarms and
extinguishers, and the number of emergency fire personnel available to operate
the equipment;
      16.   Vendors; Concessions: The plans for vendors or concessionaires who
will be allowed to operate on the grounds, including the names and addresses of
all vendors or concessionaires, their license or permit numbers, and proof of
insurance;
      17.   Traffic Laws, Controls or Road Closures: The plans for and map of
all traffic controls and full or partial road closures for the event with
details on how those roads will be controlled or closed and the plans for
enforcement. Details regarding pick up of drop out participants, and the time
for course closure, are required:
         a.   All special event participants, attendees and organizers are
subject to traffic laws and trail rules, and will be cited for violations,
         b.   State Road 18: Due to traffic volumes, and to secure the health
and safety of participants, attendees and the public, special events on SR-18
shall not impair the roadway or lanes. Except for signature events, Iimpairment
is prohibited and includes the use of lead vehicles, escort or sweeper
vehicles, barricades, closures, or any other impairment by organizers,
attendees, or participants.
            (1)   For special events with less than two hundred (200)
attendees, route participants onto the paved county trail, and provide signage
to the public for entering and exiting the trail, and at regular intervals on
the trail, messaging to the public that the public and the event are sharing
the trail. Signage and placement shall be proposed by the applicant and
approved by the county.
            (2)   For special events with two hundred (200) or more attendees
on the roadway, propose signage to the public regarding the special event. Do
not route participants onto the county paved trail.
            (3)   Signature events, defined as Ironman, St. George Marathon and
Snow Canyon Half Marathon, shall follow county policies negotiated with event
sponsors and governmental entity partners for roadway controls or closures.
      18.   Route Plan: A complete route plan showing all routes, including
legible maps, and including the participants' routes, parking, staging, start,
finish and assembly areas;
      19.   Site Plan: A site plan showing a diagram of all gathering points
and the location of parking, shuttles, first aid and water stations, vendors,
concessionaires, sanitary facilities, spectator areas, etc.
   D.   It is the responsibility of any event organizer or vendor participating
in a special event to remit sales taxes to the Utah State Tax Commission.
Admission fees, participation fees, and merchandise and food sales, are taxable
sales sourced to the county in which the special event starts regardless of the
location of the business entity or end location. Charitable organizations with
501(c)(3) entity status shall follow all federal and state tax laws. (Ord.
2014-1037-O, 5-6-2014; amd. Ord., 4-28-2021; Ord. 2025-1291-O, 5-6-2025)
3-3-6: CONDITIONS FOR ISSUING PERMIT:
   A.   Conditions Apply To All Permits: Unless otherwise stated, the
conditions contained in this section apply to every permit issued by the
county. The county community development director, in consult with the
appropriate department, may determine that a particular requirement does not
apply to the event at issue except those that relate to law enforcement or the
county's liability or the bond/proof of insurance requirement.
   B.   Maximum Number Of Persons Determination: Before the applicant may be
issued a permit, the applicant shall first determine the maximum number of
participants and total number of all attendees who will be assembled at or be
admitted to the location of the special event. The maximum number shall not
exceed the maximum number which can reasonably assemble at or be admitted to
the location of the special event.
   C.   Requirements To Be Furnished: Before the applicant may be issued a
permit, the applicant shall provide proof of the following before the event
commences:
      1.   Water: Potable water, meeting all federal and state requirements for
purity, sufficient to provide drinking water for the maximum number of people
to be assembled at the rate of at least one gallon per person per day;
      2.   Sanitary Facilities: The approved plans for providing sanitary
facilities sufficient for the maximum capacity for the event. If no plans are
submitted and approved, the default plans shall be as follows: Sufficient
toilets for all participants, registrants, organizers, spectators, staff,
contractors, volunteers, or officials meeting all state and local
specifications, conveniently located throughout the grounds, sufficient to
provide facilities for the maximum number of people to be assembled together
with an efficient, sanitary means of disposing of waste matter deposited, which
is in compliance with all state and local laws and regulations;
      3.   Waste Disposal: The approved plans for providing waste disposal
sufficient for the maximum capacity for the event. If no plans are submitted
and approved, the default plans shall be as follows: A sanitary method of
disposing of solid waste, in compliance with state and local laws and
regulations, sufficient to dispose of the solid waste production of the maximum
number of people to be assembled at the rate of at least two and one-half (2 1/
2) pounds of solid waste per person per day, together with a plan for holding
and a plan for collecting all such waste at least once each day of the assembly
and sufficient trash cans with tightfitting lids and personnel to perform the
task;
      4.   Medical Personnel: The approved plans for providing sufficient
medical personnel to provide for the needs of the special event's participants
with special consideration given to the medical needs of endurance race
participants, and the medical needs of all participants, registrants,
organizers, spectators, staff, contractors, volunteers, officials, or the
public;
      5.   Lighting: If the special event is to continue during hours of
darkness, illumination sufficient to reasonably light the entire area of the
special event, but not to shine beyond the boundaries of the location of the
assembly or the special event property;
      6.   Parking: A free parking area inside of the special event grounds
sufficient to provide required ADA parking, and parking space for the maximum
number of people to be assembled at the rate required by state and federal law;
      7.   Camping Facilities: If the special event is to continue overnight,
camping facilities in compliance with all federal, state and local requirements
sufficient to provide camping accommodations for the maximum number of people
to be assembled overnight;
      8.   Security Personnel: Security guards will only be deemed necessary if
required by the Washington County sheriff's office. The sheriff may determine
the number of security guards necessary to provide adequate security;
      9.   Fire Protection: Fire protection, including, where applicable,
alarms, extinguishing devices and fire lanes and escapes, sufficient to meet
all federal, state and local standards for the location of the special event
and sufficient emergency personnel to efficiently operate the required
equipment;
      10.   Signage: Any signs or barriers placed on or near roadways or trails
can be placed no sooner than twenty four (24) hours before the event and must
be taken down no later than twenty four (24) hours after the event, unless the
county requires additional signage;
      11.   Proof Of Insurance: Applicant, and all vendors or concessionaires
at the special event, shall provide proof of insurance for approval by the
county attorney's office. Unless approved otherwise, they must have insurance
in an amount to protect the county from liability up to or greater than the
governmental immunity threshold under Utah state law. They must also indemnify
and hold harmless the county or any of its agents, officers, servants and
employees from any liability or causes of action which might arise by reason of
granting the permit. All coverage shall be occurrence based, not claims made.
         a.   Bond: In addition, the county may require the applicant to also
obtain a cash bond in circumstances that have the potential to damage county
infrastructure or for events that use excess public services.
      12.   Road Closures Plan And Notification: The applicant's proposed road
closures must be reviewed and approved by the applicable department, including,
where applicable, the Washington County public works department, the Washington
County sheriff's office, or the Utah department of transportation. Applicants
and organizers shall comply with all signage required by the county.
      13.   Law Enforcement Plan: If deemed necessary by the sheriff, the
applicant is required to coordinate with the Washington County sheriff's office
in developing a law enforcement plan for the event. If the special event
crosses multiple jurisdictions, the applicant shall also coordinate with the
other jurisdictions.
      14.   Support Vehicle Regulations: The sheriff may develop safety
regulations and procedures for support vehicles used during an endurance event.
If the sheriff has developed these regulations and posted them on a county
website, then those regulations will become a condition upon issuing a permit
for any special event that uses support vehicles during an endurance event;
   D.   Limitation Of Liability: This chapter shall not be construed as
imposing upon the county or its officials or employees any liability or
responsibility for any injury or damage to any person in any way connected to
the use for which permits have been issued. The county and its employees shall
not be deemed to have assumed any liability or responsibility by reasons of
inspections performed, the issuance of any permit, or the approval of any use
of the right of way. The county does not waive any governmental immunity that
it has under the governmental immunity act of Utah, found in Utah Code Ann. §
63G-7-101, et. seq., or any other valid provision under which the county may
rightly claim immunity.
   E.   Additional Conditions: The county community development director,
county sheriff, or county commission may add any reasonable condition deemed
necessary for health, safety, or welfare of persons or property when issuing a
permit.
   F.   Additional Information: The county may require any other information
reasonably determined to be pertinent, including, but not limited to,
information from other governmental entities like: UHP, UDOT, the Health
Department, local municipalities, DABC, or federal or state land management
agencies. (Ord. 2014-1037-O, 5-6-2014; amd. Ord., 4-28-2021; Ord. 2025-1291-O,
5-6-2025)
3-3-7: APPLICATION PROCESSING:
   A.   Departments To Review: Upon receipt of an application for a permit, the
community development director may circulate copies of the application to any
department the community development director believes should provide input on
the application or to any department that will provide services related to the
application.
   B.   Considerations: In reviewing an application, department may consider
the following:
      1.   The impact of the proposed special event on the traffic, security,
health and safety of the public;
      2.   A determination by the department of appropriate and reasonable
requirements for the mitigation of traffic, security, health and safety
concerns and an evaluation of the measure proposed by the applicant to satisfy
those requirements.
      3.   The demonstrated ability of the applicant to comply with
requirements necessary to protect the safety, health and welfare of the public.
      4.   The location and duration of the proposed special event and the
county's ability to accommodate the event with the necessary resources.
      5.   Other previously approved special events that could cause scheduling
conflicts during the same period and cause overextension of the county's
resources or severe traffic issues.
      6.   Any other factor the department may reasonably deem to be necessary
to protect the health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of the county.
   C.   Submission Of Concerns By Department: A department involved in
reviewing an application may submit, in writing, concerns, which the department
has regarding the security of property and the protection of the health and
safety of the public.
   D.   Approval Of Application: After the application is reviewed by the
appropriate departments, the county community development director or the
director's designee may approve, approve with conditions, or deny the request
for a special event.
   E.   Time Line For Approval: For all special events, a decision to approve,
approve with conditions, or deny the application must be made within twenty
(20) days after the submission of a complete application. (Ord. 2014-1037-O, 5-
6-2014; amd. Ord., 4-28-2021)
3-3-8: GROUNDS FOR DENIAL:
The county can deny an application, and give notice to applicant, for the
following grounds:
   A.   The proposed special event violates a law, ordinance, policy,
procedure, or regulation or poses a danger or threat to the public health,
safety or welfare, or causes unreasonable inconvenience or cost the public;
   B.   The proposed special event is not consistent with the intended nature
and use of the requested county property;
   C.   The proposed special event is scheduled at a place and time that could
disrupt or interfere with an already approved special event;
   D.   The proposed location or building is not adequate to accommodate the
proposed special event such as parking, sanitation facilities, and health or
safety codes, or the nature of the proposed special event is such that the
county, or the applicant, does not have sufficient resources available to
ensure the health, safety, and welfare of special event participants,
attendees, or the general public;
   E.   The permit application contains a material falsehood or
misrepresentation;
   F.   The applicant has failed to pay a debt to the county including costs
incurred during a prior special event;
   G.   Incomplete permit applications; or
   H.   The applicant or any person on whose behalf the applicant for a permit
was made has on prior occasions:
      1.   Damaged county property if the applicant is for an event on county
property; or
      2.   Made material misrepresentations regarding the nature or scope of an
event or activity previously permitted; or
      3.   Has violated the terms of prior permits issued to or on behalf of
the applicant. (Ord., 4-28-2021; amd. Ord. 2025-1291-O, 5-6-2025)
3-3-9: GROUNDS FOR REVOCATION:
The county can revoke a permit, and give notice to the applicant, for the
following grounds:
   A.   Discretionary Revocation: The county community development director or
county sheriff may revoke an issued special event permit at any time if any of
the conditions necessary for issuing the permit are not met.
   B.   Automatic Revocation: An issued permit shall be immediately revoked and
void if any of the following apply:
      1.   The information upon which the permit was issued was misleading.
      2.   The plans contained in the permit are not reasonably followed.
      3.   The maximum number of participants or attendees in an area is
exceeded.
      4.   The safety plans are not followed in such a way that the
participants, spectators, volunteers, officials, or the general public, are put
at a substantial risk of serious bodily harm or death.
      5.   A road or lanes are partially or fully closed or impaired without
the permission of the county.
      6.   A disaster, public calamity, riot, or other emergency exists that
necessitates canceling the permit. (Ord. 2014-1037-O, 5-6-2014; amd. Ord., 4-
28-2021; Ord. 2025-1291-O, 5-6-2025)
3-3-10: HEARING, APPEAL ON PERMIT DENIAL OR REVOCATION:
   A.   Notice To Applicant: If the county community development director or
sheriff's office determines that facts exist for denial or revocation under
this chapter, the county shall notify the applicant in writing and shall
specify the grounds for such denial or revocation.
   B.   Exception To Notice And Appeal: When the county community development
director or sheriff's office learns of facts immediately before or during a
special event that require the revocation of the permit, then the county
community development director or sheriff's office can revoke the permit, and
the notice and appeal requirements shall not apply. The revocation is
immediate, and the crowd shall disperse if assembled. The standard for the
county community development director or county sheriff's decision is whether
they acted reasonably under the circumstance.
   C.   Applicant's Opportunity To Appeal Staff's Decision: Within ten (10)
business days of receipt of staff's decision, the applicant may provide to the
county clerk/auditor, in writing, an appeal with a detailed statement of
reasons why the permit should not have been denied or revoked.
      1.   Effect Of No Appeal: If an appeal is not received within ten (10)
business days of the denial or revocation, the denial or revocation becomes
final and may not be appealed.
   D.   Notice Of Hearing: Within three (3) business days of the receipt of
applicant's written appeal, the county clerk/auditor shall notify applicant in
writing of the hearing date for the appeal.
   E.   Hearing: Within ten (10) business days of the receipt of applicant's
written response, the county commission shall conduct a hearing to determine
whether the denial or revocation was appropriately issued.
      1.   Opportunity For Representation: The applicant shall have the
opportunity to be represented by counsel, at the applicant's own expense, at
the hearing.
      2.   Opportunity To Present Case: The applicant shall have the
opportunity to present evidence and witnesses on the applicant's behalf.
   G.   County Commission Review: The county commission may, at its discretion,
decide whether to uphold the denial or revocation or choose to issue a new
permit, and their decision be deemed to be a final decision. (Ord. 2014-1037-O,
5-6-2014; amd. Ord., 4-28-2021; Ord. 2025-1291-O, 5-6-2025)
3-3-11: ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   Court Enforcement: The provisions of this chapter may be enforced by
the county with civil fines, criminal charges, or by injunction requested in a
court of competent jurisdiction.
   B.   Public Nuisance: The holding of a special event in violation of any
provisions or conditions contained in this chapter shall be deemed a public
nuisance and also may be abated as such. (Ord. 2014-1037-O, 5-6-2014; amd.
Ord., 4-28-2021; Ord. 2025-1291-O, 5-6-2025)
3-3-12: PENALTIES AND LIABILITY:
   A.   Special Event Shut Down: If the Sheriff's office or the county
determine that a special event is being conducted without a permit, in
violation of approved plans or conditions, or in violation of law, or the event
poses an imminent risk to public health, safety, or welfare, they have the
authority to shut down the special event and to disperse the attendees.
   B.   Civil Fines for Special Events: The civil fine for conducting a special
event without a valid permit is one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). Additionally,
the county may deny a special event permit for two years for the same event, or
for the same applicant or organizer. The civil fine for violating approved
plans or conditions of a special event permit is five hundred dollars ($500.00)
a day for each day of the violation.
   C.   Criminal Penalties for Holding a Major Event Without a Permit: An
individual, organizer, or entity that holds a major event without a permit, or
does not comply with the conditions of an issued permit for a major event, then
that individual, organizer, or entity shall be guilty of a class B misdemeanor.
   D.   Criminal Penalties For Holding A Minor Event Without A Permit: An
individual, organizer, or entity that holds a minor event without a permit, or
does not comply with the conditions of an issued permit for a minor event,
shall be guilty of a class C misdemeanor.
   E.   Civil and Criminal Liability: County may recover all costs incurred by
it from the applicant, individuals, organizers, or entities for the special
event in an amount proportionate to the impacts on the county for excess public
services. Cost recovery for event-specific fees may include: public safety,
utilities, traffic control, parking, fire protection, road damage, cleanup,
staff time, other public services, or other similar impacts generated by the
event. Applicants, organizers, operators, and property owners are wholly
responsible for the special events, and it is their responsibility to protect
participants, attendees and the public from nuisances or acts arising from or
related to the special event. Additionally, to the extent permitted by law,
applicants, organizers, operators and property owners may be prosecuted for
conspiring or knowingly permitting illegal activity at a special event. (Ord.
2014-1037-O, 5-6-2014; amd. Ord., 4-28-2021; Ord. 2025-1291-O, 5-6-2025)
CHAPTER 4
SEXUALLY ORIENTED BUSINESSES
SECTION:

3-4-0: PREAMBLE AND FINDINGS:
Whereas, the planning commission and the county commission have received
evidence concerning the adverse secondary effects of sexually oriented
businesses on the community presented in public hearings; and
Whereas, the planning commission and the county commission have conducted
extensive review of land use studies concerning the secondary effects
associated with sexually oriented businesses in other cities and counties,
including Phoenix, Arizona (1979); Tucson, Arizona (1990); Garden Grove,
California (1991); Los Angeles, California (1977); Whittier, California (1978);
Indianapolis, Indiana (1984); Minneapolis, Minnesota (1980); Cleveland, Ohio
(1977); Oklahoma City, Oklahoma (1986); Amarillo, Texas (1977); Austin, Texas
(1986); Beaumont, Texas (1982); Houston, Texas (1977); Seattle, Washington
(1989); Dallas, Texas (1997); Newport News, Virginia (1966); Ellicottville, New
York (1998); New Hanover County, North Carolina (1989); St. Croix County,
Wisconsin (1993); Adams County, Colorado (1990); and Manatee County, Florida
(1987); and
Whereas, the planning commission and the county commission have reviewed the
findings incorporated in the cases of United States v. O'Brien, 391 U.S. 367
(1968), Young v. American Mini Theatres, 427 U.S. 50 (1976), Schad v. Borough
of Mt. Ephraim, 452 U.S. 61 (1981), City of Renton v. Playtime Theatres, Inc.,
475 U.S. 41 (1986), City of Los Angeles v. Alameda Books, et al, 122 S. Ct.
1728 (2002); and
Whereas, the planning commission and the county commission have received public
input at public hearings with regard to the enactment of this chapter; and
Whereas, there is convincing documented evidence that sexually oriented
businesses, because of their very nature, have a deleterious effect on both
existing businesses around them and the surrounding residential areas adjacent
to them, causing among other adverse secondary effects, increased crime and
downgrading of property values; and
Whereas, there is convincing documented evidence that crime in areas
surrounding sexually oriented businesses is significantly higher than in like
areas where sexually oriented businesses are not present, which include
significant increases in sex offenses (rape, indecent exposure, lewd and
lascivious behavior and child molestation), violent crimes (rape, murder,
robbery and assault), and property crimes (burglary, larceny and auto theft);
and
Whereas, there is convincing documented evidence that increased crime and
unhealthful conduct tend to accompany, concentrate around and be aggravated by
sexually oriented businesses, including but not limited to, prostitution,
pandering, exposing minors to harmful materials, possession and distribution of
obscene materials and child pornography, possession and sale of controlled
substances, and violent crimes against persons and property; and
Whereas, there is convincing documented evidence that sexually oriented
businesses are frequently used for unlawful sexual activities, including
prostitution and sexual liaison of a casual nature; and
Whereas, there is convincing documented evidence that there are adverse harmful
effects on children and minors exposed to the effects of sexually oriented
businesses, deterioration of respect for family values, and people being afraid
to walk in areas where sexually oriented businesses operate, which necessitate
walking around or not visiting in the immediate neighborhood of such
businesses; and
Whereas, there is convincing documented evidence that when sexually oriented
businesses operate in the vicinity of churches, churches have had to drive the
elderly to church services to protect them from being exposed to unsavory
persons, and post private guards in their parking lots to keep patrons of
sexually oriented businesses, and people associated with the activities
surrounding the sexually oriented businesses, out of the church parking lots;
and
Whereas, there is convincing documented evidence that the value and
marketability of residential property (single-family and multiple-family
properties), within three (3) blocks of a sexually oriented business, and
commercial property, within three (3) blocks of a sexually oriented business,
are significantly lower than similar properties in areas where sexually
oriented businesses are not present, and that residential locations are
affected more than commercial locations; and
Whereas, there is convincing documented evidence that there is a deterioration
in the quality of businesses which choose to operate in and around such
sexually oriented businesses; and
Whereas, there is convincing documented evidence that sexually oriented
businesses, due to their nature, have serious objectionable operational
characteristics, particularly when they are operating in close proximity to
each other, thereby contributing to increased crime, lower property values,
urban blight, and downgrading of the quality of life in the adjacent area,
including increased noise, lighting and traffic generated by sexually oriented
businesses, and that the higher the concentration of sexually oriented
businesses, the greater the impact; and
Whereas, there is convincing documented evidence that the peak hours of a
sexually oriented business are evening hours, and that the operation of
sexually oriented businesses during late hours is a nuisance to property owners
in close proximity to a sexually oriented business, who use their property
during evening hours by increasing the contact of neighboring property owners
with the negative secondary effects of sexually oriented businesses; and
Whereas, the county, consistent with the sale and consumption of alcohol and
outside advertising limitations, finds that restricted hours of operation will
further prevent the adverse secondary effects of sexually oriented businesses;
and
Whereas, there is convincing documented evidence that sexually oriented
businesses lend themselves to ancillary unlawful and unhealthy activities that
are presently uncontrolled by the operators of the sexually oriented business
establishments; and
Whereas, there is convincing documented evidence that booths in sexually
oriented businesses facilitate anonymous sex acts between patrons, which
facilitate the spread of sexually transmitted diseases, that sexually oriented
businesses that do not have clear lines of vision encourage lewd behavior or
sexual contact, and that locked rooms in sexually oriented businesses are used
as fronts for prostitution; and
Whereas, concern over sexually transmitted diseases, including AIDS, is a
legitimate health concern of the county, which demands reasonable regulations
of sexually oriented businesses in order to protect the health and well-being
of its citizens; and
Whereas, there is convincing documented evidence that sexually oriented
business signs are generally larger, more often illuminated and graphic than
other commercial signs, which is out of keeping with neighborhood character and
results in the exposure of minors to inappropriate sexual images; and
Whereas, zoning, licensing and other police power regulations are legitimate.
reasonable means of accountability to ensure the operators of sexually oriented
businesses comply with reasonable regulations and are located in places which
minimize the adverse secondary effects which naturally accompany the operation
of such businesses; and
Whereas, location criteria alone will not adequately protect the health, safety
and general welfare of the citizens of the county and thus, certain regulation
with respect to the ownership and operation of sexually oriented businesses is
in the public interest; and
Whereas, requiring licensees of sexually oriented businesses to keep
information regarding current employees and past employees will help reduce the
incidence of certain types of criminal behavior by facilitating the
identification of potential witnesses or suspects and by preventing minors from
working in such establishments; and
Whereas, the disclosure of certain information by those persons ultimately
responsible for the day to day operation and maintenance of the sexually
oriented business, where such information is substantially related to the
significant governmental interest in the operation of such uses, will aid in
preventing the spread of sexually transmitted diseases; and
Whereas, it is desirable in the prevention of the spread of communicable
diseases to obtain information regarding certain employees who may engage in
the conduct which this chapter is designed to prevent or who are likely to be
witnesses to such activity; and
Whereas, the fact that an applicant for an adult use license has been convicted
of a sexually related crime leads to the rational assumption that the applicant
may engage in that conduct in contravention of this chapter, and the barring of
such individuals from the management or employees of sexually oriented
businesses for a period of years serves as a deterrent to and prevents conduct
which leads to the transmission of sexually transmitted diseases; and
Whereas, the county desires to minimize and control the adverse secondary
effects of sexually oriented businesses and thereby protect the health, safety
and welfare of the citizens of the county, protect its citizens from increased
crime, preserve the quality of life, preserve the property values and the
character of surrounding neighborhoods and businesses, deter the spread of
urban blight and protect against the threat to health from the spread of
communicable and social diseases; and
Whereas, sexually oriented businesses in the unincorporated areas of the county
require special supervision from public safety and health agencies of the
county in order to protect and preserve the health, safety and welfare of the
patrons of such businesses as well as the citizens of the county; and
Whereas, it is not the intent of this chapter to suppress any expression or
expressive conduct or activities protected by the first amendment, but to enact
a content neutral ordinance which addresses the secondary effects of sexually
oriented businesses; and
Whereas, it is not the intent of the planning commission and the county
commission to condone or legitimize the distribution of obscene materials, and
the planning commission and the county commission expect and encourage state
and local enforcement officials to enforce state and local obscenity laws
against such illegal activities in the county. (Ord. 2003-832-O, 5-6-2003)
3-4-1: STATUTORY AUTHORITY:
The statutory authority for enacting this chapter is Utah Code Annotated
sections 17-27-102 and 17-53-223, as amended. (Ord. 2003-832-O, 5-6-2003)
3-4-2: PURPOSE AND INTENT:
It is the purpose of this chapter to regulate sexually oriented businesses in
order to promote the health, safety, morals and general welfare of the citizens
of the county, and to establish reasonable and uniform regulations to prevent
the deleterious location and concentration of sexually oriented businesses
within the unincorporated areas of the county. The provisions of this chapter
have neither the purpose nor effect of imposing a limitation or restriction on
the content of any communicative materials, including sexually oriented
materials. Similarly, it is not the intent nor effect of this chapter to
restrict or deny access by adults to sexually oriented materials protected by
the first amendment, or to deny access by the distributors and exhibitors of
sexually oriented entertainment to their intended market. Neither is it the
intent nor effect of this chapter to condone or legitimize the distribution of
obscene material. (Ord. 2003-832-O, 5-6-2003)
3-4-3: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms and words are defined as
follows:
DISTINGUISHED OR CHARACTERIZED BY AN EMPHASIS UPON: The dominant or principal
theme of the object referenced. For instance, when the phrase refers to films
"which are distinguished or characterized by an emphasis upon the exhibition or
display of specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas", the
films so described are those whose dominant or principal character and theme
are the exhibition or display of "specified anatomical areas" or "specified
sexual activities".
EMPLOYEE: A person who works or performs in and/or for a sexually oriented
business, regardless of whether or not said person is paid a salary, wage or
other compensation by the operator of said business.
ESTABLISHMENT: Means and includes any of the following:
   A.   The opening or commencement of any sexually oriented business as a new
business;
   B.   The conversion of an existing business, whether or not a sexually
oriented business, to any sexually oriented business;
   C.   The addition of any sexually oriented business to any other existing
sexually oriented business; or
   D.   The relocation of any sexually oriented business.
LICENSEE: A person in whose name a license to operate a sexually oriented
business has been issued, as well as the individual listed as an applicant on
the application for a license; and in the case of an employee, a person in
whose name a license has been issued authorizing employment in a sexually
oriented business.
NUDITY, NUDE OR A STATE OF NUDITY: A. The appearance of human bare buttocks,
anus, male genitals, female genitals, or the areola or nipple of the female
breast; or
   B.   A state of dress which fails to opaquely and fully cover a human
buttocks, anus, male or female genitals, pubic region, or areola or nipple of
the female breast.
OPERATOR: Means and includes the owner, permit holder, custodian, manager,
operator or person in charge of any permitted or licensed premises.
PERMITTED PREMISES OR LICENSED PREMISES: Any premises that requires a license
and/or permit and that is classified as a sexually oriented business.
PERSON: An individual, proprietorship, partnership, corporation, association or
other legal entity.
PUBLIC BUILDING: Any building owned, leased or held by the United States, the
state, the county, a city, any special district, school district, or any other
agency or political subdivision of the state or the United States, which
building is used for governmental purposes.
PUBLIC PARK: Public land which has been designated for park or recreational
activities, including, but not limited to, a park, playground, nature trails,
swimming pool, reservoir, athletic field, basketball or tennis courts,
pedestrian or bicycle paths, open space, wilderness areas, or similar public
land within the county, which is under the control, operation or management of
the county.
RELIGIOUS INSTITUTION: Any church, synagogue, mosque, temple or building, which
is used primarily for religious worship and related religious activities.
RESIDENTIAL DISTRICT OR RESIDENTIAL USE: Except with regard to caretaker
residences in a commercial or manufacturing zone, a single-family, duplex,
townhouse, multiple-family, or mobile home park, development or subdivision and
campgrounds, and single-family, duplex, townhouse, multiple-family, or mobile
home uses, all as defined under county ordinances.
SCHOOL: Any public or private educational facility, including, but not limited
to, child daycare facilities, nursery schools, preschools, kindergartens,
elementary schools, primary schools, intermediate schools, junior high schools,
middle schools, high schools, vocational schools, secondary schools,
continuation schools, special education schools, junior colleges, colleges and
universities. "School" includes the school grounds, but does not include the
facilities used primarily for another purpose and only incidentally as a
school.
SEMINUDE: A state of dress in which clothing covers no more than the genitals,
pubic region and areola of the female breast, as well as portions of the body
covered by supporting straps or devices.
SEXUALLY ORIENTED BUSINESSES: Those businesses defined as follows:
Adult Arcade: Any place to which the public is permitted or invited, for any
form of consideration, where one or more still or motion picture projectors,
slide projectors or similar machines, or other image producing machines, for
viewing by five (5) or fewer persons each, are regularly used to show films,
motion pictures, video cassettes, compact discs, DVDs, slides, animations,
electronic media, or other photographic reproductions which are characterized
by the depiction or description of "specified sexual activities" or "specified
anatomical areas".
Adult Bookstore, Adult Novelty Store Or Adult Video Store: A commercial
establishment which has a significant or substantial portion of its stock in
trade or derives a significant or substantial portion of its revenues or
devotes a significant or substantial portion of its interior business or
advertising for the sale or rental, for any form of consideration, of any one
or more of the following:
   A.   Books, magazines, periodicals or other printed matter, or photographs,
films, motion pictures, video cassettes, compact discs, DVDs, slides,
animation, electronic media, or other visual representations which are
characterized by their emphasis upon the exhibition or display of "specified
sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas";
   B.   Instruments, devices or paraphernalia which are designed for use or
marketed primarily for stimulation of human genital organs or for
sadomasochistic use or abuse of the purchasers or others;
   C.   An establishment may have other principal business purposes that do not
involve the offering for sale, rental or viewing of materials depicting or
describing "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas", and
still be categorized as an "adult bookstore, adult novelty store or adult video
store". Such other business purposes will not serve to exempt such
establishments from being categorized as an "adult bookstore, adult novelty
store or adult video store" so long as one of its principal business purposes
is offering for sale, rental or viewing, for some form of consideration, the
specified materials which depict or describe "specified anatomical areas" or
"specified sexual activities".
Adult Cabaret: A nightclub, bar, restaurant, "bottle club", or similar
commercial establishment, whether or not alcoholic beverages are served, which
regularly features:
   A.   Persons who appear nude or in a state of nudity or seminudity;
   B.   Live performances which are characterized by the exposure of "specified
anatomical areas" or by "specified sexual activities"; or
   C.   Films, motion pictures, video cassettes, compact discs, DVDs, slides,
animation, electronic media or other photographic reproductions which are
characterized by the depiction or display of "specified sexual activities" or
"specified anatomical areas".
Adult Motel: A hotel, motel or similar commercial establishment which:
   A.   Offers accommodations to the public for any form of consideration,
which provides patrons with closed circuit television transmissions, films,
motion pictures, video cassettes, compact discs, DVDs, slides, animation,
electronic media, or other photographic reproductions which are characterized
by the depiction or description of "specified sexual activities" or "specified
anatomical areas", and which advertises the availability of this sexually
oriented type of material by means of a sign visible from the public right of
way, or by means of any off premises advertising, including, but not limited
to, newspapers, magazines, pamphlets or leaflets, radio or television;
   B.   Offers a sleeping room for rent for a period of time that is less than
ten (10) hours; or
   C.   Allows a tenant or occupant of a sleeping room to subrent the room for
a period of time that is less than ten (10) hours.
Adult Motion Picture Theater: A commercial establishment where, for any form of
consideration, films, motion pictures, video cassettes, compact discs, DVDs,
slides, animation, electronic media, or similar photographic reproductions are
regularly shown which are characterized by the depiction or description of
"specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas".
Adult Theater: A theater, concert hall, auditorium or similar commercial
establishment which, for any form of consideration, regularly features persons
who appear in a state of nudity or seminudity, or live performances which are
characterized by the exposure of "specified anatomical areas" or by "specified
sexual activities".
Escort: A person who, for any form of consideration, agrees or offers to act as
a companion, guide or date for another person, or who agrees or offers to
privately model lingerie or to privately perform a striptease for another
person.
Escort Agency: A person or business association who furnishes, offers to
furnish or advertises to furnish escorts as one of its primary business
purposes for a fee, tip or other consideration.
Massage Parlor: Any place where, for any form of consideration or gratuity,
massage, alcohol rub, administration of fomentations, electric or magnetic
treatments, or any other manipulation of the human body which occurs as a part
of or in connection with "specified sexual activities", or where any person
providing such treatment, manipulation or service related thereto exposes his
or her "specified anatomical areas". The definition of "sexually oriented
businesses" shall not include the practice of massage in any licensed hospital,
nor by a licensed hospital, nor by a licensed physician, surgeon, chiropractor,
