DISTRICT (the "District"):              storage, conservation, treatment,
                                        supply and distribution of water to its
                                        service area. (Ord. 2021-1177-O, 5-4-
                                        2021)
 
5-4-2: CAMPING:
Camping at the facility is limited to designated campgrounds and campsites, and
limited to holders of a valid permit for the time and date specified in the
permit. Each permit covers one vehicle and one attached item ofrecreational
equipment (i.e. travel trailer). A maximum of eight (8) people are allowed per
campsite. One camping unit is permitted per campsite (one tent, camper, RV, or
travel trailer). The stay limit is fourteen (14) days in any thirty (30) day
period, and is strictly enforced. The stay limit for each user also applies to
their tent, camper, RV, or travel trailer. Due to campsite sizes, no camper,
RV, or travel trailer in excess of thirty (30) feet is permitted. (Ord. 2021-
1177-O, 5-4-2021)
5-4-3: PETS:
   A.   Pets On Leash: Pets are permitted in the facility if on a leash and
under the direct control of a person, or if the pet is a hunting dog
accompanying a licensed hunter in the act of hunting during official seasons in
accordance with state and local laws. Pets shall be picked up after and
attended at all times.
   B.   Release Of Pets Or Nonnative Species. The release or attempted release
of pets or nonnative species into the facility is prohibited. (Ord. 2021-1177-
O, 5-4-2021)
5-4-4: FIRE RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Utah Department of Natural Resource ("DNR") fire restrictions apply to
the facility.
   B.   In addition to DNR fire restrictions, fire use is prohibited in the
facility except:
      1.   In designated camping areas when the fire is confined in an
existing, permanently constructed cement or metal fire pit; or
      2.   In a fire ring, stove or grill fueled solely by liquid petroleum.
   C.   All fires shall be completely extinguished when not in use. Leaving a
fire unattended is prohibited.
   D.   Firearm: It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge a firearm or
weapon within or into the boundaries of the facility except during state
regulated hunting within prescribed seasons. Propelling an arrow by a bow shall
be considered a discharge of a weapon for purposes of this section. Any device
or instrument loaded with powder or other explosive, or a gun or pistol
actuated by compressed air, shall be considered a firearm.
   E.   Firewood: Collecting, cutting and gathering of firewood is prohibited.
   F.   Fireworks and Explosives: No fireworks, or incendiary, chemical or
explosive devices, are permitted.
   G.   Smoking: No smoking except in an enclosed vehicle or trailer, or in a
developed recreation site with a minimum of three feet (3') in diameter
pavement area or clearing area down to mineral soil. Throwing or dropping of a
lighted cigarette or other burning material is prohibited. (Ord. 2021-1177-O,
5-4-2021)
5-4-5: PROHIBITED ACTIVITIES:
   A.   Camp Host Instructions: Failure to comply with camp host instructions
is prohibited and can result in cancellation of a permit, removal from the
facility, or both.
   B.   Garbage, Rubbish, And Hazardous Materials: Disposing of garbage or
rubbish of any kind, including hazardous materials or pollutants, other than at
points or places designated for the disposal of materials, is prohibited.
   C.   Discharge Of Wastewater: Discharging wastewater of any kind is
prohibited.
   D.   Recreational Activities: Paintball, target shooting, waterskiing or jet
skiing are prohibited. Any other activity that damages the facility is
prohibited.
   E.   Events Prohibited Without Permit: No person shall engage, conduct, or
participate in a scheduled event within the facility without a special
recreation permit, a special use permit, or a cooperative agreement.
   F.   Sound Systems, Noise: No person shall use loudspeakers, amplifiers or
public address systems in the facility without approval of the County. Quiet
hours are ten o’clock (10:00) P.M. to seven o’clock (7:00) A.M.
   G.   Entertainment and Similar Activities: No entertainment, exhibition,
meeting, concert or tournament, whether public or private, and whether for
profit or not, shall be conducted at the facility without a special event
permit or other written approval of the County.
   H.   Commercial Activity, Vending: No person or group may utilize the
facility for profit or financial gain without a special event permit or other
written approval of the County. This includes, but is not limited to, selling,
entertainment, concerts, and other activities that charge a fee.
   I.   Personal Property: Junk or personal property that poses an immediate
threat to the health or safety of the public may be seized and discarded
immediately without prior notice. Junk, vehicles, campers, RVs, trailers,
vessels, or other personal property left on the facility by a User or permit
holder, for twenty-four (24) hours or more, or after permit expiration, may be
seized, discarded, or impounded.
   J.   When personal property is seized, a notice shall be left stating where
the property is being held, how long it will be held, and how to contact the
holder of the property. All seized personal property shall be retained and
disposed of pursuant to the Utah State Code for abandoned property, and at
owner's expense. (Ord. 2021-1177-O, 5-4-2021)
5-4-6: VEHICLE USE:
   A.   Operating Or Parking Vehicles Or Trailers: Operating or parking a
vehicle or trailer, except where permitted, or in a designated campsite
matching the time and date specified on a valid permit, is prohibited. No
overnight parking of vehicles or trailers is allowed without a proper permit.
The operation of vehicles, including, but not limited to, cars, trucks,
machinery, motorcycles, dirt bikes, and OHVs and ATVs, off designated lanes of
travel is prohibited within the boundaries of the facility. Vehicles or
trailers operated or parked in violation of this provision shall be towed and
impounded at owner's expense. It is prohibited for any person to commit any
act, by use or operation of any motor vehicle in the Facility, which if
committed upon a public highway or street in the state, would be prohibited or
unlawful.
   B.   Speed Limit: The speed limit in the facility is fifteen (15) miles per
hour. (Ord. 2021-1177-O, 5-4-2021)
5-4-7: VESSEL USE:
Vessel use on the facility is limited to unpowered vessels, or vessels powered
by an outboard motor with ten (10) horsepower or less according to the
manufacturer's listing. Two-stroke outboard motors are not permitted.
Discharging hazardous materials or pollutants in the Facility is prohibited.
Utah boating regulations are enforced. No overnight parking of vessels is
allowed without a proper permit. (Ord. 2021-1177-O, 5-4-2021)
5-4-8: ENFORCEMENT, PENALTY:
Licensed law enforcement officers have jurisdiction in the facility and are
authorized to enforce the provisions of this chapter, and other federal, state
and local laws. Whoever violates any provision of this chapter may be
immediately expelled from the facility and prohibited from returning for forty-
eight (48) hours, and shall be guilty of a class B misdemeanor and, upon
conviction, subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. Any violation shall constitute a separate offense on each
successive day continued. If a violation occurs that results in damage to the
facility, the cost of repair may be assessed against the permit holder, the
violator, or both. (Ord. 2021-1177-O, 5-4-2021)
CHAPTER 5
DISPERSED CAMPING IN UNINCORPORATED WASHINGTON COUNTY AND PUBLIC LAND WITHIN
THE COUNTY
SECTION:
5-5-1: Purpose
5-5-2: Definitions
5-5-3: Dispersed Camping Limitations
5-5-4: Removal Of Unauthorized Campsites
5-5-5: Abandoned Property
5-5-6: No Camping Near Livestock Watering Points And Structures
5-5-7: Fire Restrictions
5-5-8: Enforcement
5-5-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to establish minimum standards to:
   A.   Reduce damage to lands used for Dispersed Camping in Washington County,
including local wildlife, vegetation, soil, and other resources;
   B.   Increase the safety and enjoyment of persons engaged in Dispersed
Camping and others recreating within Washington County; and
   C.   Assist local law enforcement officers in enforcing regulations enacted
to accomplish the purposes listed in (A-B) of this Section. (2021-1187-O, 8-17-
2021)
5-5-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the below listed terms, phrases, and words
shall have the following meanings:
                             The erecting of a tent or shelter of
                             natural or synthetic material, preparing
CAMPING:                     a sleeping bag or other bedding material
                             for use, or parking of a motor vehicle,
                             motor home or trailer for the apparent
                             purpose of overnight occupancy.
                             Any location outside of a Designated
CAMPSITE:                    Camping location used for the purpose of
                             Camping.
                             Any property, item, or substance which
CONTRABAND:                  is unlawful to produce or possess under
                             State or Federal Law.
                             Any form of Camping, within a pay-to-use
                             location or established location that
                             contains amenities, such as potable
                             water, toiletries, electrical hookups,
                             pavilions, or otherwise. Examples
DESIGNATED CAMPING:          include but are not limited to, any
                             commercial camping location such as:
                             KOA, RV parks, Federal Campsites, State
                             Parks, etc. (This Chapter does not apply
                             to any persons engaged in Designated
                             Camping within Washington County).
                             Camping anywhere within unincorporated
DISPERSED CAMPING:           Washington County or Public Land outside
                             of a Designated Camping location.
                             Any structure, man-made, natural or

5-5-3: DISPERSED CAMPING LIMITATIONS:
Where Dispersed Camping is allowed on undeveloped Public Land in the
unincorporated areas of Washington County the Dispersed Camping is limited to a
period not to exceed fifteen (15) days within a twenty-eight (28) consecutive
day period. The twenty-eight (28) day period begins when any person begins
Dispersed Camping. The fifteen (15) day limit may be reached either through a
consecutive occupancy or separate occupancies totaling fifteen (15) days within
a twenty-eight (28) consecutive day period. (2021-1187-O, 8-17-2021)
5-5-4: REMOVAL OF UNAUTHORIZED CAMPSITES:
   A.   Upon discovery of an Unauthorized Campsite the Washington County
Sheriff’s Office may immediately remove the campsite if:
      1.   After reasonable notice, the individual or individuals refuse to
remove their personal property from the premises;
      2.   The personal property reasonably appears to be abandoned or
unclaimed;
      3.   The personal property is contraband;
      4.   There is probable cause for law enforcement officials to believe
that illegal activities other than camping are occurring at the campsite; or,
      5.   The personal property presents immediate danger to human life,
health, or safety including, but not limited to, presenting possible
contamination of public or private property by unsanitary and/or hazardous
materials. (2021-1187-O, 8-17-2021)
5-5-5: ABANDONED PROPERTY:
Personal property left unattended while engaged in Dispersed Camping for more
than seventy-two (72) hours may be considered abandoned and disposed of by the
Washington County Sheriff’s Office. Upon removal of a campsite, all litter,
including items having no apparent utility or monetary value and items in an
unsanitary condition, may be immediately discarded or otherwise disposed. All
other Personal Property shall be gathered, retained, and released, with notice
being provided to the property owner, in accordance with Utah Code Title 24,
the Forfeiture and Disposition of Property Act, Utah Code Title 77, Chapter
24A, Lost or Mislaid Personal Property, and relevant Washington County Sheriff
policy. (2021-1187-O, 8-17-2021)
5-5-6: NO CAMPING NEAR LIVESTOCK WATERING POINTS AND STRUCTURES:
Camping is prohibited within two hundred (200) feet of any Livestock Watering
Points or Structures. (2021-1187-O, 8-17-2021)
5-5-7: FIRE RESTRICTIONS:
All persons engaged in Dispersed Camping within unincorporated Washington
County or Public Land must abide by all local and State fire restrictions. Any
person in violation of the current Fire Restrictions are subject to all
applicable penalties. (2021-1187-O, 8-17-2021)
5-5-8: ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   Chapter Violation: Any violation of this Chapter constitutes an
Infraction consistent with Title 1 Chapter 4 of the Washington County Code and
carries a three hundred ($300) dollar fine.
   B.   Other Violations: Any person engaged in Dispersed Camping in the
unincorporated area of Washington County or Public Land shall comply with all
other applicable County, State, and Federal statutes. (2021-1187-O, 8-17-2021)

Notes
1 1. UCA § 41-22-2 (1953, as amended)
6-1-2: TRUCK AND OTHER TRAFFIC ON KOLOB MOUNTAIN ROAD:
   A.   Statutory Authority: The statutory authority for enacting this section
is Utah Code Annotated sections 17-53-223 and 72-7-408, as amended.
   B.   Purpose Of Provisions: The purpose of this section is to protect
highway foundation, surfaces, and structures on Kolob Mountain Road (aka Kolob
Terrace Road) from damage and deterioration caused by climatic conditions by
restricting the use of certain vehicles during certain times of the year. The
National Park Service closes the road to vehicle traffic from fall to spring
due to weather conditions. The closure begins at Maloney Hill about one mile
from Hop Valley Trailhead. After the road opens, moisture from melting ice and
snow has accumulated under the road surface making it prone to edge failure,
surface damage, sinkage, and other failures. Preventing stress from heavy
vehicles by restricting use on the roadway minimizes road damage and failure
until the subsurface of the road hardens and stabilizes. These regulations do
not apply to National Park Service roadways.
   C.   Prohibition Of Certain Truck Traffic On Kolob Mountain Road: Prohibited
vehicles, dump trucks, cement trucks, and truck tractors carrying or towing
either trailers or semitrailers are prohibited on Kolob Mountain Road from
March 1 to June 30 of each year. Farm trucks, farm tractors, fuel trucks, and
other overweight vehicles must be issued a permit by the County Public Works
Department, after completion of an application and payment of a fee, to access
Kolob Mountain Road during the prohibited dates. Permits will not be issued
until the road is inspected by the Public Works Department and determined to be
traffic-worthy. Vehicles transporting live farm animals only are exempt from
the permit requirements, and date and weight prohibitions, in this paragraph.
   D.   Signs To Be Posted: The Road Department shall erect signs warning of
the road restrictions for the portion of Kolob Mountain Road affected by this
section.
   E.   Permit Application: The County Public Works Department may, upon
receipt of an application and good cause shown and upon payment of a fee, issue
a permit. The County Public Works Department may deny or issue a permit under
this section to protect the highway foundation, surfaces and structures on
Kolob Mountain Road from undue damage by one or more of the following:
      1.   Limiting the number of trips the vehicle may make;
      2.   Establishing time limits within which the vehicle may operate or
move on Kolob Mountain Road;
      3.   Requiring security in the form of a cash escrow or cash bond in
addition to the permit to compensate for any potential damage by the vehicle to
the highway; and
      4.   Otherwise limiting the conditions of operation or movement of the
vehicle.
   F.   Designation of Kolob Mountain Road as Open to Snow Machines, Sleds,
Snowmobiles:
      1.   During the National Park Service closure of Kolob Mountain Road,
within the unincorporated area of Washington County, the road is designated as
open for snow machine, sled, or snowmobile use. The official road closure
period is defined as when the road has been officially closed for the season to
conventional motor vehicle traffic due to snow. This designation does not
include any road under the jurisdiction of the U.S. Forest Service, or roads on
private property unless such use is otherwise permitted, or those roads are
part of the county road system.
      2.   When crossing another street or highway, the operator shall come to
a complete stop before crossing, proceed only after yielding the right of way
to oncoming traffic, and proceed by crossing at a right angle.
      3.   Loading or unloading a snow machine, sled, or snowmobile from a
vehicle or trailer shall be done safely and at the nearest practical point of
operation.
      4.   When directed during an emergency by a peace officer or other public
authority, a snow machine, sled, or snowmobile may be used in locations where
the operation of a conventional motor vehicle is impractical.
   G.   Penalty: Any person who violates any restriction imposed by this
section is guilty of a Class B misdemeanor and, upon conviction, subject to
penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this Code, and may be ordered to pay restitution for any road damage
caused by violating this section. (Ord. 2017-1084-O, 4-18-2017; amd. Ord. 2024-
1248-O, 1-16-2024; Ord. 2024-1260-O, 5-21-2024)
6-1-3: OFF HIGHWAY VEHICLES (OHV; ATV; ALL TERRAIN VEHICLES):
   A.   Registration Of Off Highway Vehicle: Unless exempted under section 41-
22-9 of the Utah Code, a person may not operate or transport and an owner may
not give another person permission to operate or transport, any off highway
vehicle on any public land, trail, street, or highway within the unincorporated
area of Washington County unless the off highway vehicle has been registered in
accordance with the requirements of title 41, chapter 22 of the Utah code for
the current year.
   B.   Equipment Requirements: All off highway vehicles, as defined herein,
shall be equipped with:
      1.   Brakes adequate to control the movement of and to stop and hold the
vehicle under normal operating conditions; and
      2.   Headlights and taillights when operated between sunset and sunrise;
and
      3.   A noise control device and a spark arrestor device.
      An off highway implement of husbandry used only in agricultural
operations and not operated on a highway, is exempt from the provisions of this
subsection.
   C.   Protective Headgear:
      1.   A person under the age of 18 may not operate or ride on an all-
terrain type I vehicle or motorcycle on any public land, trail, street, or
highway within the unincorporated area of Washington County unless the person
is wearing properly fitted and fastened, United States department of
transportation safety rated protective headgear designed for motorized vehicle
use.
      2.   The owner of an off highway vehicle or any other person may not give
permission to a person who is under the age of 18 years to operate or ride on
an off highway vehicle in violation of this subsection.
      3.   An operator and passengers of off highway implements of husbandry
operated in the manner prescribed by Utah Code Annotated sections 41-22-5.5(3)
and (4) (1953, as amended) are exempt from the requirements of this subsection.
      4.   Any person convicted of a violation of this subsection is guilty of
an infraction and shall be fined not more than fifty dollars ($50.00) per
offense.
   D.   Restrictions On Privately Owned Lands:
      1.   No person shall operate or accompany a person operating an off
highway vehicle upon privately owned land of any other person, firm or
corporation without permission from the owner or person in charge.
      2.   It shall be unlawful for any person operating or accompanying a
person operating an off highway vehicle to refuse to immediately leave private
land upon request of the owner or person in charge of such land.
      3.   Subsections C.1. and C.2. of this section shall not apply to county
roadways established by prescriptive use or easements across privately owned
land.
      4.   No person operating or accompanying a person operating an off
highway vehicle shall obstruct any entrance or exit to private property without
the owner's permission.
      5.   It shall be unlawful for any person to tear down, mutilate, or
destroy any sign, signboards, or other notice which regulates trespassing for
purposes of operating an off highway vehicle on privately owned land, or to
tear down, deface, or destroy any fence or other enclosure or any gate or bars
belonging to any such fence or enclosure.
   E.   Prohibited Uses: No person may operate an off highway vehicle in
connection with acts of vandalism, harassment of wildlife or domestic animals,
burglaries or other crimes, or damage to the environment which includes
excessive pollution of air, water, or land, abuse of the watershed, impairment
of plant or animal life, or excessive mechanical noise.
   F.   Supervision, Safety Certificate Or Driver's License Required:
      1.   A person may not operate and an owner may not give that person
permission to operate an off highway vehicle on any public land, trail, street
or highway within the unincorporated area of Washington County unless the
person:
         a.   Is under the direct supervision of a certified off highway
vehicle safety instructor during a scheduled safety course,
         b.   A person may not operate an off highway vehicle except in
accordance with State law, title 41 section 22, including:
         (1)   Has in his possession the appropriate safety certificate issued
by the state of Utah, and
         (2)   If under eighteen (18) years of age, is under the direct
supervision of a person who is at least eighteen (18) years of age if operating
on a public highway that is:
            (A)   Open to motor vehicles; and
            (B)   Not exclusively reserved for off highway vehicle use, or
         c.   Has in his immediate possession of valid motor vehicle operator's
license.
         d.   "Direct supervision" means oversight at a distance:
         (1)   Of no more than three hundred feet (300'); and
         (2)   Within which:
            (A)   Visual contact is maintained; and
            (B)   Advice and assistance can be given and received.
      2.   Penalties:
         a.   Any person convicted of a violation of this subsection is guilty
of an infraction and shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00)
per offense.
         b.   It is a defense to a charge under this subsection, if the person
charged produces in court a license or an appropriate safety certificate that
was:
         (1)   Valid at the time of the citation or arrest; and
         (2)   Issued to the person operating the off highway vehicle.
      3.   The requirements of this subsection do not apply to an operator of
an off highway implement of husbandry.
   G.   Operation By Persons Under Eight (8) Years Of Age Prohibited:
      1.   Persons Under Age Eight (8): Except as provided in section 41-22-29
(3) of the Utah code, a person under the age of eight (8)may not operate and an
owner may not give another person who is under the age of eight (8) permission
to operate an off highway vehicle on any public land, trail, street, or highway
within the unincorporated area of Washington County.
      2.   Violation: Any person convicted of a violation of this section is
guilty of an infraction and shall be fined not more than fifty dollars ($50.00)
per offense.
   H.   Designation Of Roads Open To Off Highway Vehicle Use:
      1.   Within the unincorporated area of Washington County, all county
roads, except roads along, across, or within the boundaries of an interstate
freeway or limited access highway, are designated as open for general off
highway vehicle use. This designation does not include any road within and
under the jurisdiction of the U.S. Forest Service, unless the road is a claimed
R.S. 2477 road, or a county roadway established by prescriptive use or
easements across privately owned land.
      2.   Subsection H(1) of this section does not apply to off highway
implements of husbandry used in accordance with Utah Code Annotated section 41-
22-5.5 (1953, as amended).
   I.   Operation Of Vehicles On Highways: No person may operate an off highway
vehicle upon any street or highway not designated as open to off highway
vehicle use, except:
      1.   When crossing a street or highway and the operator comes to a
complete stop before crossing, proceeds only after yielding the right of way to
oncoming traffic, and crosses at a right angle;
      2.   When loading or unloading an off highway vehicle from a vehicle or
trailer, which shall be done with due regard for safety, and at the nearest
practical point of operation;
      3.   When an emergency exists, during any period of time and at those
locations when the operation of conventional motor vehicles is impractical or
when the operation is directed by a peace officer or other public authority.
   J.   Speed/Regulations: Any person operating an off highway vehicle is
subject to the provisions of title 41, chapter 6a of the Utah code, unless
specifically excluded.
   K.   Penalties For Violation: Unless otherwise specified in this section,
any violation of the terms of this section shall be punishable as a class C
misdemeanor. (Ord. 2008-967-O, 11-3-2008; amd. Ord. 2024-1248-O, 1-16-2024;
Ord. 2024-1260-O, 5-21-2024)
TITLE 7
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
CHAPTER 1
ENCROACHMENTS AND UTILITY CONSTRUCTION
SECTION:
7-1-1: Permit And Approval Required
7-1-2: Plan Presented
7-1-3: Denial Of Request

7-1-1: PERMIT AND APPROVAL REQUIRED:
   A.   Access: It shall be unlawful for any person to construct a new access
upon any county right of way within the county, without first obtaining a
permit and approval from the board of county commissioners.
   B.   Improvements: It shall be unlawful for any person to place any power
line, fence, barrier, water line, sewage line or other improvements upon any
county right of way, including any claimed R.S. 2477 right of way, without
first obtaining a permit agreement with the county commissioners.
(Ord. 282, 12-20-1976; amd. Ord. 2022-1223-O, 12-20-2022)
7-1-2: PLAN PRESENTED:
Before any permit shall be issued for any encroachment upon any county right of
way, the party requesting the permit must first present a plan indicating where
the encroachment will be and the method of construction. (Ord. 282, 12-20-1976)
7-1-3: DENIAL OF REQUEST:
Any request for a permit may be denied if said request does not meet all
requirements of the board of county commissioners, and if the board of county
commissioners shall deem that said encroachment will not be in the best
interest, or be in the health, safety or welfare of the residents of the
county. (Ord. 282, 12-20-1976)
7-1-4: COST FOR REPLACEMENT; BOND:
Upon application for a permit, said application shall set forth the cost to be
incurred for replacing the right of way back to its original condition and a
bond posted in the amount approved and required by the board of county
commissioners. (Ord. 282, 12-20-1976)
7-1-5: PENALTY:
   A.   Criminal: Any person who violates or encroaches upon county right of
way without first obtaining the permit as required by this chapter shall be
guilty of a class B misdemeanor and, upon conviction, subject to penalty as
provided in section
1-4-1 of this code.
   B.   Civil: In the event any person violates this chapter, in addition to
all criminal remedies, the board of county commissioners may request the county
attorney to enjoin any encroachment upon the county right of way and/or file
suit for damages related to trespass and any damage to the county right of way
caused by violating this chapter. In the event the county is successful, the
party is liable for all costs incurred by the county, including costs of court
and reasonable attorney fees. (Ord. 282, 12-20-1976; amd. 2004 Code)
7-1-6: MEMBERSHIP:
The chairperson of the HCAC will be determined by the committee members on an
annual basis. The HCAC will include:
   A.   A representative from the Utah Division of Wildlife Resources (UDWR),
nominated to the County Commission by the UDWR,
   B.   A representative from the U.S. Bureau of Land Management (BLM),
nominated to the County Commission by the BLM,
   C.   A representative from the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS),
nominated to the County Commission by the USFWS,
   D.   A representative from an environmental organization, appointed by the
County Commission,
   E.   A representative of local governments, designated by the Washington
County Mayors' Association,
   F.   A representative of local development interests, designated by the
County Commission,
   G.   A citizen at large, nominated to the County Commission by the
municipality with the largest population that is participating in the HCP, and
   H.   A citizen at large, appointed by the County Commission. (Ord. 2021-
1178-O, 6-1-2021)
7-1-7: LENGTH OF TERMS:
The three agency representatives will serve at the will of their respective
agencies. Of the remaining non-agency representatives, terms will comply with
the requirements of the HCP. (Ord. 2021-1178-O, 6-1-2021)
CHAPTER 2
RECREATION IN THE RED CLIFFS DESERT RESERVE
SECTION:
7-2-1: Statutory Authority
7-2-2: Purpose
7-2-3: Findings
7-2-4: Definitions
7-2-5: Trail Use
7-2-6: Geocaches And Letterboxes
7-2-7: Rock Climbing And Rappelling
7-2-8: Camping
7-2-9: Fires
7-2-10: Pets
7-2-11: Prohibited Activities
7-2-12: Environmental Protection
7-2-13: Motor Vehicle Use
7-2-14: Reclamation Costs
7-2-15: Penalties
7-2-16: Enforcement
7-2-1: STATUTORY AUTHORITY:
The statutory authority for passing this chapter is derived from Utah Code
Annotated, section 17-53-223 (1953, as amended). (Ord. 2008-959-O, 4-1-2008)
7-2-2: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to amend and supersede title 6, chapter 2, "Off
Road Motor Vehicle Limitations Within Red Cliffs Desert Reserve", of this code
and to amend and supersede Washington County ordinance 2007-949-O, which
established the rules and regulations for recreation in the Red Cliffs Desert
Reserve ("ordinance"), hereinafter collectively referred to as "reserve rules",
to include the possibility of assessing reclamation costs for terrain damaged
by the prohibited off road use of a motor vehicle as set forth below. (Ord.
2008-959-O, 4-1-2008)
7-2-3: FINDINGS:
   A.   The Washington County habitat conservation plan implementation
agreement ("agreement") was signed on February 26, 1996.
   B.   Washington County is a signatory to the agreement, committing the
county to certain obligations and responsibilities, including furthering the
purposes of and assuring compliance with the terms of the agreement, and
complying with and enforcing the conditions of the incidental take permit.
   C.   The HCP generally guides the types and locations of recreational uses
allowed within the reserve.
   D.   The Washington County public use plan, adopted by the Washington County
commission in 2000 as an extension of the HCP, specifically designated trails
and further defined restrictions on recreational uses in the reserve, balancing
recreational access with protection of critical habitat for the desert
tortoise.
   E.   Failure to follow reasonable rules established to protect fragile
Mojave Desert habitat can cause irreparable harm to the habitat and can result
in the unauthorized take of a federally protected species.
   F.   It is in the best interest of the public and the citizens of Washington
County that the proposed changes to this chapter be approved in order that the
reserve rules be clearly established and enforceable. (Ord. 2008-959-O, 4-1-
2008)
7-2-4: DEFINITIONS:
NATURAL RESOURCES: All flora and fauna and the physical factors upon which they
depend including the air, water, soil, and minerals.
NONMOTORIZED VEHICLE: Any human powered mechanical device used for
transportation.
PERSON: Any individual, partnership, corporation, association, governmental
entity, agency, or public or private organization of any character.
PET: Any animal that is tamed and domesticated and kept as a companion.
POLLUTANT: Any substance, liquid, gas or solid, which could cause contamination
of any air, land, or water so as to create or cause a nuisance or render
unclean or noxious to public health, welfare or to wildlife.
RESTRICTED ACTIVITY: Uses not otherwise permitted by this chapter, permitted
uses in unauthorized areas, and permitted uses temporarily restricted in
authorized areas for reserve management purposes, regardless of whether the
restriction is posted or not.
ROAD OR ROADWAY: A linear feature designated for vehicle use.
TRAIL: A linear feature, natural or paved surface, designated for nonmotorized
vehicle use.
TRAILHEAD: An area designated for vehicle parking that may contain such
amenities as restrooms, an information kiosk, trash receptacles, and picnic
tables.
USER OR USERS: Individuals engaged in lawful recreation pursuits within the
reserve.
VEHICLE OR MOTOR VEHICLE: Any motorized vehicle or trailer designed to travel
over land including, but not limited to, cars, trucks, heavy machinery,
motorized golf carts, motorcycles, dirt bikes, off highway vehicles (OHVs) and
all-terrain vehicles (ATVs).
WASTEWATER: Any water carrying wastes that are a mixture of water and dissolved
or suspended solids, such as grey or black water, but does not include water
from natural runoff or irrigation water. (Ord. 2008-959-O, 4-1-2008)
7-2-5: TRAIL USE:
   A.   Allowed Uses: Permitted trail uses are hiking, trail running, mountain
biking, horseback riding, dog walking, picnicking, wildlife viewing,
photography, and orienteering, unless otherwise posted. All other uses are
prohibited.
   B.   Lowland Zone: Users shall stay on marked, designated trails within the
lowland zone of the reserve, except for licensed hunters during official
seasons in accordance with state and local laws.
   C.   Upland Zone: Hikers and equestrians are permitted to responsibly travel
off trail in the upland zone unless otherwise posted. Bicycles shall travel on
marked, signed, designated trails in all zones.
   D.   Creation Or Construction Of Unauthorized Trails: The creation or
construction of trails, by any means, including, but not limited to, tools or
trail markers, is prohibited within the boundaries of the reserve except by
reserve managers and their personnel, including paid staff, contractors, and
volunteers. (Ord. 2008-959-O, 4-1-2008)
7-2-6: GEOCACHES AND LETTERBOXES:
   A.   Approval Required: All geocaches and letterboxes located or proposed to
be located within the boundaries of the Red Cliffs Desert Reserve shall have
written approval from either the Washington County HCP administration, Snow
Canyon state park manager, or applicable reserve manager prior to placement.
   B.   Compliance With Policies: Authorized caches and letterboxes shall be in
compliance with reserve or Snow Canyon state park official policies regarding
these activities. (Ord. 2008-959-O, 4-1-2008)
7-2-7: ROCK CLIMBING AND RAPPELLING:
   A.   Permitted Locations: Rock climbing and rappelling is allowed in the
following areas: Turtle Wall, Pioneer park, Diagonal Street Cliffs, and Snow
Canyon state park (including Chuckwalla Wall, Black Rocks, and Cougar Cliffs)
where additional rules governing climbing apply; it is prohibited in all other
areas of the reserve.
   B.   Installation Of Hardware: Except as deemed necessary by authorized SAR
and other emergency responders, the installation of any hardware for use in
rock climbing and rappelling, including, but not limited to, bolts, hangers,
chains, and webbing is prohibited except for locations where climbing and
rappelling is allowed under this section.
   C.   Snow Canyon State Park: New route construction and installation or
removal of fixed hardware in Snow Canyon state park is prohibited without prior
approval of the Snow Canyon climbing advisory team. (Ord. 2008-959-O, 4-1-2008)
7-2-8: CAMPING:
   A.   Lowland Zone: Camping is limited to designated campgrounds and
campsites.
   B.   Upland Zone: Camping is permitted within the upland zone, unless
otherwise posted, except in the Babylon/Sandstone Mountain area, where camping
is restricted to the Sand Cove primitive campground and a permit is required.
Permits shall be obtained from the HCP administration or other applicable
reserve manager.
   C.   Trailheads: Camping is prohibited at reserve trailheads.
   D.   Lands Managed By The BLM: Camping is limited to no more than seven (7)
consecutive days in any one area. Vehicle based camping is limited to within
fifty feet (50') of designated roads. Vehicles must stay on the roadway. In
addition, upland/lowland zone restrictions apply. (Ord. 2008-959-O, 4-1-2008)
7-2-9: FIRES:
   A.   Limited Use Of Fire: The lighting, maintaining, or attending of a fire
is prohibited except:
      1.   In designated camping areas when the fire is confined in a
fireplace, ring or grill provided for that purpose,
      2.   In other locations by permit, and
      3.   In stoves or lanterns using gasoline, propane, or similar fuels.
   B.   Firewood: Collecting, cutting and gathering of firewood is prohibited.
   C.   Posted Restrictions: Smoking or lighting fires is prohibited in the
reserve when such restriction is posted. (Ord. 2008-959-O, 4-1-2008)
7-2-10: PETS:
   A.   Pets On Leash: Pets are permitted on designated trails in the reserve
if on a leash and under the direct control of a person, or if the pet is a
hunting dog accompanying a licensed hunter in the act of hunting during
official seasons in accordance with state and local laws.
   B.   Posted Closures: Pets are prohibited from any trails or locations
posted closed to pets within the reserve, except for: 1) guide or service dogs
accompanying individuals with a handicap that requires the animal's assistance
or 2) hunting dogs in the act of hunting during official seasons accompanied by
a licensed hunter.
   C.   Release Of Pets And Nonnative Species: The release or attempted release
of pets and nonnative species into the reserve is prohibited. (Ord. 2008-959-O,
4-1-2008)
7-2-11: PROHIBITED ACTIVITIES:
   A.   Recreational Activities: Paintball, target shooting, base jumping,
urban mushing (or "dog scootering"), and any other recreational activity that
is inconsistent with the purposes of the reserve, is not explicitly authorized,
or damages reserve resources is prohibited.
   B.   Events Prohibited Without Permit: No person shall engage, conduct, or
participate in a commercial activity or scheduled event within the reserve
without a special recreation permit, a special use permit, or cooperative
agreement.
   C.   Restricted Activities: No person shall participate in a restricted
activity.
   D.   Explosives And Fireworks: The use or possession of explosives,
fireworks, or firecrackers, except by permit or as part of an authorized
utility project, is prohibited within the reserve.
   E.   Closures: No person shall be in a closed area which has been closed by
reserve managers to protect public safety or reserve resources. (Ord. 2008-959-
O, 4-1-2008)
7-2-12: ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION:
   A.   Damage To Reserve Resources: Disturbing, taking, removing, damaging,
defacing, destroying, injuring, or collecting, or attempting to disturb, take,
remove, damage, deface, destroy, injure, or collect any property within the
reserve is prohibited, including, but not limited to, vegetation, ruins,
wildlife, geological formations, archeological artifacts, structures, signs,
markers, or facilities, except protected wildlife may be legally taken in
accordance with state and local laws and vegetation unavoidably damaged or
destroyed as part of an approved utility project. Collections for scientific
and educational purposes may be made after obtaining appropriate federal,
state, and HCP administration permits. As used in this section, "protected
wildlife" and "take" or "taken" have the same meaning as defined in Utah code
section 23-13-2.
   B.   Garbage, Rubbish, And Hazardous Materials: Disposing of garbage and
rubbish of any kind, including hazardous materials or pollutants, other than at
points or places designated for the disposal of materials is prohibited.
   C.   Discharge Of Wastewater: Discharging wastewater of any kind is
prohibited.
   D.   Discharge Of Pool And Hot Tub Water: No pool or hot tub water shall be
discharged into the reserve at any time.
   E.   Holes, Trenches, Or Other Excavations: Digging or excavating is
prohibited, except as part of an authorized utility, fencing, road maintenance,
trail maintenance, or other project authorized by the HCP administration or
other applicable reserve manager.
   F.   Boundary Fences: Removal, relocation, alteration, modification, damage,
and destruction of a reserve boundary fence is prohibited without written
authorization from the HCP administrator. (Ord. 2008-959-O, 4-1-2008)
7-2-13: MOTOR VEHICLE USE:
   A.   Roadway And Parking Areas: Operating or parking a motor vehicle or
trailer except on roadways and trailheads developed for that use is prohibited.
   B.   Off Road Use: The operation of vehicles, including, but not limited to,
cars, trucks, heavy machinery, motorcycles, dirt bikes, and OHVs and ATVs, off
designated roads is prohibited within the boundaries of the reserve, except as
set forth in subsection 7-2-16B of this chapter. (Ord. 2008-959-O, 4-1-2008)
7-2-14: RECLAMATION COSTS:
Any person violating this chapter may be assessed the reclamation costs
incurred repairing, reseeding or reforming terrain damaged by the prohibited
off road use of a motor vehicle. (Ord. 2008-959-O, 4-1-2008)
7-2-15: PENALTIES:
A person found guilty of violating any provision of this chapter shall be
guilty of a class B misdemeanor. (Ord. 2008-959-O, 4-1-2008)
7-2-16: ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   Authorized Law Enforcement Officers: Licensed officers that have
jurisdiction within the reserve are authorized to enforce the provisions of
this chapter.
   B.   Performance Of Assigned Duties: Nothing in this chapter shall prevent
employees of the city, county, state or federal governments, emergency service
providers or approved contractors from performing their assigned duties and
using motorized vehicles as necessary. (Ord. 2008-959-O, 4-1-2008)
CHAPTER 3
COUNTY POWER TO ACQUIRE, CONSTRUCT AND CONTROL ROADS AND RIGHTS OF WAY
SECTION:
7-3-1:   County Powers And Limits
7-3-2:   Franchises Over Public Roads And Rights Of Way
7-3-3:   Restricting Use; Closing Road
7-3-4:   Closing Or Vacating An R.S. 2477 Right Of Way
7-3-5:   Obstructions Of Public Roads Or Rights Of Way
7-3-1: COUNTY POWERS AND LIMITS:
The county may purchase, acquire, design, construct, maintain, control, and
manage county roads and rights of way. The county may by ordinance vacate or
abandon all or a portion of a county road or right of way in accordance with
state law. Except as provided in Utah Code Ann. § 72-5-305, as amended, if the
county vacates all or a portion of a county road or right of way, the state’s
interest in the road or right of way also is vacated. The county may change the
name of a county road. The county may designate and maintain roads within or
extending through a city or town if the roads do not exceed three in the same
direction. The county has no responsibility to provide maintenance or services
on public roads that are not county roads, county roads under the jurisdiction
of another governmental entity or special service district, or private roads.
(Ord. 2024-1248, 1-16-2024)
7-3-2: FRANCHISES OVER PUBLIC ROADS:
   A.   The county may grant franchises along and over public roads and rights
of way for lawful purposes, and on terms, conditions, and restrictions approved
by the county legislative body. The franchise grants shall be exercised in a
manner causing the least possible obstruction and inconvenience to the public.
   B.   A franchise right of a public utility may not be impaired by the
vacation or abandonment of all or a portion of a county road.
   C.   A franchise under this section shall not be granted for a period longer
than 30 years. (Ord. 2024-1248, 1-16-2024)
7-3-3: RESTRICTING USE; CLOSING ROAD:
The county may close a road, or restrict travel, for any lawful purpose,
including construction, maintenance, or emergency. Traffic control devices
shall be utilized if found necessary. A person who fails to observe a temporary
or permanent traffic control device is guilty of a class B misdemeanor. (Ord.
2024-1248, 1-16-2024)
7-3-4: CLOSING OR VACATING AN R.S. 2477 RIGHT OF WAY:
   A.   The county may temporarily close all or a portion of an R.S. 2477 right
of way. Temporary closure is not a vacation or abandonment.
   B.   An interruption of the public’s continuous use of an R.S. 2477 right of
way once established is not a vacation or abandonment even if the interruption
is allowed to continue unabated.
   C.   The county may by ordinance permanently vacate or abandon its interest
in all or a portion of an R.S. 2477 right of way, with the interest reverting
to the state unless the state consents. The vacation or abandonment shall be
based on good cause, a finding that the public interest or any person will not
be materially injured by the vacation, and the existence of an alternative
route acceptable to the county legislative body. (Ord. 2024-1248, 1-16-2024)
7-3-5: OBSTRUCTIONS OF PUBLIC ROADS OR RIGHTS OF WAY:
   A.   Obstructing a Public Road or Right of Way: It is unlawful to park or
leave unattended construction materials, equipment, vehicles, attachments, or
trailers to transport such items in the public road or right of way or within
thirty feet of an intersection or blind curve.
   B.   Private Improvements in a Road or Right of Way: It is unlawful to place
or construct private improvements in the county road or right of way. The
county is not responsible for damage to any private improvements in the county
road or right of way. The county may cause the removal of the obstruction, and
charge the cost to the property owner or against the adjacent property as a
lien. The owner is responsible for any damage to its private property, personal
property, or vehicles, caused by the private obstruction in the county road or
right of way, including any replacement costs or rental charges. The county is
not responsible for injury or damage to property due to the removal or impound
of the item.
   C.   Damage to County: If county equipment is damaged due to a private
obstruction in the road or right of way, the owner or violator is liable to the
county for damages, and the county may charge the cost to the property owner or
against the owner or violator’s property as a lien.
   D.   Damage to Others: If the county damages private property, personal
property, or vehicles while performing county duties, it is not responsible for
the damages. The owner is responsible for any damage to its private property,
personal property, or vehicles, including any replacement costs or rental
charges. The county is not responsible for injury or damage to property due to
the removal or impound of the item. (Ord. 2024-1248, 1-16-2024)
CHAPTER 4
SNOW AND ICE REMOVAL
SECTION:
7-4-1:   Snow And Ice Removal Priorities
7-4-2:   Snow And Ice Removal On Private Roads
7-4-3:   Obstructions; Encroachments
7-4-4:   Duty Regarding Hydrants
7-4-5:   Seasonal Road Closures
7-4-6:   Penalties
7-4-1: SNOW AND ICE REMOVAL PRIORITIES:
Snow and ice removal is provided on public roadways based on numerous factors,
including: the type of road, the volume of population served, safety,
reasonable rotation of services, budget limitations, and the availability of
labor, equipment, and materials. Plowing priority is given first to arterial
and collector streets, followed by secondary and residential streets. Many
rural roads, particularly gravel, dirt, natural, or unpaved roads, cannot be
plowed, and snow and ice removal is impractical. Crew safety and potential
damage to equipment also are important factors when prioritizing snow and ice
removal on the many miles of roads in the county. (Ord. 2024-1248, 1-16-2024)
7-4-2: SNOW AND ICE REMOVAL ON PRIVATE ROADS:
It is the duty of every property owners’ association (POA), entity, or property
owner abutting the private road or gaining access via the private road, to
provide regular snow and ice removal for their property and the private roads.
The county will not provide snow or ice removal on private property or private
roads. (Ord. 2024-1248, 1-16-2024)
7-4-3: OBSTRUCTIONS; ENCROACHMENTS:
   A.   Obstructing a Public Road or Right of Way with Snow or Ice. It is
unlawful to place, push, or blow snow or ice from private property or drive
approaches onto the public road or right of way. It is unlawful to place snow
or ice removed from private property or drive approaches in a manner that
causes a hazard to vehicle or pedestrian traffic. If snow or ice is placed in a
manner that violates this provision, the county may cause the removal of the
obstruction, and charge the cost to the property owner or against the adjacent
private property as a lien.
   B.   Storage of Snow or Ice. Each property owner, occupant, lessor, lessee,
agent, entity, association, or private person shall store its snow or ice on
its property or on the property it owns and controls, including any seasonal
accumulation. No snow or ice shall be stored by others on public property, or a
public road or right of way. No snow or ice shall be stored on the property of
another without the express, written permission of the owner. The county is not
responsible for removing accumulated snow from private property or drive
approaches.
   C.   Other Obstruction of the Public Road or Right of Way. It is unlawful to
obstruct the public road or right of way with trash containers or other
personal property. All trash containers or other personal property shall be
removed from the public road or right of way and not interfere with the
county’s snow or ice removal. It is unlawful to park any construction
materials, equipment, vehicles, attachments, or trailers to transport such
items (“personal property or vehicles”) in the public road or right of way in a
manner that obstructs snow or ice removal or in a manner that fails to leave
adequate room for the passage of plows or other equipment. If the county
damages personal property or vehicles during snow or ice removal, it is not
responsible for the damages. The owner is responsible for any damage to its
personal property or vehicles, including any replacement costs or rental
charges. The county is not responsible for injury or damage to personal
property or vehicles due to the removal or impound.
   D.   Damage to County. If county equipment or property is damaged due to
private obstructions in the road or right of way, the owner or violator is
liable to the county for damages, including repair or replacement of county
equipment or property, and the county may charge the cost to the property owner
or against the adjacent private property as a lien. Any person who violates
this section shall be liable for the cost of removal and impound of the item,
including a county administrative fee of $100 for each violation.
   E.   Encroachment of the Public Road or Right of Way. Unless a current
encroachment permit is obtained for a specific permitted activity in the public
road or right of way, it is unlawful for any private person or entity to remove
snow or ice from county roadways. (Ord. 2024-1248, 1-16-2024)
7-4-4: DUTY REGARDING HYDRANTS:
Each owner, occupant, lessor, lessee, agent, entity, association, or private
person with a fire hydrant on its property, or immediately adjacent to its
property, shall mark, uncover, and remove accumulated snow or ice from the
three-foot area surrounding the fire hydrant. Fire hydrants on private roads
shall have a marker, a minimum height of six feet, that extends above the
anticipated depth of accumulated snow or ice. (Ord. 2024-1248, 1-16-2024)
7-4-5: SEASONAL ROAD CLOSURES:
   A.   Definitions:
   DIRECTOR: The Public Works Director or his designee.
   SEASONAL ROADS: Roads that are not plowed by the county during the Snow
Season are called Seasonal Roads, and include:
      1.   Private roads;
      2.   Gravel, dirt, natural, or unpaved roads;
      3.   Class D roads;
      4.   Class B roads depicted on the Winter Maintenance Road Map as not
plowed;
      5.   All other roads constructed after the passage of this chapter in the
area or vicinity of the Seasonal Roads on the Winter Maintenance Road Map.
   SEASONAL ROAD AREAS: If a new road is constructed after the passage of this
chapter in the same area or vicinity of the Seasonal Roads on the Winter
Maintenance Road Map, it also will not be plowed by the county during the Snow
Season.
   WINTER SEASON: The period of November 1st to April 15th, or the dates
directed by the Public Works Director or designee.
   WINTER MAINTENANCE ROAD MAP (“WMR MAP”): The map that designates the paved
Seasonal Roads that will be plowed by the county during the Snow Season.
   B.   Snow and Ice Removal Priorities. The Director or designee shall
determine the order, priority, and method of snow or removal on all county
roads or rights of way based on all reasonable factors and those set forth in
this chapter. Snow or ice removal by the county will not commence on a roadway
until the road is constructed and officially accepted by the county.
   C.   Unplowed Roads during the Winter Season. Seasonal Roads and Seasonal
Road Areas on the WMR Map will not be plowed or maintained by the county during
the Winter Season defined as November 1st through April 15th. If the Director
or designee determines that the Winter Season should begin earlier or extend
later due to significant weather events, it may be altered by notice on the
county website with links on the Public Works page.
   D.   Maintaining the Winter Maintenance Road Map. The Director or designee
shall maintain the WMR Map and post it on the county’s website with links on
the Public Works page. Minor updates to the WMR Map may be made by the Director
or designee. Significant updates shall be made by the county legislative body.
A determination of whether the updates are minor or significant is in the
discretion of the Director or designee.
   E.   Seasonal Road Access. By this chapter, any lot, parcel, or development
that obtains access by a Seasonal Road, or that is in a Seasonal Road Area as
set forth on the WMP Map, is on notice that the lot or parcel is accessed by
roads that will not be plowed by the county. The county also may require
Seasonal Road restriction language on any building permit, plat, or by a
recorded deed restriction to the county’s satisfaction, that it will not plow
the public or private access roads to the lot, parcel, or development. It is
the owner, builder, and developer’s responsibility to familiarize themselves
with this chapter and the access limitations to the lot, parcel, or
development.
   F.   Interlocal Cooperation Agreements. The Director or designee shall have
the authority to negotiate interlocal cooperation agreements with other public
entities for the repair, maintenance, or snow removal on public roads or rights
of way, and have such agreements approved and executed in accordance with state
law. (Ord. 2024-1248, 1-16-2024)
7-4-6: PENALTIES:
In addition to the other liens and penalties herein, a person who violates any
provision of this chapter is guilty of a class C misdemeanor. (Ord. 2024-1248,
1-16-2024)
TITLE 8
TAXATION AND FINANCE
CHAPTER 1
REAL PROPERTY TAX SALE PROCEDURES
SECTION:
8-1-1: Statutory Authority
8-1-2: Purpose Of Provisions
8-1-3: Location Of Tax Sale
8-1-4: Administrative Fee
8-1-5: Redemption
8-1-6: Combining Parcels
8-1-7: Withdrawn Properties
8-1-8: Bidding
8-1-9: Payment
8-1-10: Final Sale
8-1-11: Excess Payments
8-1-12: Tax Deed
8-1-13: Contesting Bids And Sales
8-1-14: Disclaimer On Property Sold
8-1-15: Governing Law
8-1-1: STATUTORY AUTHORITY:
The statutory authority for enacting this chapter is Utah Code Annotated
sections 17-53-223 and 59-2-1351.1(2)(b), as amended. (Ord. 2005-885-O, 8-23-
2005)
8-1-2: PURPOSE OF PROVISIONS:
The purpose of these provisions is to establish procedures for the sale of
delinquent property that best protects the financial interest of the delinquent
property owner and meets the needs of Washington County to collect delinquent
property taxes. (Ord. 2005-885-O, 8-23-2005)
8-1-3: LOCATION OF TAX SALE:
The tax sale shall occur in a location, or by public online auction, specified
by the clerk/auditor under terms and conditions that protect the parties and
the public. If the tax sale occurs in person, the procedures for an in person
auction shall be followed. If the tax sale occurs by online auction, the
procedures for the online auction shall be followed. (Ord. 2005-885-O, 8-23-
2005; amd. Ord. 2023-1232-O, 4-18-2023)
8-1-4: ADMINISTRATIVE FEE:
An administrative fee for each delinquent property shall be assessed for
administrative costs. The administrative fee shall include the cost of
preparing a tax deed, a record deed, title search, mailing, advertising and
phone expenses. The administrative fee shall be added to the taxes, penalties
and interest outstanding on each delinquent property. The clerk/auditor will
annually determine the amount of the administrative fee. All auction fees shall
be paid by the buyer. (Ord. 2005-885-O, 8-23-2005; amd. Ord. 2023-1232-O, 4-18-
2023)
8-1-5: REDEMPTION:
Until the moment the sale begins, the owner of record or lienholder of record
of delinquent property may redeem the property by payment in full of the
delinquent taxes, penalties, interest and administrative fee. Payment must be
in cash or certified funds, such as a cashier's check or money order. (Ord.
2005-885-O, 8-23-2005)
8-1-6: COMBINING PARCELS:
The clerk/auditor may combine for sale two (2) or more contiguous parcels owned
by the same party when:
   A.   The parcels are a single economic unit or functional unit;
   B.   The combined sale will best protect the financial interests of the
delinquent property owner; and
   C.   Separate sales will reduce the economic value of the unit. (Ord. 2005-
885-O, 8-23-2005)
8-1-7: WITHDRAWN PROPERTIES:
   A.   The clerk/auditor may withdraw the following property from the tax
sale:
      1.   Any property having a title deficiency;
      2.   Any property having a deficient description;
      3.   Any property having any other similar deficiency; or
      4.   Any property which the clerk/auditor determines should be withdrawn
in the best interest of the public.
   B.   The clerk/auditor may recertify to a subsequent sale any withdrawn
property if the cause of the original withdrawal has been remedied. (Ord. 2005-
885-O, 8-23-2005)
8-1-8: BIDDING:
   A.   Each person desiring to bid must preregister with the Washington County
clerk/auditor's office beginning at eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. on the morning of
the tax sale by filling out a "bidder registration" form, or in accordance with
the online auction provider's terms and conditions. For the in person auction,
Tthe clerk/auditor will issue each bidder a bidder number. No individual may
bid without a bidder number. For the online auction, each bidder shall comply
with the online auction provider's requirements for bidders.
   B.   The clerk/auditor or the online auction provider will conduct the
bidding. The minimum acceptable bid is the sum of taxes, penalties, interest
and administrative fee owed on the property. No property will be sold for less
than the minimum acceptable bid. The clerk/auditor or the online auction
provider will determine bid increments. For an online auction a buyer's fee
also will be added to the sale price.
   C.   Each parcel will be sold to the highest bidder, except all bids shall
be considered conditional until accepted by the County Commission.
   D.   For an in person auction, Aat the apparent conclusion of bidding for
each parcel, the clerk/auditor will identify the highest bidder and the bid
amount. Before closing the bidding, the clerk/auditor will call for any further
bids. After it is apparent that there are no further bids, the clerk/auditor
will close the bidding and award the parcel to the highest bidder.
   E.   Bids may not be withdrawn. Washington County may enforce the terms of
the bid by obtaining a judgment against the bidder in the amount of the bid,
plus interest and attorney fees.
   F.   There will be no preferential sales or bids.
   G.   Any property offered for sale for which there is no purchaser will be
struck off to the county pursuant to Utah law. (Ord. 2005-885-O, 8-23-2005;
amd. Ord. 2023-1232-O, 4-18-2023)
8-1-9: PAYMENT:
   A.   Successful bidders at an in person auction must tender full payment to
the Washington County treasurer by four o'clock (4:00) P.M. of the business day
immediately following the day of the tax sale. A partial payment of no less
than twenty five percent (25%) of the bid amount must be paid to the treasurer
on the day of the sale. Successful bidders at an online auction must tender
full payment in accordance with the online auction provider's terms and
conditions.
   B.   Payments for an in person auction must be cash, wire transfer, or
certified funds made payable to the "Washington County treasurer" in the exact
amount of the bid. Payments for an online auction must be in accordance with
the online auction provider's terms and conditions.
   C.   If a successful bidder fails to satisfy the requirements of this
section, the clerk/auditor or the online auction provider may contact the next
highest bidder and offer the property to that bidder for the amount of the
bidder's highest bid. If this bidder declines to accept the offer, the clerk/
auditor or the online auction provider may then contact the next highest
bidder. (Ord. 2012-1018-O, 5-1-2012; amd. Ord. 2023-1232-O, 4-18-2023)
8-1-10: FINAL SALE:
Sales are final only after approval by the board of county commissioners during
a regularly scheduled meeting no earlier than ten (10) days after the tax sale.
(Ord. 2005-885-O, 8-23-2005)
8-1-11: EXCESS PAYMENTS:
The following procedure applies when a purchase amount received is in excess of
the taxes, interest, penalties and administrative fee:
   A.   The county shall notify those with a recorded interest in the property
of the excess funds. Notification shall be made by first class and/or certified
mail. For purposes of this section, those with a recorded interest in the
property are those previously identified as having a recorded interest in the
property and previously notified of the tax sale by the clerk/auditor. The
recipients shall have ninety (90) days from the date the notice is mailed to
submit a written claim for a specified amount of the excess proceeds and a
brief legal justification for the claim.
   B.   If only one claim is submitted within the specified time limit, the
county shall pay the amount of the claim or all of the excess funds, whichever
is less, to the claimant.
   C.   If multiple claims are submitted within the specified time limit and
the total amount claimed by all claimants is less than or equal to the total
amount of the excess funds, then the county shall pay the excess funds to the
claimants.
   D.   If no claims are submitted within the specified time limit or if the
claims submitted are less than the total excess funds, then the county shall
deposit the remaining excess funds with the state of Utah as unclaimed property
in the name of the previous recorded owner of record.
   E.   If multiple claims are submitted within the specified time limit and
the total amount claimed by all claimants is greater than the excess proceeds,
then the county shall notify each claimant of the other claims and include the
name, contact information, amount of claim, and brief description of the legal
justification for each claimant. The claimants shall be invited to resolve how
the excess funds should be divided amongst themselves. A time limit of ninety
(90) days shall be placed on these negotiations. If a resolution is reached and
the county is notified of the resolution by all of the claimants in writing,
then the county shall pay the excess funds to the claimants according to the
resolution.
   F.   If there are inadequate funds and the multiple claimants are unable to
reach an agreement as to the distribution of the excess funds, then the county
shall file an action with the 5th district court of Utah which will allow the
claimants to plead their case to the court. The excess funds shall be
distributed as ordered by the court. Alternatively, the county may make an
independent determination of how the excess funds should be distributed if the
county determines that it is clear which claimants have priority in their
claims.
   G.   The county shall determine appropriate fees to cover its costs in
distributing excess funds and this fee, as established by the Washington County
commission, shall be deducted from the funds prior to their being paid out.
   H.   The county may set a minimum amount before the above provisions apply.
If the excess funds are less than the minimum amount, then the county may
notify only the previous owner of record of the property and pay the funds to
that owner if a claim for the funds is made. If no claim is made, the funds
shall be deposited with the state of Utah as unclaimed property in the name of
the previous owner of record. (Ord. 2012-1020-O, 6-19-2012)
8-1-12: TAX DEED:
After the sales are approved by the board of county commissioners, the clerk/
auditor will issue a tax deed pursuant to Utah law. The county clerk/auditor
will only issue the buyer one deed on each property sold. (Ord. 2005-885-O, 8-
23-2005)
8-1-13: CONTESTING BIDS AND SALES:
Any person contesting any action taken in conjunction with the tax sale shall
file a written protest with the Washington County commission within ten (10)
days after the date of the tax sale. The commission will review the submissions
and render a decision based upon that information. The commission will not
grant a hearing to those contesting a bid. (Ord. 2005-885-O, 8-23-2005)
8-1-14: DISCLAIMER ON PROPERTY SOLD:
   A.   All properties sold during the tax sale shall be conveyed by a tax
deed. A tax deed is not a warranty deed and the county makes no representations
as to the title conveyed nor the purchaser's right of possession of the
property. For example, certain entities or persons, including, but not limited
to, agencies or divisions of both the state and federal government, may have
certain rights of redemption. Therefore, buyers of properties at the tax sale
make any purchase at their own risk.
   B.   Similarly, the county makes no warranties or representations as to
whether the property purchased is suitable for building or developing, nor does
the county make any representations that the property complies with applicable
zoning regulations. (Ord. 2005-885-O, 8-23-2005)
8-1-15: GOVERNING LAW:
The collection of delinquent taxes, including tax sales, is governed by Utah
Code Annotated title 59, chapter 2. In the event of a conflict between this
chapter and the laws of the state of Utah, the laws of the state of Utah
prevail. (Ord. 2005-885-O, 8-23-2005)
CHAPTER 2
PROPERTY TAX EXEMPTIONS
SECTION:
8-2-1: Authority And Purpose
8-2-2: Procedure
8-2-3: Criteria
8-2-4: Grandfather Provision
8-2-5: Conflict
8-2-6: Statutes Incorporated
8-2-1: AUTHORITY AND PURPOSE:
The Utah constitution, article XIII, section 3 and Utah Code Annotated 59-2-102
and 59-2-103(2) (1953, as amended) provide that a residential exemption from
property tax of forty five percent (45%) is available for "primary residences".
The Utah legislature enacted Utah Code Annotated section 59-2-103.5 (2002)
establishing procedures for property owners to obtain a tax exemption for
residential property and authorizing the county legislative body to adopt an
ordinance for the allowance of a residential property tax exemption. (Ord.
2013-1030-O, 7-2-2013)
8-2-2: PROCEDURE:
   A.   No later than sixty (60) days after either a change in ownership or a
change in use of the residence, all owners of residential property as defined
in Utah Code Annotated 59-2-102 (1953, as amended) shall sign and submit a form
supplied by the county, to the board of equalization in care of the Washington
County assessor, stating the current use of the property as primary or
secondary. The application shall include the following information:
      1.   The owner of record of the property;
      2.   Property parcel number;
      3.   Location of the property (address);
      4.   Name of the applicant;
      5.   Basis of the applicant's knowledge of the use of the property;
      6.   Description of the use of the property;
      7.   Evidence of domicile of the inhabitant(s) of the property; and
      8.   Signature(s) of all owners of the property and a certification that
the property is residential property.
   B.   In order to be considered for a primary residential exemption for the
current tax year, the property must be used in the current calendar year as a
primary residence for at least one hundred eighty three (183) consecutive days.
   C.   Applications seeking the exemption for the current tax year and filed
after September 15 must pay an administrative fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) to
the office of the county assessor.
   D.   Except for those properties receiving a residential exemption, which
are required to file an application each year, the county board of equalization
may require an owner of the residential property to file the application
described in subsection A of this section only if:
      1.   That residential property was ineligible for the primary residence
tax exemption during the calendar year immediately preceding the calendar year
for which the owner is seeking to claim the exemption; or
      2.   The ownership interest in that residential property changes; or
      3.   The county board of equalization or the county assessor determines
that there is reason to believe that the property no longer qualifies for the
residential exemption in accordance with Utah Code Annotated 59-2-103.
   E.   The county board of equalization or the county assessor may request or
collect information sufficient to verify the primary residence status of the
property to determine if the property is entitled to the residential exemption,
pursuant to the criteria set forth in the rules promulgated by the Utah state
tax commission.
   F.   If an applicant requests a property be designated as a primary
residence, the residential exemption shall not be granted without clear and
convincing evidence that the property serves as the primary residence. The
burden of proof shall remain at all times with the applicant.
   G.   After review of the applicant's application, the county assessor shall
make a preliminary determination of whether the requirements for a residential
residence exemption, outlined in Utah Code Annotated section 59-2-103.5(1),
have been met, and whether the factors or objective evidence determinative of
domicile, which are defined and outlined in section
8-2-3 of this chapter, are sufficient to approve the applicant's request. The
county assessor shall then make a recommendation to the board of equalization
for approval or denial of the applicant's request. The board of equalization
shall allow an owner a residential exemption for the residential property
described in the application, upon making a determination that the requirements
outlined in Utah Code Annotated section 59-2-103.5(1), have been met, and that
the factors or objective evidence supplied by the applicant are sufficient to
make a determination of domicile. (Ord. 2013-1030-O, 7-2-2013; amd. Ord. 2021-
1175-O, 4-20-2021)
8-2-3: CRITERIA:
   A.   Definitions:
    DOMICILE: The place where an individual has a true, fixed, permanent home
and principal establishment, and to which place the person has (whenever the
person is absent) the intention of returning. It is the place in which a person
has voluntarily fixed the habitation of the person and the person's family, not
for a mere special or temporary purpose, but with the present intention of
making a permanent home.
      1.   After domicile has been established, two (2) things are necessary to
create a new domicile: first, an abandonment of the old domicile; and second,
the intention and establishment of a new domicile.
      2.   The mere intention to abandon a domicile once established is not of
itself sufficient to create a new domicile; for before a person can be said to
have changed a person's domicile, a new domicile must be shown.
      3.   The assessor and the board of equalization may refer to the
administrative rules of the Utah state tax commission for guidance in reviewing
the factors and evidence determinative of domicile.
   PRIMARY RESIDENCE: The location where domicile has been established.
   B.   Residential Exemption: To qualify for the residential exemption, a
property need not be owner occupied. Apartments and other rental housing used
as a primary residence of the occupant(s) qualify for the residential exemption
in accordance with section
8-2-2 of this chapter. A primary residence does not include property used for
transient residential use, or condominiums used in rental pools. Only the
primary residence, which is occupied more than six (6) months out of the year,
qualifies for the residential exemption. The residential exemption is limited
to up to one acre of land per residential dwelling unit on a single property
description.
   C.   Partial Exemption For Mixed Commercial And Residential: A partial
exemption may be applied against the property taxes of mixed commercial and
residential property but it is presumed that the entire property is commercial.
This presumption may be rebutted by the filing of the application referred to
in subsection 8-2-2A of this chapter every year, which includes evidence of
domicile of each qualifying resident. The county assessor may require
additional information as necessary to make a determination of the percentage
of the property qualifying for the residential exemption.
   D.   Partial Exemption For Nursing Homes: A partial exemption may be applied
against the property taxes of qualifying nursing homes. In addition to the
information required in subsection 8-2-2A of this chapter, the application,
which must be filed every year, shall include the number of residents living at
the facility and the number that have established their primary residence at
the facility; the total square footage of the facility and the total
nonresidential square footage. The county assessor may require additional
information as necessary in order to determine the percentage of eligibility of
the property for the exemption. (Ord. 2013-1030-O, 7-2-2013)
8-2-4: GRANDFATHER PROVISION:
As of the effective date hereof, owner occupied residential property,
apartments and other rental property being used as the primary residence of the
occupants, where the property is currently listed by the county assessor as
having a residential exemption shall not be required to file an application to
continue its status. Owner occupied residential property, apartments and other
rental property being used as the primary residence of the occupants, where the
property is subsequently listed by the county assessor as having a residential
exemption and was constructed after the effective date hereof, shall be
required to file the application required by subsection 8-2-2A of this chapter.
However, should use change from primary residence, the property shall no longer
be considered exempt and an application under the provision of this chapter
shall be required. (Ord. 2013-1030-O, 7-2-2013)
8-2-5: CONFLICT:
In the event of any conflict between this chapter and state or federal law, the
provisions of the latter shall be controlling. (Ord. 2013-1030-O, 7-2-2013)
8-2-6: STATUTES INCORPORATED:
This chapter shall incorporate the provisions of the administrative rules
promulgated by the Utah state tax commission, and the criteria for determining
primary residence set forth in Utah Code Annotated 59-2-102 and 59-2-103 (1953,
as amended); and property tax standard 2.13 primary residential exemption.
(Ord. 2013-1030-O, 7-2-2013)
CHAPTER 3
SALES AND USE TAX
SECTION:
8-3-1: Title
8-3-2: Purpose
8-3-3: Sales And Use Tax
8-3-4: Penalty
8-3-1: TITLE:
This chapter shall be known as the SALES AND USE TAX ORDINANCE OF WASHINGTON
COUNTY. (Ord. 482, 1-29-1990, eff. retroactive to 1-1-1990)
8-3-2: PURPOSE:
   A.   The 48th session of the Utah legislature has authorized the counties
and municipalities of the state to enact sales and use tax ordinances imposing
a one percent (1%) tax.
   B.   It is the purpose of this chapter to conform the sales and use tax of
the municipality to the requirements of the sales and use tax act, Utah Code
Annotated title 59, chapter 12, as currently amended. (Ord. 482, 1-29-1990,
eff. retroactive to 1-1-1990)
8-3-3: SALES AND USE TAX:
   A.   Taxes Imposed:
      1.   From and after the effective date hereof, there is levied and there
shall be collected and paid a tax upon every retail sale of tangible personal
property, services and meals made within the municipality at the rate of one
percent (1%).
      2.   An excise tax is hereby imposed on the storage, use or other
consumption in this municipality of tangible personal property from any
retailer on or after the operative date hereof at the rate of one percent (1%)
of the sales price of the property.
      3.   For the purpose of this chapter, all retail sales shall be presumed
to have been consummated at the place of business delivered by the retailer or
his agent to an out of state destination or to a common carrier for delivery to
an out of state destination. In the event a retailer has no permanent place of
business, the place or places at which the retail sales are consummated shall
be as determined under the rules and regulations prescribed by and adopted by
the state tax commission. "Public utilities", as defined by Utah Code Annotated
title 54, as amended, shall not be obligated to determine the place or places
within any county or municipality where public utilities services are rendered,
but the place of sale or the sales tax revenue arising from such service
allocable to the county shall be as determined by the state tax commission
pursuant to an appropriate formula and other rules and regulations to be
prescribed and adopted by it.
   B.   Incorporation Of State Law; Exclusions From Determining Tax:
      1.   Except as hereinafter provided, and except insofar as they are
inconsistent with the provisions of the sales and use tax act, all of the
provisions of Utah Code Annotated title 59, chapter 12, as amended, and in
force and affect on the effective date hereof, insofar as they relate to sales
taxes, excepting sections 59-12-101 and 59-12-119 thereof, are hereby adopted
