and made a part of this chapter as though fully set forth herein.
      2.   Wherever, and to the extent that in Utah Code Annotated title 59,
chapter 12, the state of Utah is named or referred to as the taxing agency, the
name of this municipality shall be substituted therefore. Nothing in subsection
B of this section shall be deemed to require substitution of the name of the
municipality for the word "state" when that word is used as part of the title
of the state tax commission, or of the constitution of the state of Utah, nor
shall the name of the municipality be substituted for that of the state in any
section when the result of that substitution would require action to be taken
by or against the municipality or any agency thereof, rather than by or against
the state tax commission in performing the functions incident to the
administration or operation of this chapter.
      3.   If an annual license has been issued to a retailer under Utah Code
Annotated section 59-12-106, an additional license shall not be required by
reason of this section.
      4.   There shall be excluded from the purchase price paid or charged by
which the tax is measured:
         a.   The amount of any sales or use tax imposed by the state upon a
retailer or consumer;
         b.   The gross receipts from the sale of or the cost of storage, use
or other consumption of tangible personal property upon which a sales or use
tax has become due by reason of the sale transaction to any other municipality
and any county in the state, under the sales or use tax ordinance enacted by
that county or municipality in accordance with the sales and use tax act. (Ord.
482, 1-29-1990, eff. retroactive to 1-1-1990)
8-3-4: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed
guilty of a class B misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, subject to
penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 482, 1-29-1990, eff. retroactive to 1-1-1990; amd.
2004 Code)
CHAPTER 4
OPTIONAL COUNTY SALES AND USE TAX
SECTION:
8-4-1: Title
8-4-2: Statutory Authority
8-4-3: Purpose Of Provisions
8-4-4: Imposition Of Tax
8-4-5: Incorporation Of State Law
8-4-6: Administration, Collection And Distribution By State
8-4-7: Exemptions
8-4-1: TITLE:
This chapter shall be known as the OPTIONAL COUNTY SALES AND USE TAX. (Ord.
656, 8-25-1997, eff. 1-1-1998)
8-4-2: STATUTORY AUTHORITY:
The authority for imposing this tax is derived from Utah Code Annotated title
59, chapter 12, part 9, as amended. (Ord. 656, 8-25-1997, eff. 1-1-1998)
8-4-3: PURPOSE OF PROVISIONS:
This chapter is enacted to provide the county with a source of revenue to allow
the county to more effectively carry out its role as a political and legal
subdivision of the state. The board of county commissioners hereby directs that
the provisions hereby be interpreted and construed to accomplish this stated
purpose. (Ord. 656, 8-25-1997, eff. 1-1-1998)
8-4-4: IMPOSITION OF TAX:
In addition to all other taxes imposed, the county does hereby impose and levy
for collection a sales and use tax of one-fourth of one percent (1/4%) upon the
sales and uses described in Utah Code Annotated section 59-12-103(1), subject
to the exemptions provided for in Utah Code Annotated section 59-12-104. This
tax is imposed upon all sales and uses made in the county, including sales and
uses made within the corporate limits of the cities and towns of the county.
Provisions of this chapter shall be subject to the provisions of the sales and
use tax laws of the state to which reference is hereinafter made in this
chapter and which are hereby enacted and made a part of this chapter as though
fully set forth herein. (Ord. 656, 8-25-1997, eff. 1-1-1998)
8-4-5: INCORPORATION OF STATE LAW:
   A.   Except as hereinafter provided and except insofar as they are
inconsistent with provisions of the county option sales and use tax act, all
the provisions of Utah Code Annotated title 59, chapter 12, part 1, as amended,
in force and effect on the effective date hereof, insofar as they relate to the
tax imposed by this chapter, except sections 59-12-101 and 59-12-119 thereof,
are adopted and made a part of this chapter as though fully set forth herein.
   B.   Wherever and to the extent that in Utah Code Annotated title 59,
chapter 12, part 1, as amended, the state of Utah is named or referred to as
the taxing agency, the name of this county shall be substituted therefor.
Nothing in this subsection shall be deemed to require substitution of the name
of the county for the word "state" when that word is used as part of the title
of the state tax commission, or the constitution of the state, nor shall the
name of the county be substituted for that of the state in any section when the
result of that substitution would require action to be taken by or against the
county or any agency thereof, rather than by or against the state tax
commission in performing the functions incident to the administration or
operation of this chapter. (Ord. 656, 8-25-1997, eff. 1-1-1998)
8-4-6: ADMINISTRATION, COLLECTION AND DISTRIBUTION BY STATE:
   A.   Taxes imposed pursuant to this chapter shall be levied at the same time
and collected in the same manner as provided for in Utah Code Annotated section
59-12-201 et seq., as amended, except that the revenue derived from the tax is
not subject to the collection and distribution procedures established pursuant
to the provisions of Utah Code Annotated section 59-12-205(2), as amended.
Revenues collected pursuant to this chapter shall be distributed in accordance
with Utah Code Annotated section 59-12-902(3) and the rules adopted by the Utah
state tax commission pursuant to Utah Code Annotated section 59-12-902(3)(d).
All revenues so collected shall be revenues of either the county or of any
other county entitled to distribution of the same pursuant to the statute.
   B.   Any records, tax returns or other information of any person,
corporation, company, or other group or organization subject to the taxes
imposed by this chapter which relate to the calculation, collection or
remittance to the state tax commission of such taxes shall be subject to
review, inspection and auditing by the county.
   C.   The fee charged the county by the state tax commission under Utah Code
Annotated section 59-12-206, as amended, shall be based on the distribution
amount resulting after all the applicable distribution calculations under Utah
Code Annotated section 59-12-902(3) have been made. (Ord. 656, 8-25-1997, eff.
1-1-1998)
8-4-7: EXEMPTIONS:
The sale, storage, use or other consumption of tangible personal property which
is exempt from sale or use taxation pursuant to Utah Code Annotated section 59-
12-104 is exempt from the application of the optional county sales and use tax.
(Ord. 656, 8-25-1997, eff. 1-1-1998)
CHAPTER 5
TRANSIENT ROOM TAX
SECTION:
8-5-1: Statutory Authority
8-5-2: Purpose Of Provisions
8-5-3: Findings
8-5-4: Tax Imposed; Amount
8-5-5: Use Of Revenues
8-5-6: Penalties
8-5-7: Operative Date Of The Tax Increase
8-5-1: STATUTORY AUTHORITY:
The statutory authority for imposing this tax is derived from Utah Code
Annotated section 59-12-301 (1953, as amended). (Ord. 2007-930-O, 2-6-2007)
8-5-2: PURPOSE OF PROVISIONS:
The chapter is enacted to raise the tax on charges for the accommodations and
services described in Utah Code Annotated, section 59-12-103(1)(i) (1953, as
amended), hereinafter referred to as transient room tax ("TRT"), from three
percent (3%) to four and one-fourth percent (41/4%). (Ord. 2007-930-O, 2-6-
2007)
8-5-3: FINDINGS:
   A.   The TRT was enacted by the Washington County commission in 1972,
ordinance 252, which set the original TRT rate at one and one-half percent (11/
2%).
   B.   The TRT was increased from one and one-half percent (11/2%) to three
percent (3%) in 1983, ordinance 352.
   C.   The 2006 Utah state legislature, pursuant to the provisions of Utah
Code Annotated, section 59-12-301(1)(a)(ii) (1953, as amended), allows the
county legislative body to impose a tax on charges for the accommodations and
services as defined and set forth in Utah Code Annotated, section 59-12-103(1)
(i) (1953, as amended), i.e., amounts paid or charged for short term rental,
hotel, motel, or trailer court accommodations and services that are regularly
rented for less than thirty (30) consecutive days, at a rate of not to exceed
four and one-fourth percent (41/4%).
   D.   The St. George Lodging Association unanimously approved the proposed
increase by the Washington County commission of the TRT from three percent (3%)
to four and one-fourth percent (41/4%).
   E.   It is in the best interest of the public and the citizens of Washington
County to have the TRT rate increased from three percent(3%) to four and one-
fourth percent (41/4%). (Ord. 2007-930-O, 2-6-2007; amd. Ord. 2021-1196-O, 10-
5-2021)
8-5-4: TAX IMPOSED; AMOUNT:
   A.   The TRT rate is increased from three percent (3%) to four and one-
fourth percent (41/4%).
   B.   The TRT shall be imposed on amounts paid or charged for short term
rental, hotel, motel, or trailer court accommodations and services that are
regularly rented for less than thirty (30) consecutive days, as defined and set
forth in Utah Code Annotated, section 59-12-103(1)(i) (1953, as amended), and
as amended by the Utah state legislature. (Ord. 2007-930-O, 2-6-2007; amd. Ord.
2021-1196-O, 10-5-2021)
8-5-5: USE OF REVENUES:
The revenues received from the TRT levied by this chapter shall be used solely
for the purposes set forth in Utah Code Annotated, section 17-31-2 (1953, as
amended). (Ord. 2007-930-O, 2-6-2007)
8-5-6: PENALTIES:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed
guilty of a class B misdemeanor. (Ord. 2007-930-O, 2-6-2007)
8-5-7: OPERATIVE DATE OF THE TAX INCREASE:
The date the TRT increase shall become operative is July 1, 2007, the first day
of a calendar quarter after a ninety (90) day period beginning on the date the
Utah state tax commission receives notice meeting the requirements of Utah Code
Annotated, section 59-12-301(3)(b)(ii) (1953, as amended). (Ord. 2007-930-O, 2-
6-2007)
CHAPTER 6
TOURISM, RECREATION, CULTURAL AND CONVENTION TAX
SECTION:
8-6-1: Title
8-6-2: Statutory Authority
8-6-3: Purpose Of Provisions
8-6-4: Definitions
8-6-5: Imposition Of Tax
8-6-6: Use Of Revenues
8-6-7: Collection
8-6-8: Licensure
8-6-9: Incorporation Of State Law
8-6-10: Penalty
8-6-1: TITLE:
This chapter shall be known as the TOURISM, RECREATION, CULTURAL, AND
CONVENTION TAX OF WASHINGTON COUNTY. This chapter repeals and replaces all
other ordinances imposing a tourism, recreation, cultural and convention tax.
(Ord. 2016-1059-O, 1-19-2016)
8-6-2: STATUTORY AUTHORITY:
The statutory authority for imposing this tax is derived from Utah Code
Annotated section 59-12-601 et seq. (1953, as amended). (Ord. 2006-909-O, 5-16-
2006)
8-6-3: PURPOSE OF PROVISIONS:
This chapter is enacted to provide the county with a source of revenue
specifically for the purposes of financing, in whole or in part, the
development, operation and maintenance of tourist, recreation, cultural and
convention facilities, and the board of county commissioners hereby directs
that the provisions hereof be interpreted and construed to accomplish the
stated purpose. (Ord. 2006-909-O, 5-16-2006)
8-6-4: DEFINITIONS:
CONVENTION FACILITY: Means the same term as defined in Utah Code Annotated
section 59-12-602(5) (as amended).
CULTURAL FACILITY: Means the same term as defined in Utah Code Annotated
section 59-12-602(6) (as amended).
MOTOR VEHICLE: Means the same term as defined in Utah Code Annotated section
41-22-2(11) (as amended).
OFF-HIGHWAY VEHICLE: Means the same term as defined in Utah Code Annotated
section 41-22-2 (14) (as amended).    
RECREATION FACILITY OR TOURIST FACILITY: Means the same term as defined in Utah
Code Annotated section 59-12-602(9) (as amended).
RECREATION VEHICLE: Means the same term as defined in Utah Code Annotated
section 59-12-602 (10) (as amended).
RESTAURANT: Means the same term as defined in Utah Code Annotated section 59-
12-602 (11) (as amended).
SHORT TERM LEASE OR RENTAL: Means the same term as defined in Utah Code
Annotated section 59-12-602(12) (as amended).
(Ord. 2006-909-O, 5-16-2006; amd. Ord. 2022-1219, 10-4-2022)
8-6-5: IMPOSITION OF TAX:
There are hereby levied tourism, recreation, cultural and convention taxes as
follows:
   A.   A tax is hereby imposed on all restaurants, as defined herein, in
Washington County at the rate of one percent (1%) on all sales by the
restaurant of beverages and prepared foods.
   B.   A tax is hereby imposed on all short term leases or rentals of motor
vehicles, as defined herein, at the rate of seven percent (7%).
   C.   A tax is hereby imposed on all short term rentals of off-highway
vehicles and recreation vehicles, as defined herein, at the rate of seven
percent (7%).
(Ord. 2006-909-O, 5-16-2006; amd. Ord. 2022-1219, 10-4-2022)
8-6-6: USE OF REVENUES:
The revenues received from the tourism, recreation, cultural and convention
taxes levied by this chapter shall be used solely for the purposes of
financing, in whole or part, tourism promotion, and the development, operation,
and maintenance of tourist, recreation, cultural, and convention facilities as
defined herein. (Ord. 2006-909-O, 5-16-2006)
8-6-7: COLLECTION:
Taxes imposed under this chapter shall be levied at the same time and collected
in the same manner as provided for in the local sales and use tax act 1  except
that the revenue derived from the tax is not subject to the provisions of Utah
Code Annotated section 59-12-205(2) through (5) (1953, as amended). (Ord. 2006-
909-O, 5-16-2006)
 
Notes
1 1. UCA § 59-12-201 et seq., 1953, as amended.
8-6-8: LICENSURE:
All persons, companies, corporations or other similar persons, groups, or
organizations required under the terms of this chapter to collect the taxes
imposed herein shall obtain from the state tax commission, a tourism,
recreation, cultural or convention tax license. No additional license shall be
required if the person, company, corporation, group or organization has
obtained a license pursuant to Utah Code Annotated section 59-12-106 (1953, as
amended). (Ord. 2006-909-O, 5-16-2006)
8-6-9: INCORPORATION OF STATE LAW:
   A.   Except as hereinafter provided, and except insofar as they are
inconsistent with the provisions of the tourism, recreation, cultural and
convention facilities tax act, all of the provisions of part 1, chapter 12,
title 59, Utah Code Annotated (1953, as amended), insofar as they relate to the
tax imposed by this chapter, excepting sections 59-12-101 and 59-12-119
thereof, are adopted and made part of this chapter as though fully set forth
herein.
   B.   Wherever, and to the extent that in part 1, chapter 12, title 59, Utah
Code Annotated (1953, as amended), the state of Utah is named or referred to as
the taxing agency, the name of Washington County shall be substituted therefor.
Nothing in this subsection shall be deemed to require substitution of the name
of the county for the word "state" when that word is used as part of the title
of the state tax commission, or of the constitution of the state of Utah, nor
shall the name of the county be substituted for that of the state in any
section when the result of that substitution would require action to be taken
by or against the county or any agency thereof, rather than by or against the
state tax commission in performing the functions incident to the administration
or operation of this chapter. (Ord. 2006-909-O, 5-16-2006)
8-6-10: PENALTY:
Any person, company, corporation, or other organization subject to the terms of
this chapter that fails to obtain the required license or fails to collect the
taxes imposed by this chapter shall be guilty of a class B misdemeanor. (Ord.
2006-909-O, 5-16-2006)
CHAPTER 7
CONTRIBUTION TO CREMATION OF UNCLAIMED PERSONS AND INDIGENTS
SECTION:
8-7-1: Statutory Authority
8-7-2: Purpose Of Provisions
8-7-3: Definitions
8-7-4: When The County Is Responsible For Cremation
8-7-5: When The County May Assume Responsibility For Cremation
8-7-6: Search For Decedent’s Will, Family Or Relatives
8-7-7: Cremation Services
8-7-8: County Attorney To Authorize Cremation
8-7-9: County Attorney Immune From Liability
8-7-1: STATUTORY AUTHORITY:
The statutory authority for enacting this chapter is Utah Code Annotated
sections 17-14-2, 17-53-221, 17-53-223 and 26-4-25 (1953, as amended). (Ord.
2017-1111-O, 12-5-2017)
8-7-2: PURPOSE OF PROVISIONS:
The purpose of this chapter is to set forth Washington County's requirements
for County contribution toward the cremation of an unclaimed dead body and the
circumstances when the County will provide for cremation of the remains of an
indigent person.
Pursuant to Utah Code Annotated section 26-4-25:
Washington County shall provide, at the County's expense, cremation for an
unclaimed body found in the County.
(Ord. 2017-1111-O, 12-5-2017)
8-7-3: DEFINITIONS:
INDIGENT: means the decedent and responsible family or next of kin: (1) are
without sufficient assets or means to pay for the cost of typical funeral
services, and (2) have an income below or equal to the poverty threshold as
provided annually by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services.
UNCLAIMED: means a decedent that is not survived by any of the following:
spouse, child, parent, sibling, grandchildren, grandparent, or a person acting
as the decedent’s representative under a signed authorization of the decedent.
(Ord. 2022-1216-O, 8-16-2022)
8-7-4: WHEN THE COUNTY IS RESPONSIBLE FOR CREMATION:
The County has the responsibility to provide for the remains of an unclaimed
dead. The County is not responsible for the decent burial of an unclaimed body
found in the County if the body is requested by the Dean of the School of
Medicine at the University of Utah under Utah Code Annotated section 53B-17-
301. It shall be presumed that the deceased had no known family or relatives at
the time of death if a search was made for the deceased person’s family or
relatives, pursuant to section 8-7-6 of this chapter, and none were found, and
no family or relative claimed the deceased person’s body within five (5)
business days after the deceased person’s death.
(Ord. 2022-1216-O, 8-16-2022)
8-7-5: WHEN THE COUNTY MAY ASSUME RESPONSIBILITY FOR CREMATION:
If a body is claimed, the responsibility for providing for the burial lies with
the deceased person’s estate or his/her family members pursuant to Utah Code
Annotated section 17-14-2 (1953, as amended). The County legislative body may
if it considers it necessary and expedient, provide for the cremation of
indigent persons who die within the County 1 .
The County will determine indigency by applying the poverty guidelines
established by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services as presented
annually by the Office of the Assistant Secretary for Planning and Evaluation.
Family members of the decedent shall submit an application for assistance
directly to the County. The County will make determinations to provide for the
cremation of an indigent person on a case-by-case basis with supportive
findings, as provided in the application for assistance, to the necessity and
expediency for doing so. If the County provides for the cremation of an
indigent person, the family members will forfeit any claim to the cremated
remains of the deceased person.
(Ord. 2022-1216-O, 8-16-2022)
 
Notes
1 1. UCA § 17-53-221.
8-7-6: SEARCH FOR DECEDENT’S WILL, FAMILY OR RELATIVES:
In determining whether an unclaimed decedent had known family or relatives, the
County Attorney is entitled to rely on the report of law enforcement agencies.
(Ord. 2017-1111-O, 12-5-2017; amd. Ord. 2022-1216-O, 8-16-2022)
8-7-7: CREMATION SERVICES:
The bodies of those dead for whom the County has responsibility shall be
disposed of by cremation. As used in this chapter, “cremation services” shall
not be deemed to include the interment of cremated remains in a burial plot,
grave, tomb or mausoleum, nor the conducting of memorial or funeral services at
County expense, and such remains shall be disposed of at the discretion of the
mortuary responsible for cremating, such disposal to be performed with all due
respect for the dead.
(Ord. 2017-1111-O, 12-5-2017; amd. Ord. 2022-1216-O, 8-16-2022)
8-7-8: COUNTY ATTORNEY TO AUTHORIZE CREMATION:
The Washington County Attorney may approve and authorize the cremation of an
unclaimed decedent.
(Ord. 2017-1111-O, 12-5-2017; amd. Ord. 2022-1216-O, 8-16-2022)
8-7-9: COUNTY ATTORNEY IMMUNE FROM LIABILITY:
The County Attorney is immune from liability, both personally and officially,
for actions taken in good faith pursuant to this chapter.
(Ord. 2017-1111-O, 12-5-2017; amd. Ord. 2022-1216-O, 8-16-2022)
CHAPTER 8
RECOVERY OF EXPENSES FOR HAZARDOUS MATERIALS EMERGENCIES
SECTION:
8-8-1: Definitions
8-8-2: Recovery Of Expenses
8-8-3: Cost Recovery Procedure
8-8-4: Action To Recover Costs
8-8-5: Expenses Of Other Responding Entities
8-8-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms, phrases and words shall
have the following meanings:
EXPENSES: All costs incurred for the response, containment and/or removal and
disposal of hazardous materials on initial remedial action. It includes, but is
not necessarily limited to, the actual labor costs of government and other
personnel, including workers' compensation benefits, fringe benefits,
administrative overhead, and any costs of equipment, equipment operation,
materials, disposal and any contract labor or materials.
HAZARDOUS MATERIALS EMERGENCY: A sudden and unexpected release of any substance
that, because of its quantity, concentration or physical, chemical or
infectious characteristics, presents a direct and immediate threat to public
safety or the environment, and requires immediate action to mitigate the
threat. (Ord. 2003-825-O, 1-21-2003)
8-8-2: RECOVERY OF EXPENSES:
   A.   Authorized: Those persons or entities whose negligent or intentional
actions cause or create, in whole or in part, a hazardous materials emergency
within the boundaries of the county are liable to the county for all costs and
expenses incurred in or arising from response to such hazardous materials
emergency by the county and any other political subdivision, agency or
cooperative entity. The county shall recover all such costs and expenses,
including reasonable attorney fees, litigation expenses and court costs
incurred in, related to or arising out of all cost recovery efforts and
enforcement of the terms of this chapter.
   B.   Rate Established: All costs and expenses shall be billed at the current
rate established and approved by resolution of the executive committee of the
interlocal agreement for cooperative hazardous materials protection and
services.
   C.   Payment Not Admission: The payment of expenses under this section does
not constitute an admission of liability or negligence in any legal action for
damages. (Ord. 2003-825-O, 1-21-2003)
8-8-3: COST RECOVERY PROCEDURE:
   A.   Investigation: The county shall investigate and determine the person or
entity responsible for causing or creating the hazardous materials emergency
and shall notify the responsible party in writing of said determination of
responsibility and the amount of costs and expenses incurred by the county in
responding to the hazardous materials emergency.
   B.   Notice Requirements; Appeal: The notice required by subsection A of
this section shall specify that the party determined to be responsible for
causing or creating the hazardous materials emergency has the right to appeal
the decision determining responsibility to the governing body of the county and
shall specify a deadline for filing the notice of appeal and the person or
office in which it must be filed. The deadline for filing the notice of appeal
shall not be less than fifteen (15) days from the date of the notice.
   C.   Hearing Procedure: In the event a notice of appeal is filed, the
hearing before the governing body shall be an informal public hearing, and the
parties shall not be required to adhere to the Utah rules of civil procedure or
evidence. The appealing party and the county shall each be entitled to present
evidence and argument in support of their respective positions, in accordance
with procedures established at the hearing by the governing body.
   D.   Decision Final: The decision of the governing body shall be final.
(Ord. 2003-825-O, 1-21-2003)
8-8-4: ACTION TO RECOVER COSTS:
In the event the responsible party fails or refuses to pay all of the costs and
expenses determined by the county related to or arising out of the county's
response to the hazardous materials emergency within thirty (30) days after
assessment or after the governing body's decision on an appeal, the county may
initiate a legal action to recover such costs, including reasonable attorney
fees and costs. (Ord. 2003-825-O, 1-21-2003)
8-8-5: EXPENSES OF OTHER RESPONDING ENTITIES:
   A.   County To Recover: In the event that personnel and equipment from other
political subdivisions, agencies or cooperative entities shall respond to
assist with the hazardous materials emergency, then the county shall recover
costs and expenses incurred by such other political subdivisions, agencies or
cooperative entities as part of the county's cost recovery efforts.
   B.   Reimbursement: Upon recovery of costs and expenses from the responsible
party, the county is authorized to reimburse such other political subdivisions,
agencies or cooperative entities for their actual costs incurred in responding
to the hazardous materials emergency. (Ord. 2003-825-O, 1-21-2003)
CHAPTER 9
COLLECTION OF DELINQUENT FEES AND UNPAID CHARGES
SECTION:
8-9-1: Statutory Authority
8-9-2: Purpose Of Provisions
8-9-3: Certification; Lien
8-9-1: STATUTORY AUTHORITY:
The statutory authority for enacting this chapter is Utah Code Annotated
sections 17-53-208 and 17A-2-1321, as amended. (Ord. 728, 9-13-1999)
8-9-2: PURPOSE OF PROVISIONS:
The purpose of this chapter is to provide a mechanism to collect delinquent
fees and charges for water, sewer, garbage and fire protection services
supplied to residents and landowners within special service districts in the
county. (Ord. 728, 9-13-1999)
8-9-3: CERTIFICATION; LIEN:
   A.   Fees and charges for water, sewer, garbage and fire protection services
supplied by a special service district shall, if not paid when due, be
certified to the county treasurer and the county assessor as delinquent.
   B.   These delinquent fees and charges, together with penalties and
applicable interest, shall immediately upon this certification, become a lien
on the delinquent premises on parity with and collected at the same time and in
the same manner as general county taxes that are a lien on the premises.
   C.   The county treasurer shall adopt procedural rules regarding the
submission of the certified list of delinquent fees and charges to the county
treasurer's office. (Ord. 728, 9-13-1999)

CHAPTER 11
ECONOMIC INCENTIVES TO PRIVATE ENTERPRISE
SECTION:
8-11-1: Statutory And Case Law Authority
8-11-2: Purpose Of Provisions
8-11-3: Economic Incentive Criteria And Requirements
8-11-1: STATUTORY AND CASE LAW AUTHORITY:
The statutory authority for enacting this chapter is Utah Code Annotated
sections 17-53-223 and 17-50-303, as amended. The case law authority for
enacting this chapter is Price Development Company et al v. Orem City et al,
995 P.2d 1237 (Utah 2000), and Salt Lake County Commission v. Salt Lake County
Attorney, 985 P.2d 899 (Utah 1999). (Ord. 2004-848-O, 5-4-2004)
8-11-2: PURPOSE OF PROVISIONS:
The purpose of this chapter is to establish the criteria by which the county
may provide economic incentives to private enterprise to aid in the economic
development of the county. (Ord. 2004-848-O, 5-4-2004)
8-11-3: ECONOMIC INCENTIVE CRITERIA AND REQUIREMENTS:
The county may provide economic incentives to private enterprise (not a
nonprofit entity) under the following conditions:
   A.   The county commission must find that each economic incentive to private
enterprise reflects a valid county public purpose.
   B.   Before an economic incentive is made to private enterprise, the county
commission must make a finding, supported by documentation, that it has
received fair market value in exchange for the incentive being provided by the
county.
   C.   In a transaction, each year's exchange must meet the standards set
forth in subsections A and B of this section independent of every other year.
(Ord. 2004-848-O, 5-4-2004)
CHAPTER 12
RECREATION, ARTS, AND PARKS TAX
SECTION:
8-12-1: Title
8-12-2: Statutory Authority
8-12-3: Purpose And Use Of Revenue
8-12-4: Imposition; Amount
8-12-5: Collection
8-12-6: Distribution Of Revenues; Advisory Board
8-12-7: Incorporation Of State Law
8-12-8: Operative And Expiration Dates Of Tax
8-12-1: TITLE:
This chapter shall be known as the RECREATION, ARTS, AND PARKS ("RAP") TAX
ORDINANCE OF WASHINGTON COUNTY. (Ord. 2014-1045-O, 12-16-2014)
8-12-2: STATUTORY AUTHORITY:
The authority for imposing this tax is derived from Utah code section 59-12-701
et seq. (West 2014). (Ord. 2014-1045-O, 12-16-2014)
8-12-3: PURPOSE AND USE OF REVENUE:
   A.   The ordinance codified in this chapter is enacted to provide the county
with a source of revenue specifically for the purposes of funding recreational
and cultural facilities and cultural organizations in Washington County such as
the following:
      1.   Publicly owned or operated athletic fields, parks, playgrounds,
gymnasiums, swimming pools, campgrounds, trails, or other facilities used for
recreational purposes; and
      2.   Nonprofit organizations, institutions, and municipal or county
cultural councils having as their primary purpose the advancement and
preservation of history, art, music, theater, dance, cultural arts, or natural
history.
   B.   The funds generated from the tax imposed in this chapter shall be used
solely for the purpose described in subsection A of this section and in
accordance with all applicable state law, rules, and regulations. (Ord. 2014-
1045-O, 12-16-2014; amd. Ord. 2024-1278-O, 11- -2024)
8-12-4: IMPOSITION; AMOUNT:
There is levied for collection a local sales and use tax of one- tenth of one
percent to fund recreational and cultural facilities and cultural organizations
in Washington County. (Ord. 2014-1045-O, 12-16-2014)
8-12-5: COLLECTION:
Taxes imposed under this chapter shall be administered, collected, and enforced
in accordance with applicable state law. (Ord. 2014-1045-O, 12-16-2014)
8-12-6: DISTRIBUTION OF REVENUES; ADVISORY BOARD:
   A.   The distribution of revenues shall be in accordance with all applicable
laws, rules, and regulations and shall be subject to any policies and
procedures adopted by the county commission.
   B.   An advisory board shall be appointed by the county commission and
charged with making recommendations for the disbursement of funds to cultural
organizations.
      1.   The advisory board shall consist of seven (7) members.
      2.   Advisory board members shall be appointed for terms lasting four (4)
years; however, board members that are appointed to fill a vacancy where a term
was not completed shall serve for the remainder of the original term.
      3.   Initially, three (3) of the board members shall serve terms of two
(2) years in order to stagger the terms.
   C.   The advisory board may propose policies and procedures to the county
commission.
   D.   The county may distribute revenues directly to cities and towns located
within the county if the municipal recipients agree, through an interlocal
agreement, to follow all applicable state and county laws and ordinances with
respect to the distribution of RAP tax revenues. (Ord. 2014-1045-O, 12-16-2014;
amd. Ord. 2024-1278-O, 11- -2024)
8-12-7: INCORPORATION OF STATE LAW:
   A.   Except as herein provided, and except insofar as they are inconsistent
with the provisions of the county option for funding botanical, cultural, and
zoological organizations legislation codified at Utah Code Annotated, section
59-12-701 et seq., all of the provisions of part 1, chapter 12, title 59, Utah
Code Annotated, 1953, as amended, in force and effect on the effective date
hereof, insofar as they relate to the tax imposed by this chapter are adopted
and made a part of this chapter as though fully set forth herein.
   B.   Wherever, and to the extent that in part 1, chapter 12, title 59, Utah
Code Annotated, 1953, as amended, the state of Utah is named or referred to as
the taxing agency, the name of this county shall be substituted therefor.
Nothing in this subsection shall be deemed to require substitution of the name
of the county for the word “state” when that word is used as part of the title
of the state tax commission, or of the constitution of the state of Utah, nor
shall the name of the county be substituted for that of the state in any
section when the result of that substitution would require action to be taken
by or against the county or any agency thereof, rather than by or against the
state tax commission in performing the functions incident to the administration
or operation of this chapter. (Ord. 2014-1045-O, 12-16-2014; amd. Ord. 2024-
1278-O, 11- -2024)
8-12-8: OPERATIVE AND EXPIRATION DATES OF TAX:
   A.   The county previously imposed the RAP Tax for a 10-year period
beginning on April 1, 2015. The RAP Tax is hereby reauthorized and is imposed
for another 10-year period starting on April 1, 2025, which is the first day of
a calendar quarter after a ninety (90) day period beginning on the date the
Utah state tax commission receives notice of the reauthorization of the RAP
Tax.
   B.   Unless reapproved by voters and reauthorized by the county commission,
the RAP Tax shall expire and no longer be collected after March 31, 2035. (Ord.
2014-1045-O, 12-16-2014; amd. Ord. 2024-1278-O, 11- -2024)
CHAPTER 13
REQUEST FOR REDUCTION OF PERSONAL PROPERTY TAX RELATED INTEREST, PENALTIES, AND
FEES
SECTION:
8-13-1: Statutory Authority
8-13-2: Purpose
8-13-3: Processing Of Requests For Reductions
8-13-4: Conditions For Acceptance Of Requests For Reductions
8-13-1: STATUTORY AUTHORITY:
The statutory authority for this chapter is Utah code section 59-2-307. (Ord.
2015-1052-O, 9-1-2015)
8-13-2: PURPOSE:
This chapter is enacted to provide taxpayers with an avenue to request a
reduction in personal property tax related interest, penalties, and fees. This
chapter will provide consistency of procedure and uniformity of application in
the processing of requests for reduction of certain personal property tax
related interest, penalties, and fees. (Ord. 2015-1052-O, 9-1-2015)
8-13-3: PROCESSING OF REQUESTS FOR REDUCTIONS:
   A.   Requests for reduction of personal property tax related interest,
penalties, and fees pursuant to this chapter shall be by written application
and shall set out the specific basis for the request as described in section
8-13-4 of this chapter and shall include evidence supporting the request.
   B.   All requests shall be submitted to the county assessor's office on or
before October 1 of the taxable year.
   C.   Within sixty (60) days of submission, the county commission will review
and make a determination to grant, grant in part, or deny the request. (Ord.
2015-1052-O, 9-1-2015)
8-13-4: CONDITIONS FOR ACCEPTANCE OF REQUESTS FOR REDUCTIONS:
In order to grant a request for reduction of personal property tax related
interest, penalties, and fees, the county commission must find that one or more
of the following conditions were present during the filing period set forth in
section 59-2-306 of the Utah code.
   A.   A medical emergency to the property owner or an immediate family member
of the property owner and no co-owner or designated representative was
reasonably able to file the signed statement;
   B.   The property owner or an immediate family member of the property owner
died and no co-owner or designated representative was reasonably able to file
the signed statement;
   C.   The county did not comply with an applicable notification requirement
in the Utah code or this code;
   D.   A factual error existed in the county records pertaining to the subject
property (this type of request is limited to correction of the factual error
and any resulting changes to the property’s valuation);
   E.   Extraordinary and unanticipated circumstances occurring during the
filing period and no owner or designated representative was reasonably able to
file the signed statement; or
   F.   Upon any other showing by the property owner that a reasonable cause
existed during the filing period. (Ord. 2015-1052-O, 9-1-2015; amd. Ord. 2024-
1280-O, 12-17-2024)

TITLE 9
BUILDINGS, LAND AND CONSTRUCTION
CHAPTER 1
CODES AND REGULATIONS
SECTION:
9-1-1: Title
9-1-2: Statutory Authority

9-1-5: Compliance With Codes

9-1-1: TITLE:
This chapter shall be known as the BUILDING CODE ORDINANCE OF WASHINGTON
COUNTY. (Ord. 2007-929-O, 2-6-2007)

sections 17-53-208, 17-53-223, 17-27a-102, 58-56-4 and 58-56-8 (1953, as
amended). (Ord. 2007-929-O, 2-6-2007)

The purpose of this chapter is to protect the health, safety and welfare of the
citizens of Washington County by adopting as the Building Codes of Washington
County the codes listed herein and to establish a method of appeal by which a
person disputing the application and interpretation of a Building Code may
appeal and receive timely review of the disputed issues. (Ord. 2007-929-O, 2-6-
2007)
9-1-4: ADOPTION OF CODES BY REFERENCE:
The most recent version adopted by the State of Utah of the following codes and
the appendices and the State’s amendment are incorporated by reference and
adopted as the Building Codes of Washington County: International Building Code
including appendix J, International Mechanical Code, International Fuel Gas
Code, International Residential Code including appendix J, International Fire
Code including appendices A, B, C, and D as amended by the State of Utah,
International Energy Conservation Code, International Plumbing Code, National
Electrical Code, HUD Code, and the Model Manufactured Home Installation
Standard. Three (3) copies of each of the codes shall be kept on file in the
Office of the Washington County Clerk for use and examination by the public:
   A.   The cited sections of the International Residential Code are amended as
follows:

   C.   International Urban-Wildland Interface Code, 2003 Edition:
      1.   The international urban-wildland interface code, 2003 edition, as
currently amended by the division of forestry, fire and state lands under rule
R652-122 of the Utah administrative code (the 2006 Utah wildland-urban
interface code), is hereby adopted as the wildland-urban interface code of
Washington County, for regulating and governing the mitigation of hazard to
life and property from the intrusion of fire from wildland exposures, fire from
adjacent structures and prevention of structure fires from spreading to
wildland fuels as therein provided; providing for the issuance of permits and
the collection of fees therefor; and each and all of the regulations,
provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said wildland-urban interface
code on file in the office of the Washington County clerk are hereby referred
to, adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this chapter, with
the additions, insertions and changes as set forth in rule R652-122 of the Utah
administrative code and as set forth in subsection C2 of this section.
      2.   The following sections are hereby revised (stricken language is
removed, underlined language is added):
Chapter 1
Section 101.1 Scope
Exceptions:
      1.   A structure that is no more than 1,000 square feet, with the
required defensible space and without reasonable access to a municipal, or
similar, water system.
      2.   A structure that originally did not exceed 1,000 square feet, when
adding an addition of 25% or less to the total original square footage.
Chapter 2
Definitions
Approved. Acceptable to the building official, fire official, or authority
having jurisdiction. Approval by the code official as the result of review,
investigation or tests conducted by the code official or by reason of accepted
principles or tests by national authorities, or technical or scientific
organizations.
Chapter 4
Section 402.2 Individual Structures
402.2.1 Access. Individual structures hereafter constructed or relocated into
or with-in the wildland urban interface areas shall be provided with approved
fire apparatus access roads in accordance with the international fire code and
driveways in accordance with section 403.2. ...
402.2.2 Water Supply
Exceptions:
2. Buildings containing only private garages, carports, sheds and agricultural
buildings with a floor area of no more than 600 square feet. A structure that
is no more than 1,000 square feet, with the required defensible space and
without reasonable access to a municipal, or similar, water system.
3. A structure that originally did not exceed 1,000 square feet, when adding an
addition of 25% or less to the total original square footage.
Section 403.2 Driveways
Exceptions:
1. New structures and additions to existing structures on existing approved
driveways.
2. Approved driveways through easements less than the required driveway width.
Section 403.3 Fire Apparatus Access Roads. When required, fire apparatus access
roads shall be all weather approved roads with...
   Exceptions:
1. Fire apparatus access roads on federal and state land.
2. Fire apparatus access roads through easements less than the required road
width.
3. Existing fire apparatus access roads.
(Ord. 2015-1048-O, 4-7-2015; amd. Ord. 2019-1138-O, 6-4-2019; Ord. 2021-1188-O,
9-7-2021)
9-1-5: COMPLIANCE WITH CODES:
It shall be unlawful to construct, alter, or repair any building or structure
in the county in violation of, or without complying with the appropriate
provisions of, such regulations. (Ord. 2007-929-O, 2-6-2007)
9-1-6: STANDARDS:
All work on the construction, alteration and repair of buildings and other
structures shall be performed in a good, workmanlike manner according to
accepted standards and practices in the trade. The provisions of the codes
adopted in section
9-1-4 of this chapter shall be considered to be standard and acceptable
practices for all matters concerning building construction, not otherwise
provided for by ordinance. (Ord. 2007-929-O, 2-6-2007)
9-1-7: BUILDING PERMIT REQUIRED:
No building permit shall be issued unless the applicable requirements of this
chapter and the building codes adopted herein, the county zoning ordinance,
subdivision ordinance, groundwater protection ordinance and all other
ordinances pertaining thereto are met. All work done under any building permit
issued herein shall be in full compliance with the applicable requirements of
this chapter, the zoning ordinance, the subdivision ordinance, the groundwater
protection ordinance and all other ordinances pertaining thereto. (Ord. 2007-
929-O, 2-6-2007)
9-1-8: BUILDING PERMIT FEES:
Building permit, plan review, and investigation fees shall be assessed in
accordance with the table of building permit fees adopted by the county
commission. (Ord. 2007-929-O, 2-6-2007)
9-1-9: CERTIFICATE OF OCCUPANCY:
No certificate of occupancy for any building or structure constructed, altered,
or repaired after the adoption hereof, shall be issued unless such building or
structure was constructed, altered, or repaired in compliance with the
applicable requirements of this chapter, the zoning ordinance, the subdivision
ordinance, the groundwater protection ordinance and all other ordinances
pertaining thereto. (Ord. 2007-929-O, 2-6-2007)
9-1-10: ADMINISTRATION:
The county building inspector shall have the power and duty to enforce the
provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 2007-929-O, 2-6-2007)
9-1-11: INTERPRETATION:
Whenever in the codes adopted by reference herein it is provided that anything
must be done to the approval or subject to the direction of the building
inspector, or any other officer of the county, this shall be construed to give
any such officer only the discretion of determining whether the rules and
standards established by ordinance have been complied with; and no such
provision shall be construed as giving any officer discretionary powers as to
what such codes or standards shall be, or power to require conditions not
prescribed by ordinance or to enforce ordinance provisions in an arbitrary or
discriminatory manner. (Ord. 2007-929-O, 2-6-2007)
9-1-12: BOARD OF BUILDING APPEALS:
   A.   Established: There is hereby created the board of building appeals,
hereinafter called the board. The board shall consist of five (5) members,
appointed by the county commission. No county officer or employee may serve on
the board. In making appointments, the county commission will consider the
integrity, impartiality and knowledge of building construction of the potential
members.
   B.   Terms, Officers, Quorum: Members of the board shall serve for five (5)
year terms, provided that the persons first appointed shall serve for one, two
(2), three (3), four (4) and five (5) year terms so one term will expire each
year. Terms will start on January 1. The board shall select from among its
members a chair, vice chair and secretary. Three (3) board members constitute a
quorum and decisions of the board must be by a majority vote of those present
at a meeting.
   C.   Services And Supplies: The county commission shall assign office help
and provide supplies for the work of the board.
   D.   No Compensation: Members of the board shall serve without pay. Board
members may be reimbursed for their expenses. (Ord. 2007-929-O, 2-6-2007)
9-1-13: APPEAL PROCEDURE:
Any person aggrieved by a decision of the building department or building
official applying the building codes adopted by this chapter may appeal in the
manner provided in Title 10 chapter 2. (Ord. 2007-929-O, 2-6-2007; amd. Ord.
2022-1205-O, 3-15-2022)
CHAPTER 2
IMPACT FEES
ARTICLE A. ENVIRONMENTAL MITIGATION IMPACT FEE FOR THE WASHINGTON COUNTY
HABITAT CONSERVATION PLAN
SECTION:
9-2A-1: Findings
9-2A-2: Established
9-2A-3: Purpose
9-2A-4: Accounting; Use Of Funds
9-2A-5: Reporting Requirements
9-2A-6: Sunset Dates
9-2A-7: Interlocal Agreement
9-2A-1: FINDINGS:
Washington County, Utah makes the following findings:
   A.   Much of Washington County is critical habitat for the Mojave Desert
Tortoise, which is listed as a threatened species under the Endangered Species
Act of 1973.
   B.   To mitigate impacts to the Mojave Desert Tortoise habitat the Habitat
Conservation Plan was established in 1995 and later restated and amended in
2020.
   C.   The Habitat Conservation Plan is required by the United States Fish and
Wildlife Service for Washington County’s Incidental Take Permit No. TE036719.
   D.   The Habitat Conservation Plan and the Incidental Take Permit resolves
conflicts with the Endangered Species Act of 1973 and permit growth,
development, and other covered activities to occur in the Mojave Desert
Tortoise habitat of Washington County.
   E.   The Habitat Conservation Plan established the Red Cliffs Desert
Reserve, a large area of land approximately 69,000 acres in size, which is the
primary conservation measure to offset the impacts allowed under the Incidental
Take Permit.
   F.   An environmental mitigation impact fee is necessary to finance the
Washington County Habitat Conservation Plan, including the management and
monitoring of actions and activities within the Red Cliffs Desert Reserve and
provides other environmental protections throughout the County.
   G.   The environmental mitigation impact fee imposed herein bears a
reasonable relationship to the administration and finance of the required
Habitat Conservation Plan. (Ord. 2024-1249-O, 2-6-2024)
9-2A-2: ESTABLISHED:
There is established an environmental mitigation impact fee under the authority
of Utah Code Ann. § 1 l-36a-205 (as amended). The environmental mitigation
impact fee shall be 0.2 percent of the total construction value of new building
permits, payable with the issuance of building permits on all new residential,
commercial, and industrial construction within the Incidental Take Permit Area
in unincorporated Washington County. This environmental mitigation impact fee
shall not apply to building permits for remodeling, add-ons of existing
structures, or outbuildings. (Ord. 547, 8-30-1993, eff. 10-1-1993; amd. Ord.
2021-1173-O, 4-20-2021; Ord. 2024-1249-O, 2-6-2024)
9-2A-3: PURPOSE:
The environmental mitigation impact fees assessed herein are required to
finance the administration of the Habitat Conservation Plan. (2004 Code; amd.
Ord. 2024-1249-O, 2-6-2024)
9-2A-4: ACCOUNTING; USE OF FUNDS:
The Washington County Treasurer is hereby directed to accumulate the
environmental mitigation impact fee funds in a separate account designated the
“endangered species conservation account” and to hold the funds collected to be
used for endangered species issues, including the Habitat Conservation Plan as
directed by the Washington County Board of Commissioners. This account shall
also receive, hold, accumulate^and disburse environmental mitigation impact fee
funds imposed by and from participating municipalities. (Ord. 547, 8-30-1993,
eff. 10-1-1993; amd. Ord. 2024-1249-O, 2-6-2024)
9-2A-5: REPORTING REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   The Washington County Habitat Conservation Plan Department shall
provide the Washington County Board of Commissioners with an annual report. The
annual report shall provide general updates on the Habitat Conservation Plan,
the Red Cliffs Desert Reserve, environmental mitigation impact fees collected,
and expenditures. The annual report shall be legislatively approved and
adopted.
   B.   Once approved, Washington County shall provide the participating
municipalities with the annual report.
   C.   Pursuant to
9-2A-6 , the Washington County Habitat Conservation Plan Department shall
conduct a study every five years to determine whether or not the environment
mitigation impact fee is still required to finance the Habitat Conservation
Plan. This study shall serve as the annual report required under 9-2A-5(A).
(Ord. 547, 8-30-1993, eff. 10-1-1993; amd. Ord. 2024-1249-O, 2-6-2024)
9-2A-6: SUNSET DATES:
Pursuant to Utah Code Ann. §1 l-36a-205 (as amended) the environmental
mitigation impact fee assessed herein shall sunset every five years, beginning
in 2030. The Washington County Board of Commissioners shall review the
environmental mitigation impact fee assessed herein in March of every fifth
year, starting in 2025. The review is to determine whether or not the
environmental mitigation impact fee is still required to finance the Habitat
Conservation Plan and if the Washington County Board of Commissioners
determines the environmental mitigation impact fee is still required to finance
the Habitat Conservation Plan, it shall reauthorize the impact fee. (2004 Code;
amd. Ord. 2024-1249-O, 2-6-2024)
9-2A-7: INTERLOCAL AGREEMENT:
This article shall be subject to an interlocal agreement between Washington
County and participating municipalities in the County, a copy of which is on
file in the Washington County Administrative Office, and is incorporated herein
by reference. (Ord. 547, 8-30-1993, eff. 10-1-1993; amd. 2004 Code; amd. Ord.
2024-1249-O, 2-6-2024)
CHAPTER 3
AGRICULTURE PROTECTION AREAS
SECTION:
9-3-1: Agriculture Protection Area Advisory Board
9-3-2: Minimum Size For Agriculture Protection Areas
9-3-3: Fees For Accepting And Processing Proposals
9-3-4: Filing Procedure
9-3-1: AGRICULTURE PROTECTION AREA ADVISORY BOARD:
   A.   Established: An agriculture protection area advisory board is hereby
established for the county pursuant to Utah Code Annotated section 17-41-201,
to perform the duties set out in Utah Code Annotated section 17-41-201, or any
later amendment or enactment of that section.
   B.   Appointment Of Board Members: The board of county commissioners shall
appoint five (5) members to the agriculture protection area advisory board
established under subsection A of this section. The board members shall be
appointed by resolution from among the members of the boards of supervisors of
the Dixie soil conservation districts located in the county.
   C.   Term Of Office; Removal: Each member appointed to the agriculture
protection area advisory board shall serve on said board until expiration of
that member's respective term on the soil conservation district boards of
supervisors. The board of county commissioners may remove and replace any
advisory board member for cause or for failure to perform the required duties.
   D.   Officers Of Board: The members of the agriculture protection area
advisory board shall select a chairperson, vice chairperson and secretary. The
chairperson and vice chairperson shall be selected from among the members of
the agriculture protection area advisory board. The secretary may be either a
member of the advisory board or a county employee. The selection of a county
employee to serve as the secretary must be approved by the board of county
commissioners.
   E.   Quorum And Rules Of Operation: Any three (3) members of the agriculture
protection area advisory board shall constitute a quorum of that board. All
actions of the board, except to adjourn a meeting at which there is not a
quorum present, must be made in a meeting at which a quorum is present. Any
actions of the agriculture protection area advisory board must be approved by
at least three (3) members of that board. All meetings shall be conducted in
accordance with the Utah open and public meetings act. The agriculture
protection area advisory board may adopt such additional rules of operation as
it deems necessary to govern its affairs. (Ord. 600, 7-17-1995)
9-3-2: MINIMUM SIZE FOR AGRICULTURE PROTECTION AREAS:
Pursuant to Utah Code Annotated section 17-41-301(5), or any later amendment or
enactment of that section, at least five (5) continuous acres must be included
in each agriculture protection area established within the county. (Ord. 600,
7-17-1995)
9-3-3: FEES FOR ACCEPTING AND PROCESSING PROPOSALS:
Any person filing a proposal to create an agriculture protection area pursuant
to Utah Code Annotated title 17, chapter 41 shall pay a fee at the time of
filing. The amount of the fee shall be established by the board of county
commissioners. Any person filing a proposal for creation of an agriculture
protection area shall reimburse the county for all publication costs incurred
by the county in publishing the notices required under Utah Code Annotated
title 17, chapter 41, or any subsequent amendment or enactment of that statute.
(Ord. 600, 7-17-1995)
9-3-4: FILING PROCEDURE:
All proposals to create agriculture protection areas within the county shall be
filed in the office of the county clerk/auditor. All proposals must be
accompanied by the filing fee established by the board of commissioners. (Ord.
600, 7-17-1995)
CHAPTER 4
FENCING OF PRIVATE PROPERTY
SECTION:
9-4-1: Legal Fence Defined
9-4-2: Fencing Required
9-4-3: Collection Of Damages
9-4-4: Exceptions
9-4-1: LEGAL FENCE DEFINED:
A "legal fence" is defined for the purposes of this chapter as a fence with not
less than four (4) horizontal barriers, consisting of wires, boards, poles or
other fence material in common use in the neighborhood, with posts set not more
than twenty feet (20') apart. The lower barrier shall not be more than twelve
inches (12") from the ground and the space between any two (2) barriers shall
not be more than twelve inches (12"), and the height of the top barrier must be
at least forty eight inches (48") above the ground. Every post shall be so set
as to withstand a horizontal strain of two hundred fifty (250) pounds at a
point four feet (4') from the ground, and each barrier shall be capable of
withstanding a horizontal strain of two hundred fifty (250) pounds at any point
midway between the posts. (Ord. 247, 9-8-1969)
9-4-2: FENCING REQUIRED:
The owners of all farms, subdivisions and other private property shall fence
their said property so as to prevent domestic animals from trespassing on such
farms, subdivisions and other private property. (Ord. 247, 9-8-1969; amd. 2004
Code)
9-4-3: COLLECTION OF DAMAGES:
Except as hereinafter provided, no person, firm or corporation shall be
entitled to collect damages and no court in this state shall award damages for
any trespass of livestock on farms, subdivisions and other private property in
the county, if such land, at the time of such trespass, shall not have been
enclosed by a legal fence. (Ord. 247, 9-8-1969)
9-4-4: EXCEPTIONS:
This chapter shall not apply in areas in the county used primarily for farming
purposes; provided, however, it shall apply to areas abutting land belonging to
the United States and used for grazing purposes. (Ord. 247, 9-8-1969)
CHAPTER 5
GRADING OR FENCING ADJACENT TO RED CLIFFS DESERT WILDLIFE RESERVE
SECTION:
9-5-1: Fencing Plan Approval
9-5-2: Grading Or Modifying Surfaces
9-5-3: Fencing Completed Prior To Surface Modification
9-5-4: Exceptions
9-5-5: Penalty
9-5-1: FENCING PLAN APPROVAL:
No plat shall be approved for any land bordering the Red Cliffs Desert Wildlife
Reserve unless and until the habitat conversation plan (HCP) administration has
first issued a written approval for a fencing plan along the border of the
reserve. In the event the HCP administration has not issued an approval or
objection to the proposed fencing plan within thirty (30) days of submission to
the administrator, the fencing plan shall be deemed approved as proposed. (Ord.
652, 7-28-1997)
9-5-2: GRADING OR MODIFYING SURFACES:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to grade or otherwise modify the
surface of any property within an area defined by the HCP as an "incidental
take" area, as more fully described on exhibit A, attached to ordinance 652,
which exhibit is on file in the county office, and which exhibit is
incorporated herein by this reference, unless and until a release form has been
received from the HCP administration stating that the property has been
surveyed for tortoises and any tortoises removed and that the property has been
authorized for development.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person to grade or otherwise modify the
surface of property, construct any improvements, or erect any structure on any
property located adjacent to the border of the Red Cliffs Desert Reserve, as
more fully described on exhibit B, attached to ordinance 652, which exhibit is
on file in the county office, and which exhibit is incorporated herein by this
reference, without first receiving a written approval for a fencing plan along
the border of the reserve as required by this chapter. (Ord. 652, 7-28-1997;
amd. 2004 Code)
9-5-3: FENCING COMPLETED PRIOR TO SURFACE MODIFICATION:
All fencing required by the approved fencing plan shall be completed before any
surface modification and, if the area is within an "incidental take area"
described on exhibit A, before the HCP administration commences survey and
removal of tortoises. (Ord. 652, 7-28-1997)
9-5-4: EXCEPTIONS:
Lots located in subdivisions for which plats were recorded on or before
February 23, 1996, and lots located in subdivisions recorded thereafter which
have met the requirements of this chapter, shall be exempt from the
requirements of sections
9-5-2 and
9-5-3 of this chapter. (Ord. 652, 7-28-1997)
9-5-5: PENALTY:
Each violation of this chapter shall constitute an infraction and, upon
conviction, subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 652, 7-28-1997; amd. 2004 Code)
TITLE 10
ZONING REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
GENERAL PROVISIONS
SECTION:
